PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, being concerned that the Australian Government, in breach of its own stated policies, has lifted the bans on the sale of uranium to France; demand that the Government re-impose the bans on such sales, and further, that the Government ratifies and strengthens the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty to prohibit uranium sales within the region.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card.

(2) That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combatting the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.

(3) That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life.
(4) That we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Taxation Office and other departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2 per cent discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 Oct. 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of the pensioner and surviving dependents-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term `extraordinary circumstances of the economy' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 Oct. 1986 to 1 July 1987 so that pensions are restored to the 9 Oct. 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 42 citizens), Button (from 10 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 60 citizens) and Collard (from 13 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke-free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutants, are available at all aerodromes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Related Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The costs of raising children are rising and the value of government provided economic assistance to families is declining.
Families raising children are providing a vital function to society and are deserving of government provided economic assistance.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
1. Restore family allowance payments to their 1976 real money value.
2. Provide for the regular and automatic indexation of family allowance payments.
3. Increase the value of the Dependant Spouse Rebate to $1851 per annum and convert it to a cash payment given directly to the non-income family spouse.
4. Amend the Family Income Supplement scheme so that its value is increased, its eligibility provisions widened and its withdrawal provisions eased.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security Amendment Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Maranoa Electorate respectively showeth that: The Social Security Amendment Bill 1987, Schedule 1, page 15, additional amendments of the Social Security Act 1947, part 1, omit ``Subsection 6 (1) (definition of `de facto spouse'):

Insert `and includes a person who, but for a law of a State or territory prohibiting sexual intercourse between the person and another person by reason only of the age of either person, would be such a person' after `to that other person'.'',
Substitute
``Subsection 6 (1) (definition of `de facto spouse'):
Insert `but does not include a person who is living with another person in a relationship prohibited by a law of a State or Territory' after `to that other person'.''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw Government Business, Notices of Motion Nos 1 and 2, standing in my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, Notices of Motion Nos 1 to 5 inclusive, standing in my name for the next day of sitting for disallowance of the Credit (Amendment) Ordinance 1987, the Electricity (Amendment) Ordinance 1987, the Public Service Board Determination No. 4 of 1987, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Order No. MS11/87, and Postal (Staff) By-laws Amendment No. 1 of 1987. I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Regulations and Ordinances Committee has examined aspects of this delegated legislation concerning the imposition of large penalties for certain offences; the need for brief explanatory statements to inform parliament and the community of the purpose and effect of certain kinds of delegated legislation; and the way in which by-laws and determinations provide for the exercise of important discretionary powers concerning employment matters in the Public Service and statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has received a satisfactory explanation for the level of penalties, a ministerial undertaking to provide explanatory statements, and a Public Service Board undertaking to ensure that the conferral of wide discretionary powers over individuals is expressly made, subject to their reasonable exercise. The Committee acknowledges the co-operation and advice it has received from the Minister for Primary Industry, the Minister for Territories, the Public Service Board and the Australian Postal Commission.
Delegated Legislation
For the information of honourable senators and others, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a more detailed summary of the Committee's scrutiny.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES COMMITTEE
ELECTRICITY (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE 1987

The Electricity (Amendment) Ordinance 1985 created a range of offences to ensure the saftey of electrical appliances in the A.C.T. Penalties ranging from $100 to $10,000 were imposed. The Electricity (Amendment) Ordinance 1987 increased these penalties, in some cases to levels 20 times higher than those originally prescribed. The new penalties range from $500 to $100,000.

It was the Committee's view that the maximum penalty to be imposed on an offender should be reasonably commensurate with the seriousness of the offence which an offender commits or is deterred from committing. However, where, under delegated legislation, a prescribed penalty appears to be set at a level beyond the confines of this rationale, the Committee considers that it has an obligation to determine whether the penalty is so high or so lacking in relative justification that it is unreasonable and an infringement of the Committee's principles relating to trespass on personal rights and liberties.

The Committee therefore, invited the Minister for Territories (the Honourable Gordon Scholes, M.P.) to explain why these penalties have been increased so significantly within a relatively short time of their initial prescription. The Minister informed the Committee that the original penalties in 1985 had been determined by the Attorney-General's Department without reference to the penalty levels applying to contraventions of the then proposed Division 1A of Part V of the Trade Practices Act 1974. They were instead determined in the context of establishing a uniform scheme for control of electrical articles and reflected proposed penalty levels in other States. Under the Trade Practices Act (as amended by the Trade Practices Revision Act 1986) the Attorney-General was given powers in relation to all consumer products which were similar to the powers conferred on the A.C.T. Electricity Authority under the Ordinance specifically in relation to electrical goods. However, the level of penalties prescribed under section 79 of the Act (as amended in 1986) were very different from the level prescribed under the Ordinance. The Committee accepted that there was a need for consistency in the level of penalties prescribed under both enactments. The Committee decided to withdraw its opposition to the Ordinance bearing in mind:
(i) the threat to life and limb which could arise from the criminal practices of an electrical goods manufacturer or supplier; and
(ii) the Parliament's previous endorsement of similar penalty levels in the broad Trade Practices area.
The Committee concluded that in these particular circumstances the increased penalties were not an undue trespass on personal rights and liberties.
POSTAL (STAFF) BY-LAWS AMENDMENT

These By-laws provided for certain internal grievance procedures, as avenues of redress for Australian Postal Commission employees who may feel aggrieved at managerial decisions. In examining delegated legislation made by a statutory authority to provide for internal managerial and organisational procedures the Committee's role is to be astute in ensuring that the imposition of parliamentary supervision does not unnecessarily hamper the organisation in the discharge of its managerial and functional roles. In its dealings with statutory authorities the Committee endeavours to strike an appropriate balance by applying its principles of legality, propriety, liberty and redress to the delegated legislation in a way which takes account of and makes allowance for the different relationship that exists between an employer and an employee.

In this case the Committee was concerned firstly, that reasons for disciplinary decisions be given in a timely manner. The Commission explained that explanatory guidelines issued to managers and supervisors would make it clear that this should be done. Secondly, the Committee sought assurances that a complainant would not be burdened with a requirement to forward to higher levels of management, official documents already available to lower level managers who had initially dealt with the grievance. The Commission explained that there would be no such requirement but that applicants in being required to give reasons for seeking a higher level of review would reasonably be in a position to focus and reflect on the nature of their grievance. Thirdly, the Committee was concerned whether the drafting of the by-laws was sufficiently clear to ensure that the higher levels of internal review addressed the real nature of a grievance rather than the procedure or nature of lower level reviews unless these themselves become the subject of a fresh grievance. The Commission assured the Committee that while this proper process was not explicitly stated in the by-law it was so essential for the operation of the overall procedures as to be clearly implied.
The Committee accepted the Commission's explanations and considered that, in the circumstances, it was not necessary to further enquire into the By-laws.
CREDIT (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE 1987

Under section 19 of the Principal Ordinance made in 1985, the Minister for Territories was empowered, at his discretion, to suspend the operation of the protective provisions of the new credit law. The Committee considered that such an unusual power should be exercised by an instrument made subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament. The Minister (the Hon. Gordon Scholes, M.P.) agreed to exercise the power by means of A.C.T. Regulations and he amended the legislation accordingly. The present Amendment Ordinance provides that exemptions from the law are now to be made instead by ministerial declarations which will however, remain subject to tabling and disallowance.

For some time now the Committee has been concerned about the implications of the perceived drift in delegated legislation, away from professionally prepared and presented instruments, to less formal documents of a legislative and quasi-legislative character. The Committee has understood that when delegated legislation is made in the form of, for example, Statutory Rules;
it is drafted by professionally skilled legislative drafters;
it is briefly annotated to identify previously related instruments;
it is printed and assigned a sequential number for citation and reference purposes;
it is considered by the Federal Executive Council and its attendant scrutiny processes;
it is tabled in Parliament with an explanatory statement indicating the authority under which it is made and briefly describing its purposes and impact; and finally
it is made available for wide dissemination to users and the public generally.

Each of these steps is an important part of the subordinate law making process, designed to provide some procedural as well as some parliamentary supervision over the exercise of ministerial powers to make law outside the procedures of the primary law-makers in parliament.

Apart from the involvement of the Federal Executive Council, which arises from the formal legislative empowering of the Governor-General to make delegated legislation, the Committee finds it difficult to accept that these procedural and presentational requirements should not be uniformly adopted for all delegated legislative instruments. That which may cause possible objection for financial reasons, namely the provision of a brief explanatory statement, should in reality have no significant resource implications at all. In practice a Minister, contemplating the making of a delegated instrument, will always insist on having before him or her a document or submission describing the purpose and import of the draft instrument he or she is considering. Such a document would, of course, with little redrafting, qualify as an explanatory statement to inform and assist the Parliament, before whose members the signed instrument is tabled for approval or dissent.

The Minister explained to the Committee that he preferred to make use of a declaratory mechanism rather than regulations to create exemptions in order to be in a position to respond more quickly and more flexibly to exemptions made in those other States with whose credit laws the A.C.T. Ordinance is in basic uniformity. The Minister indicated that there is a backlog of 25 State exemptions which need to be given effect to in the A.C.T. and thereafter it is anticipated that there will be a continuing need for approximately 6 exemptions per year. Finally, the Minister undertook to examine the resource implications of ensuring that an explanatory statement accompanied each of the new declarations.

The Committee is encouraged by the Minister's positive response to examine the question of providing explanatory notes. The Committee agreed to withdraw the notice of motion of disallowance to enable him to do this freely. At this stage however, the Committee remains solidly of the view that delegated legislation, although subordinate in nature, is nevertheless in the eyes of the courts and the community, a legislative activity capable of imposing heavy obligations and severe penalties. Such legislation, whether it takes the form of a statutory rule, an ordinance, a regulation, a by-law, a declaration, a notice, a principle, a plan, a guideline, a determination, a direction, an order or an instrument of some other nomenclature, is often highly technical, and seemingly incomprehensible to the extent that it may form a small amending part of a large regulatory jig saw. Nevertheless, it can impact very significantly on the rights and liberties of individuals and it may contain important subordinate policy initiatives of lasting significance. It is at the very least unfair, and it may indeed be a discourtesy, to a House of the Parliament and a Standing Committee functioning in a scrutiny role under its authority, not to have available to it an official explanatory document describing the legality, the purpose and the impact of the instrument.

It is very much the hope of the Committee that economic, uniform and adequate standards of presentation will be adopted for all instruments of delegated legislation which, regardless of their name, are submitted to Parliament for scrutiny.
AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK ORDER NO. MS11/87

The Committee invited the Minister for Primary Industry (the Hon. John Kerin, M.P.), who has portfolio responsibility for the Corporation, to consider the practice of ensuring that when presented to Parliament for scrutiny, future Orders should be accompanied by a brief explanation of their authority, import and implications. The Committee considered that adequate statements, contemporaneously prepared by the legal and policy experts responsible for the preparation of the Order, would be of value to Parliament and the Community. The Committee also raised with the Minister some technical problems concerning the clarity of the drafting of a part of that Order. The Minister has agreed that the provision of explanatory statements would be of assistance to the Parliament and he has directed his officials to consult with the Corporation to ensure that it is aware of the requirements of the Parliament in connection with the drafting and presentation of subordinate legislative instruments.
PUBLIC SERVICE BOARD DETERMINATION NO. 4 OF 1987

This Determination was designed to transfer from the Public Service Act, the Public Service Regulations, and other non-legislative Public Service documents, and remake in the form of a Determination, certain conditions of employment related to leave of absence, other than recreation and sick leave. The Determination also amended earlier provisions dealing with studies assistance. The Determination represented, in part, the implementation of Public Service streamlining proposals concerning conditions of service. It transferred from the Board to Departmental Secretaries certain powers and functions. In doing this, certain broad personal discretions were conferred on Secretaries and their delegates. The Committee sought from the Chairman of the Public Service Board, Dr Peter Wilenski, comments and advice on the conferral of personal or subjective discretions on Secretaries and delegates, whether it would be possible or acceptable to replace personal discretions with objective standards and whether the conferral of personal powers should be expressly qualified by reference to their ``reasonable'' exercise.

The Chairman of the Board, through one of his Commissioners, explained the background to the Determination, emphasising the Board's view that, in this particular area of personnel management, it was not desirable to avoid discretions when drafting conditions of service. Although it considered that, at law, the conferral of personal discretions was impliedly predicated on their reasonable exercise, nevertheless if for presentational reasons express reference should be made to the reasonable exercise of powers, the Determination could be amended to include a general declaratory provision to that effect.

In its frequent examination of delegated legislative instruments which embody conditions of employment of public service officers, Defence Force personnel or employees of statutory authorities, the Committee is careful to ensure that the performance of its role as a legislative scrutineer and watchdog does not unnecessarily interfere with the special relationship that exists between employers and employees. In this respect the Committee endeavours to ameliorate what is, sometimes, wrongly seen as its intrusive role, by applying its scrutiny principles in a way which ensures that excessive managerial zeal or discretion is properly checked rather than legislatively entrenched.

The Board expressed some reluctance to insert a qualifying clause into the Determination for ``presentational'' purposes arguing that ``most Secretaries and their delegates have a sufficiently sophisticated grasp of administrative law concepts for them to appreciate the need to act reasonably even though that is not specified in the provision''. After careful reflection however, and in the light of the detailed submission put to it by the Board, the Committee decided to accept the Board's suggestion that a general declaratory clause should appear in the Determination. The Committee considered that this initiative could have consequences beyond being a merely presentational gesture. It could assist the small number of Secretaries and delegates whom the Board acknowledges have not yet achieved that sophisticated grasp of administrative law concepts and the imperative to act reasonably attained by the majority of their peers and colleagues. Further it could underpin existing high standards of personnel management and reinforce employees' confidence in the integrity and professional judgement of Australia's most senior officials and their expert delegates.
The Committee is grateful to the Board for its alternative suggestion and commends it for the helpful submission it presented.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to table the Committee's correspondence, which is too lengthy to incorporate in Hansard. This is in accordance with the Committee's usual practice.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to provide for the filling of casual vacancies in the House of Representatives and for related purposes.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my second reading speech.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Introduction

The Commonwealth Electoral Act Amendment (By-Elections) Bill 1987 has two main purposes. The first is to provide rotation of names on ballot papers; the second is to provide for the filling of casual vacancies by a recount of the votes polled at the previous election. This will dispense with the need to have voters come to the poll for by-elections.
Purpose

The Bill makes provision for the rotation of names on the House of Representatives ballot paper so that no candidate is advantaged or disadvantaged by the donkey vote. Because the votes of those who could not care less will be shared among all candidates, the luck of a series of double randomised lotteries will no longer be able to determine the majority or even the nature of a government.

The Bill also makes provision for the filling of casual vacancies in the House of Representatives by a re-examination of the ballot cast at the previous general election. This will reinforce the compact which candidates make with the voters during the campaign, namely to serve for the duration of the next Parliament. In most areas, voters can also expect to be offered a wider selection of endorsed candidates from whom to choose.
Background

The ordinary processes of government will no longer grind to a holt as they did in 1982 when the Fraser government faced the media circuses of the Lowe and Flinders by-elections. Disaffected members will no longer be able to threaten chaos by resigning and forcing the government to hold a by-election at an awkward time.

However, depending on the way in which parties respond to the change, those members whose health declines will no longer feel obliged to hang on at immense personal cost just because the government could have a serious reverse at a by-election.

More and more members are choosing to resign part-way through an elected term instead of waiting until the next general election to leave politics. As the pressure of public life mount and more people come into Parliament with a clear intention to move on to another career after 10 or 12 years, we will be facing ever greater upheavals and disruption unless we act now. We certainly do not want to confront an epidemic similar to the run of 13 by-elections in the current New South Wales Legislative Assembly since February 1985.
ONE VOTE ONE VALUE IS IMPOSSIBLE WITHOUT FUNDAMENTAL REFORM

It is important to note that while these changes will inject greater fairness towards all candidates, and will encourage governments to look a little further into the future, they will not bring us any closer to one vote one value.
The results of the 1984 general election are a clear indication that more fundamental changes are needed to achieve fairness to the voters and to the parties.

The Australian Labor Party received 4,120,130 first preferences and won 82 seats, one for each 50,000 supporters. The Liberal Party won 45 seats as a result of its 2,978,891 votes, one for each 66,000 supporters. The National Party captured 21 seats with its 921,151 first preferences, one for each 44,000 supporters.
These glaring national disparities, which would create major political unrest in much of continental Europe, are even worse when the outcomes in each State in 1984 are considered.

For instance, in New South Wales the National Party won 10 seats at an average of one for each 31,800 supporters. Labor took 29 seats, one for each 50,300 first preferences. The Liberals filled the remaining 12 seats at a strike rate of one for each 82,500 votes.
In Tasmania, the Liberal Party received 133,173 votes-51.1 per cent-and emerged with all five seats. The other 127,273 voters may as well not have turned up for all that their efforts achieved.
As the following table shows, the outcome in other States was far from the one vote one value ideal that the reduction to 10 per cent in the tolerance in enrolment variations was supposed to herald.

The only effective way of removing these gross imbalances is to adopt a quota-preferential system of proportional representation as set out in the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment (Representation of the People) Bill introduced last year by my colleague Senator Macklin. As the Labor, Liberal and National parties all hope to benefit most from the iniquities of the current arrangements, we are forced to bring forward minor but important reforms nevertheless which go some way towards putting all candidates in an electorate on the same footing.
Rotation of names on ballot papers
THE DONKEY VOTE LOTTERY-AN AUTHENTIC AUSTRALIAN SOLUTION, BUT NOT THE MOST EQUITABLE ONE
Before the 1984 general election, the listing of candidates on House of Representatives ballot papers had been in strict alphabetical order.
This had several consequences for the behaviour of preselectors and the composition of the House of Representatives.

While the Democratic Labor Party had an unenviable reputation for putting up candidates whose surnames would put them at the top of the ballot paper, others also had more than a passing interest in the matter.

In 1982, Jonathan Kelly and Ian McAllister from the Department of Sociology at the ANU's Institute of Advanced Studies published `Ballot paper cues and the vote in Australia and Great Britain: alphabetic voting, sex, and title' in which they analysed voting at the 1974 and 1977 general elections. Using standard linear regression techniques, they found that in Australia a candidate with a name in the top third of the alphabet can expect to obtain an additional 2.5 per cent of the vote compared with counterparts in the bottom third of the alphabet, all other things being equal. About three-fifths of this difference was because `the major parties think the electorate are donkeys and choose candidates with names high in the alphabet'. The other two-fifths was explained by the advantage of being nearer the top of the ballot paper.

In a paper titled `The Donkey Vote', written before he became Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Barry Cohen, produced a table which indicated that the composition of the Senate in 1980 and since Federation was in accordance with the general distribution of names in the telephone directory, but that there was `an outrageous over-representation in earlier letters in the alphabet' in the House of Representatives.

Marginal seats were defined as those which could have changed hand with a swing of 5 per cent or less between 1969 and 1980.

The Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Act 1983 put an end to the tyranny of alphabet. Evidence put to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform had indicated how the draw for column places on the Senate ballot paper could be improved by carrying out the process in two rounds. The suggested double randomised draw for places was adopted for order of places on House of Representatives ballot papers also.

It is an interesting reflection on us as Australians that we insist upon having the fairest possible rules for the conduct of the lottery for places. However, once the two sets of draws are made, the die is cast and the donkey vote effect set for a particular electorate.

Most analyses put at between 1 and 3 per cent the proportion of the votes where the numbering is straight down the ballot paper, whether because the voters do not really care or they do not understand preferential voting. There are certainly differences between regions at any particular election.

At the 1984 general election, there were 25 seats where a change of mind by 2.5 per cent of the voters or less could have led to another candidate being elected. Only two of the 11 successful Labor candidates involved were assisted by the donkey vote, whereas 9 of the 14 successful Liberal and National candidates received that particular benefit.

In the electorates of Petrie, Casey, Denison, Gilmore, Flinders, the Northern Territory, and Macquarie, the two-party preferred vote for the elected candidate was 51.5 per cent or less. Several of the sitting members, all Liberals or Nationals, owe their election to their good fortune at the draw for places on the ballot paper.
The 1984 departures from one vote, one value may have been even significantly worse had it not been for the Opposition's luck of the lottery!
FAIRNESS FOR ALL CANDIDATES

The provisions of this Bill seek to give all candidates equal access to the most favourable places on the ballot paper, and hence to spread the donkey vote evenly. The details follow very much the work of the Liberal member of Tasmania's House of Assembly, Neil Robson.

In fact the idea was put forward in 1957 during the inquiry into electoral matters by a select committee of the House of Assembly. Although the Premier and Chairman of that committee, Mr Cosgrove, was receptive of the suggestion, it was apparently set aside when the Electoral Department said that rotational printing of ballot papers would create undue counting difficulties.

Neil Robson took up the idea because it enabled a more accurate reflection of the people's will. He introduced a private member's Bill in May 1977 and over the next 2 1/2 years promoted the merits of the change and sorted out the mathematical detail of the selection of the ballot paper permutations which treated all candidates fairly without creating horrendous problems for the printer.

His proposal affected both the single-member districts of the Legislative Council and the group columns on the ballot paper for the seven-member districts of the House of Assembly. The crisis brought about by allegations of overspending at the 1979 general election produced an atmosphere in which the Electoral Amendment Bill 1979 passed through both houses without amendment, and received the royal assent on 21 November 1979.
During the course of debate, the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Aulich, said:

This Bill will make the Hare-Clark system the fairest in the world. It is already one of the fairest but this, by first of all changing the relative positions of the big poll-getters in multi-member electorates and by rearranging the donkey vote so that it is shared out equally amongst every candidate in the electorate will make the system near perfect. There are other changes that I am sure we can make by regulation which will sharpen the system up but in effect what we are doing here today, if the rest of Australia is listening and if the rest of Australia is as honest as both sides of this House have been about electoral reform, will be reflected elsewhere in Australia later.

When he introduced this private member's Bill, Mr Robson circulated notes which pointed out the common practice in the United States of printing candidates' names in rotation, but generally following a single sequence. His contribution, as embodied in the Electoral Amendment Regulations (No. 2) 1979, was to devise a selection of sequences which gives all candidates equal access to the best places at the top and bottom of the column, and evenly spreads the benefit of other patterns where voters do not have any firm preferences beyond the first few.

His Bill, as does this one, further seeks fair treatment for all by requiring ballot papers to be collated and distributed at polling places in such a way that each sequence of names on the ballot paper is just as likely to be the one on the paper handed to a particular voter as any other.

The presence of party designations on each ballot paper, next to each candidate's name, and the availability of official assistance for those who are illiterate, means that each voter has an unfettered opportunity to make his or her wishes known. There is no longer any excuse for how-to-vote cards which at present constitute an enormous waste of resources, and which with rotational printing would confuse as many people as they would assist.
As Neil Robson put it:

If the listing of names on the ballot-paper were rotated, thereby giving every candidate an equal share of the ``donkey'' or ``down-the-ticket'' votes, then the choice of Members of Parliament would be made-as in justice to the electors it should-by the deliberate decisions expressed through the ballot box. If the ``donkey vote'' were thus neutralised by rotational printing, a candidate would be assured that this success or failure would depend on the number of deliberately selected votes which he had won, not on whether he lost or gained a portion of votes due to the luck of the draw for position on the ballot-paper.
House of Representatives-Filling of casual vacancies

The second arm of this Bill provides for the orderly filling of casual vacancies which arise in the House of Representatives, without requiring the voters of that electorate to return to the polling places. Only if none of the unsuccessful candidates at the previous general election indicates a willingness to act if elected will there be a need for a supplementary election after the calling of nominations afresh.
Section 33 of the Australian Constitution says:

Whenever a vacancy happens in the House of Representatives, the Speaker shall issue his writ for the election of a new member, or if there is no Speaker or if he is absent from the Commonwealth the Governor-General in Council may issue the writ.
Since the first Parliament convened in Melbourne in 1901, there have been 136 vacancies in the House of Representatives.

Four of these occurred because the Court of Disputed Returns voided the outcome declared at the general election. In addition, the member for Kalgoorlie was expelled from the House in November 1920 for `seditious and disloyal utterances at a public meeting' where he criticised British policy on Ireland.

Nineteen vacancies, each of which occurred within three months of the dissolution of Parliament, were not filled. On two of these occasions, in 1931 and 1934, the Speaker withdraw a writ which had already been issued. On four other occasions, in Kalgoorlie in 1913, Dalley in 1915, Wide Bay in 1928, and Cunningham in 1956, only one candidate nominated and so the voters were not called back to the polling places.

Seventy-six members have died in office while 48 have resigned, some through ill-health or to go into retirement after many years of service, but the overwhelming proportion, about three-quarters of them, to take up government appointments either at home or abroad.
CHANGING PATTERNS IN THE CAUSES OF BY-ELECTIONS
Of the Parliaments, only three, the Ninth (1923-25), Eighteenth (1946-49) and the Nineteenth (1950-51), have passed without any vacancy arising.
On the other hand, there were 10 vacancies during the course of the Twentieth Parliament (1951-54), nine of them because of the death of the sitting member.

Three times, in 1952-3, 1960 and 1983-84, there have been 6 by-elections in well under a year. The death of the sitting member was the cause in all cases the first time. On the second occasion, four resignations were among the causes, while the third time, all the vacancies were created by resignations. This is a trend which is also borne out dramatically in overall figures.

In the period to the end of the Twenty-fifth Parliament in 1966, there were 64 deaths and 30 resignations which left vacancies in the House of Representatives. Since then, however, the vacancies have been caused by 12 deaths and 25 resignations. That is, the proportion of resignations has swung from one-third to two-thirds since the retirement of Sir Robert Menzies.

I believe that it is time to re-examine our understanding of the purpose of a general election before matters get as far out of hand as they have in the New South Wales Parliament. Since 1975, there have been 32 by-elections, 13 of these from February 1985 in the lifetime of the current Legislative Assembly. It is difficult to accept that by-elections can occur in such epidemic quantities when candidates ask the voters to endorse them for a full term of the Parliament at a general election.
DISRUPTION OF GOVERNMENT AND COST TO PUBLIC REVENUE

There is a major problem when the government and the media concentrate almost exclusively on the beaten-up significance of a particular by-election. We can well remember the media circuses which accompanied the Lowe and Flinders by-elections of 1982, and the Bankstown and Heathcote by-elections for the New South Wales Legislative Assembly earlier this year. The prospect of a possible Bowman by-election has also been concentrating the minds of a number of people in recent months.

We cannot afford to have governments diverted from the business of administration and policy oversight because they sense that a lot of face is at stake at a particular by-election. In fact, we should be encouraging governments to take longer term views of the nation's welfare than what extra promises might save them a seat.

More and more, we will object to the considerable expense involved in recalling the voters of any electorate to the polling places, and in reimbursing some of the various candidates' expenses under the public funding schemes which operate.
For instance, the Australian Electoral Commission has given the cost of staging last year's Scullin by-election as $129,283. A further $33,056 was spent under the public funding provisions.

The cost to the public purse of holding the 6 by-elections held in the course of the Thirty-third Parliament (1983-84) was over three-quarters of a million dollars, exclusive of the ordinary payments to Australian Electoral Commission staff whose efforts are called upon.
Figures provided to Senate Estimates Committee E in May 1986 illustrate how fast costs of by-elections rose over the period of the previous two parliaments:

The Australian Electoral Commission noted that advertising costs had risen from 5 per cent of total cost in 1981 to 10 per in 1984, and were expected to reach 12 per cent of total cost in 1986.

As the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Act 1983 only came into effect on 21 February 1984 by proclamation of the Governor-General, these figures for costs will be further increased by the public funding requirements of the future.

They are already massive when compared with what it costs to fill casual vacancies in Tasmania's House of Assembly. The Parliamentary Library was able to supply me with the Electoral Office's estimate that its re-examinations of ballot papers involve six staff for about a day and a half.
THE TASMANIAN EXPERIENCE

Once the Chief Electoral Officer has been notified of a vacancy, a notice about it is published in at least two newspapers, and unsuccessful candidates at the general election who have not since been elected have 10 days in which to notify their availability to serve if elected as the replacement.

When the period for notifying consents has expired, there is a re-examination of ballot papers. In the case where the vacating candidate was elected at the general election, all the ballot papers which contributed to that election are re-examined, and the candidate preferred by those who have lost their representative becomes the replacement. The same principle operates where the vacating candidate was elected to fill a casual vacancy, except that all the papers examined in that person's election are re-examined.

The driving force behind the idea that voters not be recalled to the polling places appears to have been Professor Giblin who in 1914 appeared before a commission of inquiry into the electoral system. The original provisions were enacted in 1917 and have since been altered to avoid further polling if a vacancy arises from a member who filled an earlier vacancy.

In 1979, in the midst of the campaign overspending controversy, special provision was made for circumstances in which more than one vacancy was created simultaneously. When the election of three Labor members was voided on these grounds, a by-election for all seven seats in Denison was held the following year. The sunset clause on this legislation has since expired, and Tasmanians can continue to expect that vacancies in the House of Assembly will be filled expeditiously without disrupting the operations of government or requiring voters to return to the polling places.

Since 1946, every vacating Liberal or Labor member has been replaced by a colleague from the same party. The two vacating Independents, Wedd and Turnbull, have been replaced respectively by the Independent McPartlan and the Australian Labor Party member Fraser. The Independent Dr Bob Brown replaced the Australian Democrat Dr Norm Sanders in January 1983 because Denison environmentalists' support was common to both.

One of the major benefits to Tasmanian voters of these rescrutiny arrangements is the extra choice they have among those candidates whom various groups have endorsed. Although no party has ever won more than five seats in any electorate, and three or four seats have usually been taken by Labor and the Liberals, voters have usually been able to choose among seven to nine candidates endorsed by both the Labor and Liberal parties. This has saved them from voting against their preferred party because none of its endorsed candidates was acceptable.
OTHER VACANCIES FILLED WITHOUT POLLING

In the same legislation which introduced the re-examination of ballot papers, the Electoral Amendment Act 1917, was another section which allowed Legislative Council and House of Assembly members unsuccessful at a Federal election to be reinstated to their former place if they so chose, without any further polling whatsoever. When these circumstances arose, the returning officer to whom the writ for a by-election was directed was to `forthwith, without holding a poll, publicly declare him to be duly elected to fill the said vacancy' and to return the writ.

At the Premiers Conference in 1920, it was resolved to try to induce the Commonwealth Government to remove the disability upon members of State parliaments who wanted to contest a Federal election. Once it became clear that nothing would be done by the Commonwealth, all the States except New South Wales brought in legislation based on Tasmania's, and sometimes worded almost exactly the same. The common thread was that a writ for a by-election could be returned without the holding of a poll.

On 8 December 1921, the Hughes Government effectively over-rode these State enactments by inserting a tougher disability on State members, one which precluded nomination as a senator or as a member of the House of Representatives of anyone who had the right `to be re-elected to the Parliament of the State without the holding of a poll'. This disability remained on the statute books until the proclamation of the day from which the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Act 1983 came into effect.
THOSE WHO ARE STILL WITHOUT REPRESENTATION SHOULD DETERMINE THE REPLACEMENT

While I have followed the practical outline of the way in which arrangements are made to determine the consenting candidates, I have made one important change in relation to the papers which are examined in order to fill a casual vacancy.

I believe that as many people as possible should have direct input into the processes of democracy. Consequently, when a casual vacancy occurs, those who are without representation should determine the replacement. In the case of single-member districts with which this Bill deals, all the ballot papers cast at the general election would be re-examined.

This Bill is timely in that its principles can be extended to multi-member electorates, where the papers to be examined would be those for the vacating candidate and those not in the quota of any elected candidate.

This would have resolved the current impasse over the replacement of former Senator Grimes. Such problems will continue to surface, as will the other major deficiencies in the 1977 constitutional amendment. Unless we act now, they will continue to give rise to political mischief and chicanery. We must resolve the basic principles at stake. This Bill is a step in the right direction.
If we restore the power of appointing any replacement to those voters not represented, we will cut off further avenues of political manipulation in the composition of the Senate.
By strengthening the role that voters play when they go to the polls at a general election, we will be making a very strong statement about what is expected of governments.

Apart from giving voters more choice among the available candidates and eliminating unnecessary expenditure, we will be demanding that governments not be sidetracked by sideshows but that they get on with the job with which they are entrusted.
Conclusion
The two measures in this Bill:
(1) rotation of the names of candidates on House of Representatives ballot papers,
(2) filling of casual vacancies in the House of Representatives by a recount of the original votes cast at the previous general election,
will both improve the fairness and effectiveness of the electoral process for the voters, and decrease the cost to the people of Australia.
I commend these measures, and the Bill, to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill contains amendments to the Social Security Act 1947, the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, and the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940 to implement decisions which are to come into effect before or shortly after October 1987. Other measures which were announced by the Treasurer in the May economic statement will be implemented in Budget legislation or, where legislation is not required, administratively.

Amendments in this Bill will lead to some new directions for social security while producing considerable savings. There will be changes building on administrative measures aimed at reducing the risk of wrong payments and welfare fraud. Other changes will encourage people to obtain employment and thereby combat long term dependence on Social Security.

The Government retains its deeply-held commitment to disadvantaged people and children in poverty. In order to protect and improve their living standards we must ensure that social security payments are well targeted.

In line with this objective, the Government has decided to income test family allowances for families where the parental taxable income exceeds $50,000 a year. This threshold will be indexed. To protect large families the threshold before the income test applies will be increased by $2,500 for each dependent child after the first child. Where the income test applies the family allowance payable will be reduced by 25 per cent of the income in excess of the threshold.
In the area of unemployment benefit, amendments in this Bill will give effect to the following measures:
The waiting period before benefit is payable will begin after registration with the Commonwealth Employment Service;
an `education leaver' waiting period of 13 weeks will be introduced for most claimants under 21 years of age without work experience; and

an increased postponement period will apply for successive occasions on which claimants leave their employment voluntarily, are dismissed for misconduct or fail the work test for unemployment benefit.
New measures will facilitate obtaining written confirmation of the circumstances of termination of employment from previous employers of claimants for benefit.
There will be some changes to eligibility for pension and benefit for sole parents and widows.
Eligibility for a supporting parent's benefit and a class A widow's pension will be restricted to those with children aged under 16.

The class B widow's pension will be phased out. This will be done gradually and will generally not affect the future eligibility of women currently aged 45 or over with dependants or of other women currently aged 50 or over.
Amendments to rationalise the social security system and produce considerable savings include:
Measures by which sickness benefits will become more closely aligned to unemployment benefit rates for unmarried people without dependants;
the strengthening of residence requirements;
changes to eligibility for invalid pension-medical impairment will have to constitute the major part of the incapacity for work; and
the removal of the savings provision which currently enables those in government housing to receive rent assistance.
Other amendments in this Bill enhance actions against welfare fraud and extend the powers of the Departments of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs to recover overpayments:
The information gathering powers in the legislation will be extended to allow for greater access to external records;

amendments will enable the passing on of relevant information, subject to secrecy provisions, to other Commonwealth Departments and authorities. Administrative arrangements between the Department of Social Security, the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Education will produce immediate savings by facilitating the earlier detection of incorrect payments and fraud;
the powers in the legislation to acquire information from ex-clients will be extended;
there will be power to recover debts from a wider variety of sources; and
a penalty will be levied on persons who do not repay an overpayment within 3 months.
Provisions relating to arrears of pension, benefit and allowances will be standardised and there will be limits on arrears payable following appeals.

Amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940 made by this Bill will mirror amendments made to the Social Security Act 1947 in relation to debt recovery and information gathering powers, disclosure powers, and residence requirements.
This Bill will result in estimated net savings of $236m in 1987-1988 and further net savings of $342m in 1988-1989.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-We have now had presented the first of what I understand will be a series of guillotine motions that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) proposes to move during the next few days. I want to make it quite clear that he does this without the consent of the Opposition. Indeed, we have a general opposition to the imposition of the guillotine. I make that statement knowing that the Government has called an election-an unnecessary early election, in our view-and has said that the Parliament will rise next Friday. It is likely that the Senate will deal with the Government's program within that time. But we face a situation in which without warning the Government has called an election, having said specifically within the last two weeks that it would not and we have a legislative program of very considerable substance.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate which we are about to have on the Appropriations and Supply package for which 10 hours has been allowed is a debate which enables the Senate to direct its attention to the economic situation, as does the debate on the May package which is not dealt with in this motion. Since the Government has seen fit to behave in an extraordinary way and the Government's economic management has been brought into question by the need for it to bring down a mini-Budget, we would have thought that putting limitations on debate in this area would be quite inappropriate. A very substantial number of senators have indicated that they wish to speak on the appropriation Bills. There is a speakers' list of close to 20 senators. Quite clearly, the time will be insufficient to deal with the Committee stage matters which honourable senators may wish to raise on this legislation. The ludicrous situation that the Government has put us in is best examined by looking at the grouping of Bills under the heading `July 1 Commencement Bills'. The time permitted for debate here is three hours. There is an extraordinary collection of legislation. There is nursing homes and hostels legislation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Two hours.
—It is now three hours. The Minister amended it to three hours.
—Not at the moment. There will be a subsequent amendment.

—I am sorry. It is two hours at the moment, which makes the point even more forcefully. There is nursing homes and hostels legislation which is of very considerable significance to a large number of Australians, not least elderly Australians. We have veterans' affairs legislation, two egg industry Bills-which are not particularly contentious because they relate merely to a levy-and wool marketing Bills and wool tax Bills. The time presently allowed for discussion of those six Bills is two hours. The Minister has indicated that he may amend the motion to three hours. But if we stop to think about it, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) pointed out, we have a very large number of parties represented in this Senate. We have the Government, the Liberal Party of Australia, as the official Opposition, the National Party of Australia, the Australian Democrats and several Independents. With debate of three hours allowed on six Bills it is quite clear that for even a single spokesman from each of the parties represented in this place to speak and for all to have equal time is scarcely fair to the official Opposition which has the bulk of the numbers on the non-government side. It would be a matter of each party having a few minutes to put its views on a significant range of Bills. We object to that in principle. We think it is quite improper.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make my central point about the final list of Bills. Under the innocuous heading `Miscellaneous Urgent Bills' we find that the Government includes the Social Security Amendment Bill along with the Ships (Capital Grants) Bill 1987 and the Ministers of State Amendment Bill 1987. Two hours are allowed for us to debate three lots of legislation. I want to draw the Senate's attention to the social security legislation because it undertakes some major changes to social security policy. In the past it has been made plain by the Government that these major areas of policy are of very great importance.

I want to select two things from the social security legislation which the Government expects us to deal with, along with two other Bills, in the space of two hours. The social security legislation effects changes to the invalid pension rules and it effects changes to the class B widow's pension rules. Mr President, can you imagine what Labor Party senators would say if the Liberal Party had introduced legislation to abolish the class B widow's pension and allowed perhaps 20 minutes for the Labor Party to put its case. The class B widow's pension provides a pension for women who have been widowed before they reach pensionable age. If they do not have dependent children but are in their fifties they have traditionally been given a pension called the class B widow's pension. I will not go into detail as to the qualifications, but essentially it provides a pension for women of mature age on the assumption that, where a woman has been a homemaker, a mother, for the whole of her working life and she then becomes a widow in her fifties, it is really rather unreasonable to expect her to go into the labour market. That is a quite significant sort of social policy question. We find slipped into this mini-Budget statement this view from the Government-I speak for the Government because this is what its mini-Budget statement says-`These women should not get a pension, they should be on the unemployment benefit'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in their fifties. They will still get the pension.
—What age group?
—It is under 45.
—These are women who were previously qualified for a pension, who have had children and who have ceased to have young children?
—If the children are over 16 they will lose their eligibility.

—But the important thing is that women who might have been out of the work force bringing up children and who are widowed will be disqualified from that pension and put on the unemployment benefit. I am not prepared to debate that provision in detail here. I simply say that it is an important social measure and it is significant that there is very high and continuing unemployment. On the statistics, mature age workers are shown to have very long periods of unemployment. It means that these widows will have to be subjected to the work test. They will have to deal with the Department of Social Security as unemployed people, not as widowed pensioners. I think that is a matter on which some debate would have been expected. As I have said, if a Liberal government had brought forward this proposal I am sure that Labor senators would have expected an opportunity to probe and to question the Government both on the policy that is being implemented and on the practical implications of it for the individuals concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I am even more surprised to find that the Government expects us to debate in a few minutes provisions which go to the invalid pension. It may be that the Government expects this because Senator Grimes is no longer here. Labor senators will remember that Senator Grimes, in opposition, was very active as shadow Minister for Social Security in expressing concern on behalf of the Labor Party for the tests which were imposed on invalid Australians before they could get an invalid pension. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle who was Minister for Social Security until 1980, and I, after the portfolio was given to me in December of that year, had extensive debate with the Labor Party on the application of the invalid pension rules. That was a matter which was regarded as being of major significance. In the explanatory material that was put forward with respect to the social security changes-which we have a third of two hours for all of the parties to debate-we find this very simple statement:

There is a redefinition of invalid pension medical eligibility. While current eligibility provisions require no minimum medical incapacity for invalid pensioners, this will be changed from July 1987 to require that the major part of an invalid pensioner's incapacity for work must be medical incapacity.

Mr President, I remind you of the debates of the 1979, 1980 and 1981 period when the Australian Labor Party, of which you, of course, were part, asserted very strongly that it was quite unjust for the then Liberal Government to be ignoring the state of the labour market in assessing eligibility for the invalid pension. The view put was that to make an assessment of disability on medical grounds only was grossly unjust. We were told that if the labour market proved to be very difficult it was unfair and unjust to suggest that 85 per cent medical incapacity was the only way one could establish one's incapacity to work. We were attacked continuously by the Labor Party on that subject. It was a matter of bitter recrimination in the Senate and elsewhere. The point that I want to make is that, with this mini-Budget, this Government is, as far as we know, not only going back to an even stricter medical test than that which applied in 1979, 1980 or 1981, but also doing so on the basis that we should have 20 minutes to debate it. Nothing could better illustrate the extraordinary lack of concern on the part of this Government in making these decisions than this particular decision, because the oft stated view of the Labor Party was, to quote from a Press release put out by Senator Grimes:
To ignore the availability and likelihood of employment in an application for invalid pension was unfair and the cause of great hardship.

That is a mild form of the words used by members of the Labor Party at that time. I draw this matter to the attention of the Senate as one tiny part of the legislation that we have been given 20 minutes to debate.

I would say to the Australian Democrats that their desire to have an early election and a double dissolution is understandable. Clearly it represented the only option that they had to survive politically. But I also would like to remind the Australian Democrats that they took the view that they would not prevent debate in this place and would not support the gag or the guillotine. They have, of course, broken that undertaking on many occasions and it may be that it is no longer part of Democrat policy to follow that rule. But it appears to me that, if the Democrats are prepared to support this form of guillotine when we are dealing with legislation which touches on issues of the sort that I have mentioned in my comments, the Democrats have shown that they are prepared to sell out their undertaking to see these matters fairly and fully examined in favour of their own short term political advantage.

The Government and the Australian Democrats have put us in a position where it is difficult, if not impossible, for us to do our duty by the people that we represent. That is the simple fact of the matter. We will later be dealing with other guillotines in respect of such things as the health amendments, which will affect 100,000 Australians who are waiting in hospital queues for operations, which queues will lengthen because of the legislation that the Senate is being asked to deal with in this next week. There is a series of major policy proposals which would have a significant impact on our constituents, and to suggest that they can be ordered in this way is, I think, to show a contempt for the Senate and for those constituents whose interests are being affected.

I make all those comments openly saying that we, as an opposition, would not deny the Government its legislation with respect to the mini-Budget, because we have taken the view that a mini-Budget was essential and that reductions in government expenditure are essential, and we do not see it as being consistent with our stance on that to pick and choose with respect to the Government's changes. I want to make that clear. But that does not remove the obligation of this Senate fully to examine and expose the reality of what the Government is doing. It is extraordinary that in the social security field alone there are such major changes of social policy being implemented, absolutely enormous changes affecting young Australians, which were condemned, let me say, by the Government as recently as a couple of months ago as being the sort of things that a conservative or Liberal administration would put forward but the sort of things that the Labor Party would deny.

That fact that we are being asked to accept a compressed debate of this sort is a condemnation of the Government. It is a condemnation of the Australian Democrats if they join with the Government in that. Mr President, I indicate that we will oppose this guillotine as we will oppose the other guillotines that will be brought forward later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I think it is fairly normal practice at the end of any session for a government, of whatever political persuasion, to seek the expeditious passage of necessary legislation. That has been fairly normal, even in the time of the Fraser Government. However, I certainly share with Senator Chaney some concern about the time that has been allocated for some of these elements. Of course, what Senator Chaney also needs to realise is that if this Government does want all of this legislation before the end of next week-that is, within the next seven debating days-its alternative would be to leave the Supply package until everything else has been dealt with; it would then find that it had to push that through with perhaps an hour of debate. That would give people in this chamber very little time in which to look at some of the serious matters in the Supply Bills, which are, after all, guaranteed passage by all the Opposition parties. So, it is a little precious for Senator Chaney to be complaining about the fact that the Government is attempting to lay down some order for the passage of the Bills that it wants through prior to the election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I ought to point out that, while Senator Chaney has mentioned that there are problems for the Opposition in the debating times in some of these areas, there are problems for the Australian Democrats with the debating times in some other areas and some problems within some of the legislation. Certainly, we are concerned about the Social Security Amendment Bill for the same reason that Senator Chaney mentioned-that is that widows over the age of 45 with children over the age of 16 will suddenly be forced on to unemployment benefit queues, when, as everybody knows, employers in this country are loth to take on married women who have been out of the work force for any length of time, so there are some very real concerns that these women will be facing an embarrassing and frustrating time if this legislation is passed. In addition, like Senator Chaney, we have concerns about the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill-not that I imagine there is any doubt that it will pass, but there are problems with regard, in particular, to the situation facing private nursing homes in both South Australia and Victoria and those problems need, at least, to be debated out in this place, even if nothing else can be done about them.

I might point out that, so far as the education package is concerned, if Senator Chaney or anybody else would like to run a few statistical analyses on how long it has taken each year to deal with the States grants education package, they would find that two hours is about the norm. There are usually only two or three speakers from the Opposition benches and then the Minister's summing up. That means that two hours is not an unreasonable time to offer for a package that is never defeated and is not debated at any greater length than this under normal circumstances. Nonetheless, I have to point out that five hours for the tax package, which contains some fairly contentious legislation and some legislation with problems in it, particularly that Bill relating to the imputation, is perhaps a trifle under what is required. There is, for example, what may well be an unintended consequence of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill 1987 relating to the sale of company assets where only a nominal capital gain is accrued. Under the capital gains tax legislation, that nominal gain would not be taxed. Once a company chooses to distribute that to its shareholders, because no tax has been paid on it, it is immediately subject to the full marginal tax rate. I am sure that it is an unintended consequence and perhaps one that could be dealt with by amendment. Nevertheless, it is there and it needs to be discussed at some length.

The Australian Democrats also have some problems with the Commissioner of Taxation's powers in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. Again, that could require some considerable debate and possibly amendment during the Committee stage. That leaves us with real problems with regard to provisional tax and short term redeemable preference shares, which are covered in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987. It may well be that simply removing the retrospective element, that is, the rather appalling tendency that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has to legislate by Press release, can sort out the problems but, in any event, problems regarding debate time exist. There may well have to be some additional discussion on this matter. It cannot be simply assumed that any guillotine motion that is introduced into this place during the next seven days will get through without argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Shortly, I shall move a further motion that will allocate specific time periods for the particular packages that this motion simply declares as urgent Bills. They are as follows: Ten hours for the Appropriation and Supply Bills, five hours for the tax package; two hours for education; three hours for the July 1 commencement Bills, as Senator Chaney said; and two hours for the miscellaneous urgent Bills. In addition, tomorrow I will seek to move, and possibly on Monday as well, some further guillotine motions. It is not, as Senator Chaney implied, an open ended series. It is proposed to put before the Senate only four additional packages, and they are: A customs and excise package, which it is presently proposed should be debated for two hours; a crime package, four hours; the May economic statement package, five hours; and the media package, six hours.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicate for the benefit of honourable senators that those time periods have been identified on the basis of worst case assumptions for procedural difficulties and so on, and on the basis of the need to finish deliberations by Friday of next week at the latest. They have also been identified to allow time for the quite extended series of valedictories which I know honourable senators will find it appropriate to make, and also some cleaning up of other business in the form of tabling of committee reports and things of that kind. Bearing those considerations in mind, it may be possible, as the days proceed, to find some additional time for debating some of the matters about which honourable senators have expressed concern. It may be that we will have a little more flexibility in respect of some of these matters which honourable senators will obviously want more time to debate than is provided for in the terms of this motion.

It is not the Government's intention to be in any way dog in the manger about this. If the legislation is flowing in such a way that there can be a reasonable expectation of cleaning up these matters within the time periods I have indicated, it may well be possible by agreement, as the week proceeds, to find additional room for some debate on matters on which honourable senators are anxious to spend time. I cannot give any promises about that at this stage because obviously the overwhelming time constraint is the need to clean up matters by Friday week and still allow ourselves a reasonable time for some of the decencies which I hope are still current in this place at the end of long honourable terms of service by a number of honourable senators. Against that background, I commend the declaration of urgency to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Yesterday I had a disagreement with the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), who suggested to me that I should be allowed to speak on the declaration of an election statement provided that I supported a gag on further discussion. I do not know that I would acknowledge complete agreement with what was put to me in relation to this matter, as it seems unfair that some senators should speak to the motion while others should be denied that opportunity. However, to come to the matter before the Senate at the moment: I think that debate on the fact that the Government intended to complete its business by Friday of next week and that at some stage it would move an urgency motion to deal with certain matters-if they remain urgent-should have been foreshadowed for debate next week.

SPEECH.PARA: We all have in mind now that an election is on. In fact, a gag has already been applied to this House by the double dissolution action of the Government-we have been virtually gagged by the action of the Government in calling a double dissolution. We know that next Friday we will face that situation, and we will have in mind that various other matters are to a certain extent not relevant. However, if various matters still remain urgent we would accept, possibly on Wednesday of next week, a guillotine action by the Government, but not at this stage, not today. Why should this occur today? The explanation for that has not really been provided. So, my view of this matter is that we should not accept lightly at this stage what is virtually a guillotine action and that we should reconsider the matter next week. I will vote against the proposition today, although I will not vote against it next Wednesday.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Gareth Evans's) be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe it would suit the convenience and expectation of the Senate if the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1986-87, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1986-87, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1986-87, Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88, Supply Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 were debated cognately, and I so request.

—Perhaps I should indicate that Senator Short will be leading the debate for the Opposition on these Bills. We regard it as an unusual procedure to debate the Supply and Appropriation Bills together. In the present circumstances, since a limited time for debate is imposed by the guillotine, I do not propose to take the matter further. However, I place on record that we would not regard this as the usual way of dealing with these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, has said, the Opposition has agreed, with the very greatest reluctance, to the cognate debate of the three Appropriation Bills-the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1986-87, the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1986-87 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1986-87-and the three Supply Bills-the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88, the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1897-88 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1987-88. It is indeed a very unusual procedure because the Appropriation Bills and the Supply Bills have nothing to do with each other. One group of Bills relates to one financial year and the other group-the Supply Bills-relates to the next financial year. These Bills have been declared urgent, along with many other Bills of vital interest to every Australian. That is what we have been discussing for the last hour or so.

SPEECH.PARA: It was very interesting to see which way honourable senators voted in the division on the time allotment for the Bills. The Government got its way with the acquiescence and support of the Australian Democrats. Australians will need no reminding, but they will be constantly reminded of it between now and 11 July-that the actions of the Democrats in this chamber, as displayed this morning, makes them no more than an appendage of the Australian Labor Party. The deals that the Democrats have done with the Labor Party are legion and are obviously one reason why we are having a double dissolution.
