That is the only way the Democrats can hope to survive; I do not think they will survive even on that basis.
At the outset of my remarks I foreshadow that Senator Messner will move an amendment to that Bill on behalf of the Opposition to the following effect:
At the end of motion, add `, but the Senate condemns the Government for-
(1) its decision to call an early election without informing the Australian people as to the content of the August 1987 Budget;
(2) its continued mismanagement of the economy which has caused:
(a) widespread and growing concern among Australians about their future;
(b) a sustained reduction in the living standards of all Australians, and in particular Australian families with young children, and
(c) fundamental weaknesses in the nation's economy as indicated by-
(i) declining economic growth rates,
(ii) inflation at four times the average of our major trading partners,
(iii) record relative interest rates,
(iv) an overseas debt burden of $105 billion, and
(v) the value of the Australian dollar being cut by one-third; and
(3) its failure to implement the genuine expenditure cuts in its May economic statement necessary to restore balance to its policies and reduce interest rates'.

Many questions will be asked by the people of Australia about the reasons for the 11 July election date announced yesterday. Australians will be asking why this election is coming on so early. Why are we having such an unprecedented election, an election which is being held right at the time when the government of the day ought to be devoting all its energies and attention to preparing a critically important August Budget? Why are we having a double dissolution election rather than the normal half-Senate plus House of Representatives election? Overriding all those questions will be one question and that question is: What is the Government hiding by going to an election at this unprecedented and early time? What will the Government do in the August Budget-if there is an August Budget? What will the Government do with its infamous industrial relations legislation which it has now withdrawn for consultation with employer groups which have expressed rage, great concern and anger about this legislation? That consultation will not take place before the July election.

What will the Government do when it gets its Australia Card legislation through following the double dissolution, as it says it will do if it is re-elected? It will pass that ID card legislation and the Australian people will not be told what will then develop. The ID card legislation in its present form obviously will be only the thin end of a very large wedge that will be driven into the privacy and rights of all Australians over the years ahead, if it comes to pass that the legislation gets through and heaven forbid that it does. The early election is yet another broken promise. On 1 April the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), after having stirred up early election fever, said that the next election would be held in late 1987 or March 1988. `There will be no early election,' he said. Perhaps he thought he could get away with this as an April Fools Day joke. What a way to treat the Australian public. But not once did the Prime Minister give that promise; he gave it again less than two weeks ago. On 15 May-a very significant date because it was two days after the mini-Budget-the Prime Minister said that he could not envisage any circumstances which would make a July election likely. But yesterday, in announcing the election, the Prime Minister said that the mini-Budget was one of the two developments that had led him to change his mind about an early election. What absolute cynicism. Never in our history have we had a Prime Minister or a government so cynically opportunistic, so disdainful of the public and so prone to lying to the people and to breaking promises. Let us look at what the Press today is saying about this early election decision. The Press is unanimously opposed to this decision. It has treated the decision in the way it should. Views have come from newspapers around Australia that have not been noticeably anti the Government in recent times. Indeed, they have been bending over backwards to portray this Government in a favourable light. The Melbourne Age today said:

Mr Hawke has gone back on his word for reasons linked more to opportunism than calling the double dissolution-the Australia Card legislation rejected by the Senate-is as cynical as the timing of the election. . . Mr Hawke said 7 weeks ago that he had some concern that he might appear hypocritical in calling an early election after disavowing the possibility so many times. He now appears hypocritical.
The Canberra Times says:
By calling an early election, and breaking his word to the people, Mr Hawke could be seen by many as putting political advantage before the welfare of the nation.
The editorial in today's Australian states:
The government will have to work very hard to persuade the electorate that it does not have ulterior motives in calling an early poll.
The editorial in today's Daily Telegraph states:
But even as he was calling the election events were taking place which should make sure he's not too cocky.

Other articles in newspapers indicated that yesterday the Commonwealth Bank of Australia raised housing interest rates for new borrowers by one per cent-up to 16 1/2 per cent-and, in Wollongong, 20,000 workers brought the vital steel industry to a halt in protesting against the Macquarie Street workers compensation changes. So it goes on. Editorial comments around the nation are universally condemning this cynical, opportunistic early election. How right they are! But we should not be too surprised at this latest broken promise by the Prime Minister. His four years in office are strewn with a litany of broken promises. Every one of these broken promises has resulted from the Prime Minister's deliberate attempts to mislead the Australian people and to try to buy votes. It is a record without comparison in our history.

Let us look at some of the broken promises that have occurred over the last four years. All of them have greatly disadvantaged the Australian public. The last election policy speech of the Prime Minister on 13 November 1984 stated:
We pledge ourselves to bring home ownership once again within the reach of ordinary Australian families.

At that time home loan interest rates were 11 1/2 per cent. Today they are 15 1/2 per cent and, as I have said, yesterday the Commonwealth Bank announced that it will raise interest rates to 16 1/2 per cent. Monthly repayments on a typical $50,000, 25-year home loan, have risen by $172 a month since November 1984-since the Prime Minister gave his promise to bring interest rates and, therefore, housing costs down. Since the Government came to office in 1983 housing interest repayments have risen in the last few years by $281 per month. Average loan repayments, as a percentage of median family income, have increased from 19 per cent to 27 per cent in the four years of this Government. That is one broken promise that did untold harm to, and caused hardship for, many Australians. At the same time, prior to the 1984 election, the Prime Minister also said:
At present the outlook for interest rates is as bright as it has been for more than a decade.

He said that the Government would expect to see interest rates fall in the near future. What happened? No sooner was the 1984 election out of the way than the entire interest rate structure rose to record levels in Australia's history, on a real basis, after taking account of inflation and at a time when the interest rates of every other Western nation fell. The Prime Minister also said at the time, again just prior to the 1984 election, that inflation was going to fall. He said:
We expect inflation will be less than 5 per cent in the year ahead and we are determined to keep it below 5 per cent.

What has happened since then? Annual rates of inflation, as measured by the consumer price index, have risen considerably. Indeed, the inflation rate in Australia has risen consistently while it has fallen in every other Western country. We now have an inflation rate, relative to our major trading partners, higher than we have had in our history. The Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, said, prior to the 1983 election, that falls in Saudi oil prices must be passed on to Australian motorists in lower petrol prices. What did the Australian Labor Party do when it came into office? It introduced a new excise of 10c a litre so that consumers and business received less than half the real fall that occurred in overseas oil prices.

The Prime Minister, in his election policy speech of February 1983-before this Government first came to office-promised that there would be increases in the spouse rebate and the sole parent rebate resulting in additional tax cuts of $2 a week to families. What has happened to that promise? The dependent spouse rebate has not changed in nominal terms in four years and, adjusting for inflation, the spouse rebate and, indeed, family allowances-about which similar types of promises were made-have declined in real terms by 25 per cent. Coming back to the 1984 election campaign, the Prime Minister said in his election speech:
And I now give this undertaking-
this was in relation to the Medicare levy-
that for the term of our next government, the Medicare levy will not be increased.

Last year-not much more than a year after that promise was given-the Medicare levy was increased by no less than 25 per cent. In a full year the Government will collect more than an additional $300m as a result of that broken promise. But the daddy of them all perhaps was when, immediately prior to the 1983 election, the Prime Minister said in his policy speech:
And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentations and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.

The Prime Minister gave that total and unequivocal commitment prior to being elected to office. On 19 September 1985 the Government announced that it would introduce a capital gains tax. That capital gains tax is now in operation and, far from raising the $5m to $25m this year that the Government forecast and told the Australian public that it would raise, it will raise between $125m and $150m, according to the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. This amount will skyrocket still further in the years ahead.

On television this morning the Prime Minister promised that there would be no new taxes and no tax increases in this coming August Budget. I have two comments on that matter. The first is that this rotten Government, thankfully, will not be in government to introduce the August Budget. But in any case, what reliance could the Australian people place on this latest promise by this record promise-breaking Prime Minister? The one certainty in this promise is that it will be broken too. On television this morning Mr Hawke also said:
We have brought down our Budget. We brought it down on 13 May in the mini-Budget.

What a plain stupid, nonsensical, incorrect statement. That mini-Budget had no revenue decisions in it. It was not expected to, but it did not deal at all with a key element-perhaps the key element-of the whole Budget. There were no firm decisions even on spending in the May mini-Budget. All that the mini-Budget was concerned with was a reduction in Forward Estimates that had been planned for expenditure over the year ahead. To that extent it is a mirrors and pea and thimble trick to talk about cuts off Forward Estimates. No firm decisions were made on the level of spending for 1987-88 in the mini-Budget. No idea of the borrowing requirement-and therefore the Budget deficit that will occur next year-can be gleaned from the mini-Budget. So, if that is the best that this Prime Minister and this Government can do, thank heaven the Australian people have only another six weeks to put up with them.

Let us look at just a couple of comments that were made a little after the mini-Budget was released. I stress that the mini-Budget is what the Prime Minister is now fundamentally hanging this election on. One of Australia's leading businessmen, John Spalvins, once he had had a bit of a chance to reflect on the mini-Budget, said:
I for one am concerned that perhaps the cuts have been superficial.

The President of the Sydney Chamber of Commerce, David Abba, said that Labor had performed only `cosmetic surgery where a heart transplant was required'. Allan Wood of the very respected economic forecasting group Syntec International saw the mini-Budget as containing very ominous warnings for the Australian economy. He said:
It has passed virtually without notice, but in fact the government has revised inflation forecast up by a full percentage point for the next 12 months in the space of just a few weeks.
I might add to that that at the same time the Government had revised its economic growth forecast down by one full percentage point in just a few weeks. Alan Wood also went on to say:

Also when you look at the wage assumptions that are implied in that statement, I think they are optimistic, they seem to assume that everyone is going to abide by the Arbitration Commission's new wage system and I think the evidence is fairly clear that they won't . . .
So underlying the statement is a worse inflationary picture than the Government would like us to think. He went on to say:
These problems won't really become apparent (until) a few months down the track and people suddenly find that things aren't coming good quite as fast as they thought they ought to be.

That, of course, is one of the precise reasons for the Government going to this early election. This Government is going early because it knows that the economy and the political climate will deteriorate rapidly in the months ahead. The Premiers told Mr Hawke that. His own Labor Premier from Western Australia, Brian Burke, told him that on Monday. So did the Tasmanian Premier, Robin Gray. They made it crystal clear that the effects of this Government's policies so far as the States were concerned would be to force them to put up, to extremely high rates, taxes and charges that will flow through, have a major inflationary impact and force more and more burdens on to the Australian public.

As I said, the Prime Minister's own forecasters tell him that things will deteriorate. They have forecast downwards the economic growth rate for the year ahead. They have forecast upwards the inflation rate, an inflation rate that I might point out to the Senate is the highest inflation rate relative to those of the rest of our major trading partners that we have ever had in our history. The forecasters are predicting no improvement in the level of unemployment in the year ahead and, indeed, most economic commentators now would say that there will be a considerable increase in unemployment in the year ahead because the economic growth being forecast is simply insufficient to maintain employment and, more particularly, unemployment at their present levels. There is no doubt at all that unemployment will rise significantly in the year ahead under the continuing policies of this Government.

Business investment is falling. The national accounts figures that came out yesterday showed another major fall in business investment in the March quarter and for the year to March. It followed a major fall in business investment of about 10 per cent in real terms in 1985-86, and all the surveys that have been done up to date for the year ahead show an expectation of a further fall in business investment in real terms by 10 per cent or more in 1987-88. Yet it is business investment that Australia has to rely on to be the engine of growth in our economy.

Other major indicators are pointing to an increasingly gloomy situation. New car sales, the figures for which came out yesterday, showed a fall of one-third in car sales last month to the lowest April figure for 20 years. That follows a year, 1986, in which we have already seen the biggest single proportional drop in new car sales in our post-war history. Our foreign debt situation is not improving; it is continuing to deteriorate. Our foreign debt is now $105 billion, which is equivalent to $26,000 for every family in Australia. With foreign debt growing at that level-and it is continuing to grow by at least $1 billion a month-there is no way at all that interest rates in this country can fall and, if the United States dollar continues on a downward path, forcing up interest rates in the United States of America and other countries in the world, it is obvious and necessary, particularly taken in conjunction with the policies of this Government, that interest rates in Australia will go still higher.

So, what the Government is doing with this election is running for cover. The Prime Minister is also hiding from the public further harsh decisions that he will be taking. How much more can average Australian families stand? Very little. The Hawke Labor Government has given Australians the biggest fall in living standards for more than 30 years. Yet this Prime Minister said yesterday, when announcing the election, that he was seeking a mandate from the Australian people to finish the job. What job is he talking about finishing? If the Government stands on its record, it will be massacred at the forthcoming election. I have talked about inflation, and that is worse than at any time in Australia's history when compared with the rest of the world. At a time when the rest of the world's inflation is falling, Australia's is rising. The same applies with interest rates and Australia has the highest taxation it has ever faced in its history. The four Budgets of the Keating-Hawke regime have been the four biggest spending Budgets in Australia's history, and the Government is the biggest taxing government in our history. The Government now takes in tax 25 per cent of every dollar of Australia's total gross domestic product. Australia's debt has blown out abysmally, appallingly, in a way that causes great concern to every observer of the Australian scene. So it goes on.

The Government, in its first four years in office, but more particularly in the last four weeks, has given to trade unions a power unsurpassed in Australia's history. Not only has it given them a power unsurpassed in Australia's history but also it has put the trade union movement above the law that should apply to every Australian. Now, because of the concern and the massive co-ordination of that concern expressed by employers-and I must say by many employees as well-throughout Australia, the Prime Minister, in the interests of an early election, has pulled out the industrial relations legislation to enable further consultation. But there is no way in the world that the Government will back off removing trade unions from the normal processes of the law. There is no way in the world that the Government will back off its decimation in effective terms of sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act, which have done so much in recent years to restore some degree of sanity to industrial relations. Those sections were put into the Act in 1976-77 by the present Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. That decision probably stands in the annals of Australia's industrial relations history above all else in terms of the value it has provided to every Australian. If that is the record on which the Government will stand and the mandate it wants renewed, I am happy to go to an election on that basis.

The group in our society that has suffered more than any other under this Government is the family, particularly single income families with young children. Let us look at some of the facts. A one income family with two young children is now at least $31 a week worse off than it was when the Hawke Government was first elected. Even after the Hawke Government's so-called tax cuts on 1 July next, all single income families with a dependent spouse will be paying a higher proportion of their income in income tax than they were in March 1983. The average tax rate for a single income family on average weekly earnings will have increased from 17 1/2 per cent in March 1983 to 20 1/2 per cent in July 1987, while the marginal tax rate for those families will have increased from 30 per cent to 40 per cent.

After July this year, such a family will still require an additional income tax cut of $15 a week simply to restore it to the same average tax rate position it held when the Hawke Government came to office. In other words, the Hawke Government's December 1986 and July 1987 tax cuts merely give back to taxpayers some but by no means all of the additional tax that four years of fiscal drag has taken away from them. So much for the Government's taxation policies. They have simply bled Australian families dry, particularly single income families with young children. I refer to a few other areas where this miserable, incompetent government has savaged Australians. Almost three-quarters of a million more people are now below the poverty line than when the Hawke Government came to office. There are now 2.6 million Australians below the poverty line-700,000 more than there were in March 1983. Some 400,000 Australians live permanently in caravans because they cannot afford houses, and another 100,000 Australians are either homeless or live in refuges. Public housing waiting lists have continued to grow inexorably under this Government. Some 154,000 people in Australia are now on the public housing waiting list-that is a record high. What a sad and tragic record, and in terms of the number of people it is much more than that, because families are included in that number. So, those are some of the issues on which we will go to the election. I welcome this election, as do all members of the Liberal Party of Australia, and I am sure members of the National Party of Australia as well. It is an unjustified, unnecessary and cynically motivated election, but I welcome it because it provides the one means by which this Hawke Labor Government can be thrown out of office and a Liberal-National Party government restored to office so that Australians can stop the bleeding and get this great nation of ours back on the path of vitality and prosperity, the path from which it was side-tracked in March 1983 when people in Australia made the great mistake of electing this cynical, unprincipled and incompetent Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we are debating jointly a number of government financial Bills; both Appropriation Bills for the current financial year and Supply Bills in relation to the forthcoming financial year, 1987-88. I wish to direct my remarks particularly to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1986-87, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1986-87 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1986-87. These Bills seek to appropriate funds as well as meet essential and unavoidable expenditure additional to the appropriations made last August in the 1986 Budget. The additional appropriations are required to meet commitments already approved by the Government since the Budget, as well as to meet requirements of an ongoing nature. Some $419m is sought in relation to the three Bills to which I am directing my remarks. That amount of money is offset, in part, by savings which have been made during the year. This reflects the Government's determination to achieve savings in expenditure for ongoing programs whenever possible. After allowing for the prospective savings, the net increase in expenditure which will result from these Bills is of the order of some $35m.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to direct most of my remarks today to the elections which will be held on 11 July and the issues and the policies that I see as being at the centre of that election process. In its first three years the Hawke Government delivered higher levels of economic growth than any of the other developed industrialised countries in the world. In fact, in two consecutive years while we have been in office we had over five percentage points of real economic growth-very high growth indeed. Even in 1985-86, when growth moderated to 4.1 per cent, the result achieved was still a higher rate of growth on an annual basis than was the best rate of growth ever achieved when Mr Howard was Treasurer of the Fraser Government. So, even in 1985-86 we had a higher rate of growth than the best achieved in all the years that Mr Howard was Treasurer of Australia. After three years of strong growth the Government made a readjustment to economic policy in the Budget last year. The reasons for that involved the massive decline in Australia's export prices compared to the prices that we have to pay for imported items and the consequent impact of that on the recurrent part of Australia's balance of payments deficit-the effect on our balance of payments of factors involving the trading items and the so-called invisible items, such as freight and insurance.

The Government's economic policy of readjustment basically is to hold down domestic demand growth while demand from external sources, for exports, increases. The Budget calculates that net exports, for example, will constitute some 1 3/4 percentage points of projected growth in gross domestic product this financial year, with the domestic sector contributing only one-half of a percentage point to the growth in gross domestic product. That latter figure basically will have the effect of improving the balance of payments by holding down the rate of growth in imports. To achieve those objectives about which I have spoken, the Government has made substantial reductions in its expenditure programs. I refer to last year's Budget, previous exercises in cutting expenditure and, of course, the May statement which was brought down just over two weeks ago when, in respect of the 1987-88 financial year, the Government reduced the total volume of outlays by the Commonwealth Government by $4,000m-a stupendous amount of money.

As a result of those policies, despite the situation facing us abroad and despite our difficult economic circumstances, some very encouraging economic signs are now evident in Australia. A number of very encouraging economic indicators are available to the electorate on which it can base its decisions when it votes on 11 July. The Government is going to the people of Australia with the economy having an upward trend, more jobs available, a lower employment rate and an improving external balance. In the first 10 months of the current financial year the current account deficit in the balance of payments was lower than for the same period last year, so we have had an improvement there, and, more importantly, it is now likely to be $1,000m below the Budget forecast made last August for the current financial year. There has been quite a significant improvement.

The national accounts data which were released yesterday and from which Senator Short quoted selectively show that in the six months to March 1987 the volume of exports achieved by Australia was up some 29.8 per cent. That is a stupendous increase. We have been able to achieve that in that six-month period by holding import volumes more or less constant. There has been a tremendous contribution by the excess of exports over imports to the growth in Australia's gross domestic product. That is the Government's policy. It has been saying for some time that it will use the external sector to create the real demand in the Australian economy, extra production and extra employment. That is what has been happening.

A very encouraging range of information has been released in the financial sector in recent times. All of the major Australian banks have been cutting their overdraft rates, their prime lending rates-the jargon for the overdraft interest rates for large borrowers. In April this year, only some weeks ago, rates were of the order of 18 per cent per annum, but they have been cut to the 16-17 per cent range in recent weeks. All the signs are that they are heading downwards. I instance the very important rate paid by the trading banks on their bank bills. They are very important to on-lending by banks. The rates that the banks have to pay to borrow funds for on-lending have been falling dramatically. For example, on 15 January this year, the interest rate on the 90-day bank bill, which is the major form of borrowing by the banks, was 17.7 per cent. Yesterday it was 13.8 per cent. We have seen a fall of not 1 per cent, 2 per cent or 3 per cent in that key interest rate in the Australian economy; it has gone down four percentage points in four months-a tremendous fall. I notice that as recently as last week a leading commentator said that once that rate goes below 13 per cent we will see some very significant falls in housing interest rates. We are only three-quarters of a percentage point from that level and, if that commentator is correct, housing interest rate falls are on the way.

I instance the very encouraging news on the cost of living. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will recall that when Mr Howard was Treasurer of this country, he presided, in the 12 months to March 1983, over a double digit cost of living rise of 11 1/2 per cent. That is his record; that is what he achieved when he had his go at running Australia's economy. Under this Government the cost of living rise is not 11 1/2 per cent; it is not 10 1/2 per cent; in fact it has been cut to 9.3 per cent, according to the consumer price index as of March this year. So there has been a reduction of over two percentage points in the cost of living rise under this Government.

I refer to the national accounts figures that were released yesterday. Senator Short in his address this morning ignored the inflationary implications of the national accounts data, which showed, for example, that the annual rate of inflation, as measured by the deflator which is used for the gross domestic product-it is a more broadly based indicator of inflation than the consumer price index-in the six months to March this year had fallen to 7.6 per cent. So there has been a tremendous reduction in that key indicator of prices in the community. With that sort of data available the electorate will view the reduction in cost of living rises with great interest and delight. People can accept that by June next year the cost of living rise, the rise in inflation, as forecast by this Government, will be down to 6 per cent per annum. Effectively, that will be a halving of the inflation rate inherited by this Government from the Howard Treasury in March 1983. The signs in the Australian economy are very encouraging indeed.

I turn to the jewel in the crown of our record; that is, the creation of extra jobs in the Australian economy. It is very illustrative indeed that from the time of the National Economic Summit Conference in April 1983, which was convened by Mr Hawke, up to and including April of this year-a four-year period-the number of new jobs created in the Australian economy increased by over three quarters of a million. There were 782,000 more Australians at work under the Hawke Government than were at work when Mr Howard was Treasurer. That represents an increase of 12 1/2 per cent in the total numbers of persons employed in Australia. So in a period of just four years the Australian work force has increased by a massive one-eighth since the time when Mr Howard was the Treasurer. Our record of 782,000 jobs created in four years contrasts with the record of 337,000 jobs created under the seven years of the Fraser Government. That is the record: More jobs, more opportunities and more households earning incomes under Labor than under the Liberals. We created 782,000 jobs; Mr Howard in his last year as Treasurer destroyed 186,000 jobs.

The unemployment rate has been brought down from the double digit levels under Mr Howard in 1983. During the Howard recession of 1982-83 the unemployment rate in Australia peaked at a double digit level of 10.4 per cent; under the policies of the Hawke Government unemployment has been reduced to 8.3 per cent-a reduction of over 2 percentage points in the Australian jobless rate as a result of the policies of the Labor Government. So there is a range of strong economic indicators that the electorate can use to make an informed decision on when it votes on 11 July. The electorate will return the Labor Government because of its record in getting the economy moving again after the Howard recession of 1982 and 1983.

Mr Howard has a massive credibility gap: He is going to the Australian people with a huge, yawning credibility gap. In contrast to the Hawke Government's measured response to the economic problems caused by the decline in the terms of trade, the Liberal Opposition approach is characterised by gross irresponsibility and barefaced opportunism. Mr Howard claims that the Government's May economic statement did not go far enough, although it cut $4,000m off expenditure. I read the newspapers in my State, including the provincial papers, and the Liberals around South Australia are complaining to local newspapers in their electorates about the deep cuts. Mr Howard says that the cuts do not go far enough, but a sample of the newspapers published in the electorates held by Liberal Party back benchers indicates that all they are doing is complaining about the severity of the cuts. What a contrast; what a contradiction. What utter hypocrisy from members of the Opposition in regard to the May economic statement.

Mr Howard has refused to specify the areas which should be cut and how much he expects to save. The Liberals' financial policies and promises would add some $14,000m to the Budget deficit. However, Mr Howard refuses to spell out the spending cuts that would pay for his tax promises. Mr Howard is long on rhetoric but short on detail. His lack of credibility is so big one could drive a truck through it and this is no more evident than in his failure to release the Liberals' tax policy. All the electorate has to go on in this election is a document that was leaked on Monday through the newspapers.

In contrast to the Liberals' tax mirage, the Hawke Government's tax reform package has delivered substantial tax cuts for taxpayers. It has delivered a fairer and more socially just taxation system in Australia-a system which is based more on the principle of ability to pay, a system which will no longer see high income earners regarding Australian income tax as a voluntary tax. Stage three of our income tax reductions will be introduced on 1 July next. The current 55c in the dollar marginal tax rate will be cut to 49c in the dollar; the current 43c rate will go down to 40c in the dollar and the 46c in the dollar rate will also be reduced to 40c in the dollar. In line with those reductions in income tax marginal rates, the tax free threshold will be raised; that is, the exemption from taxation of particular amounts of income will be increased and on 1 July, for the 1987-88 financial year, that figure will be $5,100 compared with the $4,595 exemption which operated when Mr Howard was Treasurer of Australia. So as a result of the Government's tax changes no Australians will pay more than half of their extra income in income tax.

Mr Howard talks about the need to cut taxes but when he was Treasurer the lowest tax bracket rate was 30c in the dollar. That was his record. As a result of Labor's tax reforms the lowest rate will not be 30c in the dollar; it will be 24c in the dollar. That is a very tangible indication of the reductions in taxation under this Labor Government-a 6c reduction under this Government has been applied to the rate for the lowest tax bracket Mr Howard could deliver in five Budgets from 1978 to 1982. Under Mr Howard the highest marginal tax rate was 60c in the dollar. That was his record. Under the Labor Government the highest marginal tax rate from 1 July next will be 49c in the dollar.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about average tax rates?

—I will turn to average tax rates in just a moment. I point out that this morning Senator Short, and yesterday Mr Howard, in his rather flustered style, said that taxation would be a major issue at the forthcoming election. Mr Howard has never been very good at doing his sums. Even the simplest piece of arithmetic escapes him. Under the Howard-Fraser Government taxation as a proportion of Australia's gross domestic product, as a proportion of our national income, did not fall despite all of the promises made by the Liberals at various elections that they would cut taxes. The fact is that over the course of the seven or eight years of Fraser-Howard Government the share of Australia's gross domestic product which went in taxation rose. It did not fall. If one looks at the figures available in the appendices to the Budget one can see that from the beginning of the Fraser-Howard Government to its end in 1982-83, the share of gross domestic product taken by taxation rose by 1.7 percentage points. It is there in black and white in the Budget figures. So the Liberals have absolutely no credibility when they say to the electorate that they will cut taxes, because their very record in government shows that despite the rhetoric they clearly are incapable of reducing taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have used that figure in this chamber day after day, week after week and month after month. Not one time has that figure been refuted because the Liberals here know, based on their record in government, that they are incapable of reducing taxation. This Government is paying for its tax cuts on 1 July by a range of very progressive, fair and socially just measures. We have scrapped free lunches for the well-to-do. What about that? In 1985 a gaggle of Opposition senators said that we would wreck Australia, the economy, business and the restaurant industry. We saved $330m a year by cracking down on expense account lunches. We are using that money. It has been redirected to pay for taxation reductions for the rest of the community. I am delighted to say that the last free lunch in Australia has been eaten.

We are taxing lurks and perks, such as the so-called company car. Why call it a company car? We, the rest of the taxpayers, pay for it. It incurs a tax deduction when it is purchased and yet it bears the name the company car. We are taxing that provision of motor vehicles to certain employees which effectively has been a form of tax avoidance. We are taxing that practice to stop it. The money from that tax is being used to reduce taxation for the rest of the community. These are some of the measures that we have introduced to make Australia's tax system fairer and more efficient, to make sure that taxation is based more on an individual's capacity to pay.

Proponents of the flat tax, and I am sure that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, are aware of some of them, have exploited confusion in the community on the difference between marginal and average tax rates. Those proponents typically have very high incomes and in effect are trying to shift the tax burden from themselves and their supporters to lower and middle income Australians. The fact is that the marginal tax rate is the rate that is levied on the last or highest dollars of a person's income, whereas the average rate is the effective rate paid on all dollars of a person's income.

For example, in the next financial year a person with a taxable income of $20,000 would have a marginal rate of 40c in the dollar compared with an average rate of 20c in the dollar. So that is the difference between the marginal and the average rate. Under the proposal for flat taxes these persons, in one model I have seen, would pay 25c in the dollar, but they would pay that on every dollar of income-so they would have an average tax rate of 25c in the dollar. That amount would be paid on every dollar of income whereas their current average tax rate is 20c in the dollar. So they would be facing an increase in taxation of 5c in the dollar on every dollar of income under this flat tax rate proposal. It is a hoax which will give enormous tax savings benefits to high income earners by reducing their average rate of tax and shift the burden of taxation on to lower and middle income earners whose average tax rates would be increased. No less than four out of five taxpayers would pay more tax under Sir Joh's flat rate tax proposal. The flat tax system would take money from the average taxpayer and give it to the 20 per cent of high income earners. In effect, by proposing this model of taxation, Sir Joh intends to rob the poor to pay the rich. That is what is behind the proposal and that is what it is designed to achieve.

Mr Howard in his knee-jerk, panicked, and flustered response yesterday to the measured statement of the Prime Minister about the election said that this election would be fought on three issues, one of which would be living standards. That is what he told the Australian people. But how can Mr Howard have any credibility on living standards? How can he go to the Australian people and say: `Vote for me because I will look after your living standards. My track record is such that it shows I am a great believer in looking after the living standards of Australian people'. What a hoax for Mr Howard to say that. His credibility is in tatters on the question of living standards.

If we look at wage rises and national wage cases before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission we see that in 18 of the last 20 wage cases heard by the Commission, the Liberal Party said: `Have a wages freeze'. That was its policy on every occasion but two in the last 20 national wage cases. That formula was retailed time after time despite changes in economic conditions. Whether there was high or low growth the Liberals wanted a wages freeze-not a pause or lower growth in wages, but a wages freeze. Whether or not the cost of living was rising the Liberals went before the Commission on 18 of 20 occasions and said: `Let's have a wages freeze'. So how can Mr Howard now go to the Australian people in this historic election campaign and say `We are going to protect your living standards' when his recipe for working people, for lower and middle income people, will be a wages freeze-whatever the economic circumstances? In the unlikely event that Mr Howard were elected Prime Minister he would offer a wages freeze as his policy on living standards.

I want to refer again to paper No. 27 which has been prepared by the Economic Planning Advisory Council, a path-breaking paper entitled `Aspects of the Social Wage'. It gives a much broader definition of living standards than do the Liberals. The Liberals define living standards only in terms of cash income and less taxation to get disposable income. They view living standards as some sort of cash concept. But in the modern industrialised society much of a person's and a household's living standard, their economic welfare, comes not just from earnings or what they pay in taxation, but what is provided by the State through expenditure programs. This comes from a range of public programs which are provided to people because government is better at providing them than are individuals. I instance education as a classic case.

For the education of Senator Short who spoke at some length this morning about living standards, I will tell him that the Economic Planning Advisory Council has come up with a broad concept of the social wage which includes income and taxation and looks at the effect of government housing expenditures and health, social welfare and education expenditures on a range of households with different incomes. What were the conclusions of the Economic Planning Advisory Council paper on the social wage, that broader definition of living standards than the narrow definition used by Liberals to define the standard of living? It showed on page 13, for example, that from 1975-76, the first financial year of the Fraser-Howard Government to 1978-79, living standards as measured by the social wage did not rise at all. In fact, they were cut on average by 5 percentage points per annum per head of population. That was the Liberals' record on living standards. There was a cut of 5 percentage points per annum per capita in social wage expenditure under the Fraser Government.

For the rest of the Fraser Government period when Mr Howard was Treasurer, from 1978-79 to 1982-83, all that could be managed was a 2.2 percentage point growth per annum per head of population in social wage expenditure. That was its result-negative growth followed by very slow growth.

But let us look at the record under this Hawke Labor Government through the accord with the trade union movement. From 1982-83 to 1985-86, the first three financial years of the Hawke Labor Government, the social wage was not cut. It did not experience negative growth as it did when the Liberals were in power, when they had their last go at running this country. It was not negative and it certainly was not held down to a rate of growth of 2.2 per cent which was the best that the Liberals could manage. It grew, on average, by 4.5 percentage points per annum per head of population. Labor's record on living standards has doubled the best rate of growth in the social wage that the Liberals could manage of 2.2 per cent; there was a broader definition of living standards in Labor's first few years of office.

So the Liberals have absolutely no credibility on the question of living standards. Mr Howard, by his own record in government, has no credibility on that question as living standards were cut under the Fraser-Howard Government. As I have pointed out, the Liberals have absolutely no credibility on the question of taxation. Their record in government shows that they are incapable of cutting taxation. Over the course of the Fraser-Howard Government Australia's share of gross domestic product going in taxation rose by 1.7 percentage points.

The Government has responded firmly and responsibly to the economic challenge posed by the decline in Australia's trading position. The Government has put in place the policy settings necessary to correct the situation. On 11 July, when the electorate votes on Australia's future, it can consider a redirected economy, a falling cost of living and a falling jobless total.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will be the last time that I rise to speak in an appropriation debate in this chamber. I would like to begin by placing on record my sincere appreciation of the friendships and the education that the last nine years in this place have given me. Being in this place is a very educational process and I am sure that all of us here find that to be the case. I will leave this Parliament not with any spirit of cynicism but rather a feeling that the issues and the problems that this Parliament encounters are difficult. Nothing in the world is simple. All the issues are complicated. Because of that I think there are difficulties and problems in the process of government in establishing and working out laws which are not generally appreciated in the community and which are often presented in an unduly simplistic way in the media. But I will say more about that later.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it is not my nature to leave any files uncompleted. Today I wish to speak on a matter that I raised in this place as early as 1982. I raise it not in a spirit of destructiveness or undue criticism but, I hope, as a harbinger for the future-as a caution. The thing which I want to talk about, which is a cautionary tale, is the new and permanent Parliament House. Over the last year or two I have found in my contacts with people in my electorate that one of the most acrimonious and controversial subjects in the eyes of the community is the new and permanent Parliament House and its costs. I think it is right and proper that that should be the case. This House of Parliament and the Parliament generally ought to take notice of the fact that, for one reason or another, through a time of great hardship in this country, a time when probably we have more people looking for public housing, more people living in caravan parks and more children in a state of destitution than has ever been the case in this country before, we have permitted the construction of a monster in economic terms.

I will say at this stage, and I think it is generally agreed, that when this monster is completed next year it will cost over $1 billion and will be one of the most expensive buildings erected on the face of the earth. I do not believe that it is appropriate, proper or right that this has happened. I believe that it is most unfortunate that, as the years have gone by, it has been a blight on this Parliament. While I never like to say `I told you so', I remind honourable senators that in 1982 I predicted in this House that, if the cost of this edifice continued to rise at the rate at which it was already moving at that time, the final cost of the building would be over $1 billion, assuming, of course, that the building would be finished by 1988. At that time Senator Sir John Carrick, the Minister responsible, said that he had spoken with members of the Parliament House Construction Authority and that the cost control situation was very good. He expressed plain horror that I could make such allegations that the building might ultimately cost more than $1 billion and he was not the only one.

At the same time Mr Gordon Peatey, the Executive Officer of the Authority, wrote a letter to the Canberra Times labelling my predicted cost figures as `inaccurate and misleading'. He felt that his efforts towards cost management were being constantly undermined by unrealistic estimates of the building's cost and unsubstantiated claims that the budget was being exceeded. That is what Mr Peatey said at the time. I bring up that figure again now, not with any great pleasure at having been right in the end, but to implore all who continue in this House and all those who will come into it not to allow a situation like this to occur again.

I am not at all impressed at the fact that, over recent months, people on the Opposition side of the Parliament have got up and criticised the cost of the new and permanent Parliament House. They did this when they knew that it was impossible to influence that cost, and they had held their hands prior to this. If some of them had stood up and supported me in 1982 we might have saved this country a lot of the money that has been wasted and we might have had more people in public housing. It is more important that we have people in public housing and that they should be housed properly and decently, rather than having an edifice which would more properly be built in Third World countries where it is necessary for governments to impress their will on the people by the size and importance of their buildings. That is an ignoble motive. Whatever one thinks of that building it is an ignoble building and an expression of ignoble motives.

I wondered whether I should hold my hands on this matter and not speak again. I have not mentioned the levels of criticism during recent months but my conscience was awakened on 11 May-not very long ago-when I heard Mr Eric Risstrom of the Taxpayers Association on the media. He took up this question of the new and permanent Parliament House and said that the building was enormously wasteful, that he had had evidence that workers on the site had set times for morning teas and other breaks which they were compelled to take-indeed, if people did not take those times they got into trouble with their fellow workers-and that there were rackets and ramps throughout all forms of the building's construction. Mr Risstrom said that taxpayers did not like their dollars being tossed down the sewer-those are his words and not mine-and I agree with him. But if a person of his standing and his degree of responsibility in the community can say that on the public media, and if members of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House have expressed disquiet about their ability to control the costs of this building and the degree of consultation that they have had, the matter ought not to be allowed to pass. There ought to be some kind of inquiry into this situation.
Why has the building cost so much? Let us look at the figures which were first announced by the then Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, in June 1980. He said:
The competition winner's cost estimate is generally credible and realistic and there will be no really significant increases upon the brief figure as the building proceeds.

That was the statement the then Prime Minister made. Of course, the figure for the design brief was $151m. What would the amount be in 1987 figures, allowing for inflation over that period? The cost should now be well under $400m. I ask honourable senators to keep that figure in mind because, as I understand it now, that cost will be something like $1.1 billion. It is just too much money to be passed over, to be shrugged aside. So it is a matter of conscience-something that lies very easily on my conscience-that I associate one of my final speeches in this Parliament with a request that the Government, or whichever party gains government after the next election, undertakes a public inquiry into the costs of the new and permanent Parliament House and to establish, among its other terms of reference, why the building has exceeded by so much, what it ought to have cost. It should also take into account those concerns being expressed by people such as Mr Risstrom and by members of parliament about the building and its costs. If we do not do that, I think the members of this Parliament will lay themselves open to the accusation that they do not care about these things-that they really do not care how much public money they spend; that it is no good the community saying that there is cause for disquiet; that literally half a billion dollars over and above what should have been spent can go down the drain and nothing will be done about it.

I suggest that that situation should not be allowed to continue. So, as an individual senator-not as an Australian Democrat but as a senator for New South Wales representing my constituents-I formally call for a government inquiry into this scandal, whatever government is returned, to establish why it happened and to make sure through the establishment of that inquiry that nothing like it ever happens again with a public building built under the auspices of this Parliament.

I felt I would raise one other matter of concern, because it is a matter about which I know other senators and members of the House of Representatives are also concerned. Honourable senators may recall that when I began I mentioned the difficulties and problems that members of this Parliament have in carrying out their work. I have been concerned over the years about what appears to me to be an attempt in areas of the community to establish a diminution of the status and value of members of this Parliament. To an extent, I think this attack on parliaments is a world-wide phenomenon. While it is only too easy in this line of work to have conspiracy theories and to be paranoid, as all of us know-I often say we fight paranoia every day-I think that the evidence is mounting that indeed members of parliament are not regarded in the way that they have been in the past.

I am one of those who believe it is quite wrong, whatever the other merits, that members of parliament should be paid so badly. Indeed, there are significant areas of the Public Service which are now paid better than members of parliament, in spite of the fact that, theoretically, members of parliament tell public servants what to do. I think it is quite wrong that, say, a Press secretary on the staff of a Minister should be paid better than a member of parliament. This is not an economic matter. I am not putting it forward in those terms. Rather, it is the process of the diminution of the status of members of parliament which is wrong.

There have been attacks, one way or another, on the privilege of members of parliament. I think they are very rightly being resisted, and they should continue to be resisted. It is not a reasonable argument to suggest that people abuse privilege. In parallel, one could make a similar argument that none of us should drive a motor car and all motor cars should be abolished from tomorrow because some people drive them dangerously or irresponsibly. The powers of privilege are very important. They are the safety valve of the community and they ought properly to be maintained. My thought is that we should give no ground whatsoever in that area under any circumstances.

Another area of this diminution of the powers of members of parliament which is cause for concern is the tendency, especially on the part of the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to look at Australia not so much as a parliamentary democracy but rather as a sort of consensus arrangement in the manner of the Indonesian Musjuwara system. The idea of having summits and calling into consultation members of the community, no matter how eminent they are, seems to me a dangerous and false direction which ought to be thought out properly at its philosophical roots. The purpose of this Parliament is to have people here who are elected by their fellow citizens after a process of thought because those fellow citizens, presumably-I know I am talking in ideal terms; but why not, for once?-feel that that is the best way of establishing a system of responsibility in the parliamentary sense. In other words, by electing us to this place and other people to the other place we have people who are responsible to the electorate. That is, of course, true. That is the whole basis of parliamentary democracy. To erode that by saying `Okay, parliament is one part of government but we will have a summit to look at what everybody in the economic field, or business or unions thinks; and those decisions will somehow be railroaded through as policy' seems to me to be a very dangerous and false direction-not because I have any argument with the wisdom of trade unions or business organisations or any of that kind of thing, but only because they are not responsible in the sense of which I am speaking.

It is a selling out of the community if people who intend to govern this country say that they will do so not through the strict mechanisms of parliamentary democracy but by somehow short-circuiting that process by going through this or that area of consultation and somehow making the results of that consultation become policy. Of course, that is dangerous also because when one consults one selects the areas of consultation, thereby involving a selective process. Again, it is wrong for anybody, with the best will in the world, to feel that he can consult a group and come away and have the resulting views confirmed and it will be fine. It seems too easy for any of us to do that. With the best will in the world, we can go along perfectly sincerely and come back after consulting a lot of people and say: `I am right about this; this confirms my view'. It depends on whom one consults. That consultation also happens to be a subjective process and because of that it ought reasonably to be suspect.

The third area in which I think there is a problem with this Parliament is the treatment it receives from the media, especially the electronic media. This is a matter which ought properly to be raised. I am not raising it in a personal way. The Democrats, and I particularly, have, to my mind, never had anything but good treatment from the media. We have had a better media run, I suppose, than we deserve, because we are a novelty and things of that kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that's true.

—I am glad that Senator Messner agrees with me. I suppose it is part of any small party's riding orders to do that. That is the sort of way we have kept things going. That is fair enough, from that point of view. But I am concerned about the overall influence of areas of the media. In Australia we are now getting very strong and persistent bias in newspapers and some of the electronic media towards certain sections of the community. My view is that the New Right is getting far too much newspaper running. It is getting a far greater amount of newspaper running and attention than its apparent influence in the community would deserve. That is being done, presumably, to try to increase its influence in the community. I do not think that is happening. The poll figures already show that that is not the case. Again, I have no particular argument with the New Right; it is entitled to its point of view. All I am saying is that a degree of bias is growing up in this country and there is also a tendency on the part of the media not to report as adequately as it should the constructive and useful things that are done in this place and in the other place. They tend to concentrate on confrontation, argument, disputation, personality problems and the bizarre and unusual things that sometimes happen in any organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to appear over-wise in this matter, but I am an ex-journalist myself. I served in that profession as a foreign correspondent, as a writer and as a reporter-right through all the stages of the journalistic profession-and it concerns me that that kind of influence should be exerted, and that it should be exerted in such a way that it does not help the public's view of parliament. What is the reason behind that? Is it accidental, or is there indeed-as there appears to be-a concerted influence over a period of time which, in fact, does reduce the influence and value of parliament in the public mind. If that is the case, whether it is accidental or not, it is a very serious matter and a very bad thing, which also ought to be examined at its philosophical roots. I do not argue with the right of the media to inquire into and investigate anything that happens here. Any of us should be completely open to investigation by anybody. That is absolutely right. I do not dispute that in the slightest. But so often it is the case that the media harps on comparatively small matters of confrontation, such as the question of who will or will not lead a particular party. I know these things are important within those parties. They are nationally important to a degree-but not to the degree that they are forced and pushed in the media of this country. I think it is time that that matter was looked at.

Perhaps it is time that members of this Parliament felt that at times they ought to be a little colder, a little harder to get and little less approachable by the media. Some interviewers try to put words into the mouth of the person being interviewed on television. This happens regularly now with some of the pundits, who are very bad interviewers-they may think they are good, but they are very bad. They seem to think that they will develop a point of view and that that point of view then has to be somehow pushed into the mouth of the person being interviewed. That is intolerable; it is inexcusable; it is not in the public interest, it is not in the interests of the media or anybody else. With all respect, I would have thought that when this occured honourable senators and members of the other place would be perfectly justified in using whatever rude words they felt like using, on air or otherwise, to put down that sort of situation and not answer that kind of questioning. I have found that a good deal of the mischief that one perceives in the political scene over the years has been contrived in exactly that way. There are plenty of questions, as we all know, of the beating your wife nature which have only wrong answers. It may seem smart and clever and it may even be good television to expose a public figure to that sort of situation, but is of no use whatsoever and is, as I have said, part of what is a potentially dangerous and damaging situation if one is considering good government and the welfare of the country as a whole. That sort of thing does not contribute to it, it does not add to it and, I suggest, it is not particularly valuable. It may well be increasingly perceived in that way over the years by members of the public.

I shall conclude, as one of those who sees light at the end of the tunnel-and I shall be running off to buy my catamaran pretty soon, and a few things like that-by wishing my colleagues who are continuing here well and the best of luck for the election, whatever party they are in, and saying, finally, `Don't get too much indigestion from the rubber chickens'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills we are discussing today form the Appropriation and Supply package that is coming forward at this time to provide Supply to the Government for the forthcoming few months. They come at a time when the Government has already declared an election, having brought down half its Budget only about a week ago and, of course, hiding from the people the fact that within another three months the Government would have had to pay the piper by introducing an horrendous full Budget, which it would have needed to bring down in August. The Government is determined to try to hide the facts from the people by going to a double dissolution election on 11 July to try to avoid the wrath of the people that would have followed the full Budget having been introduced in August. That is a fact of life. The Government is really pulling the wool over the eyes of the Australian people. In fact, it is quite clear that the Government has plenty to hide.

SPEECH.PARA: If we go through the economic facts of life, it is pretty easy to see the state of play with this Government. We know that this is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. We know that this Government is spending more and has spent more since it has been in office than any other government since Federation. We know that it presides over the greatest debt that this country has ever had. It has brought about the phenomenon of the 12-digit debt-the $105,000m that this country owes overseas. This all occurred under the tutelage of this Government over the past four years. The debt that was left for the Hawke Government when it came to power in March 1983 totalled $30,000m, and that has grown to $105,000m under this Government. That has led to enormous interest rates, the highest interest rates since the Depression. They are now at a level, in real terms, that is greater than those of all of our trading partners. Is it any wonder that not only foreigners but also people within Australia are failing to invest in new industries that would create jobs for Australians? That is the great challenge for the next Liberal government when it comes to power after 11 July-to ensure that a whole new system of incentive is established in this country and that, in fact, industry gets going again, in order to provide jobs for Australians, particularly young Australians.

We know that the average length of time for which a person is unemployed has virtually doubled since this Government came to power. In 1983, on average, people were out of work for 26 weeks; today, on average, they are out of work for 46 weeks-nearly double. So, there is absolutely no hope for the unemployed under this Government. When we look around and see the problems of young people in this community, we note that approximately 25 per cent of our young people are unable to find jobs. That is a direct result of this Government's anti-incentive policies. What are those anti-incentive policies? The first is, as I have just mentioned, those very high interest rates that this Government has brought upon this nation. The second is taxation. We all know that the Government has broken every promise that it ever gave on taxation. We know that whereas the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said he would not have a capital gains tax, we indeed got one. That is the same sort of promise that he gave pensioners about the assets test-`We will not have an assets test'-but we got one. We were not to have a tax on superannuation payments, but we got one.

So the list has gone on until the most obvious phenomenon and the clearest feature of this Government's period in office, the famous disposable promise has become apparent. The promises of this Government are not worth the proverbial bumper. They are not worth even writing down on paper.

Senator Walsh yawns at that kind of revelation, but the truth is, as he would know-he has been party to the breach of promise-that those things were promised twice to the Australian people at elections and, of course, the further promises we can expect during the election campaign in the next few weeks will not be able to be counted upon in the event of the Government being re-elected, either. The people of Australia have had enough. They know that this Government does not tell the truth. They know that it does not tell the people all the facts and, consequently, that we will not get the kind of truth in government that we might expect from another colour of government.

On the question of taxation, we have seen the introduction of the fringe benefits tax. The Government has claimed great credit for the windfall gains of hundreds of millions of dollars that have come out of business to pay that tax. Of course, the point is, as we said during the debate on this matter at an earlier time, that that is a tax on employment and, indeed, must-in the same way as payroll taxes which are levied by the States are a tax on employment-destroy job opportunities in this country. The fringe benefits tax has raised, I think, some $800m in this financial year. That is certainly a large sum of money, but how many jobs have gone down the tubes as a result? We know that motor car industry sales, for instance, are down by 35 per cent this year-35 per cent! Of course, not only has the motor car manufacturing industry suffered job losses, but the biggest impact of that drop has been in motor vehicle dealerships and the people who are employed in that sector of the industry. It is pretty obvious that perhaps 10,000 to 15,000 jobs have disappeared in the motor dealership area. That is the kind of thing that has come about as a direct result of the Government's activities and clearly indicates that there can be no investment confidence or incentive for the future as a result of these kinds of new taxation measures.

That is why the statistics that have recently emerged reveal no confidence in investment. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and the National Australia Bank recently put out statistics clearly indicating that people looking ahead to invest in new job creation opportunities in this country are very pessimistic. That was confirmed by the figures released yesterday for the March quarter this year, which indicated that investment was down by some 8 per cent compared with the figures for the previous quarter, which, in turn, were down very substantially compared with those for the rest of the year.

That investment figure is absolutely vital in terms of where this country is going. This Government is unconcerned with the fact that investment is collapsing. It is doing nothing to improve that investment climate in this country and is, indeed, trying to compound the problem by ensuring that people have the wool pulled over their eyes as to the facts.

That is why, if this Government were to be returned to power after 11 July and actually brought down a Budget in August, we would find the truth and we would find that severe measures would be taken in that Budget which would be politically unpopular and unpalatable, and which the Government is not prepared to put forward at this time. Not only has the Government imposed the highest rates of tax since Federation, but also the living standards of ordinary Australians are suffering tremendously. People are having trouble meeting the mortgage payments on their houses. People renting houses, particularly in Sydney, are finding they have to pay some $267 a week for an ordinary three-bedroom house. That seems unbelievable in terms of average weekly earnings, which are no more than about $450 a week. It means that rental payments take up more than half of people's disposable income.

That is a disgraceful state of affairs which has been brought about by a lack of investment by ordinary private individuals in housing for low income families; the capital gains tax; and the abolition by this Government of negative gearing taxation concessions. Those things are causing huge concern, and clearly people's disposable incomes are not as lavish or as generous as they were. People are starting to reduce their living expenditure. That is having a devastating impact upon their psychology, their incentive to work harder and so on. People know that taxes will only take more out of their pockets and those of their families if they seek to work a little more overtime; they know they will lose at least 40 or 50 per cent of their extra earnings through taxation.

One set of statistics that has come to my notice that indicates a downgrading of people's standards of living simply concerns retail sales. We all have read the overall statistics, and in fact some which came out yesterday indicated that retail sales have fallen by about one per cent over the last quarter. When one breaks the figures down a little, one finds major changes greater than that in, for example, the area of red meat sales. The fall in that area is dramatic. Indeed, butchers all over the country are noticing that, instead of buying a steak or some other choice piece of meat, people are downgrading their purchases to sausages and minced steak. That is happening all over Australia and it is direct evidence of the decline in the standard of living in this country under this Government. It is the kind of thing that is happening across the whole range of living costs. Some years ago we read with horror about people, living in rather insalubrious circumstances in New York City, eating dog food instead of real meat. It looks as though this country is well down that route at present as a result of the Government's policy.

On the matter of taxation, it is always useful to remind ourselves that the Government has increased the rate of tax applicable to the average wage earner since it came to power four years ago. The rate of tax applicable to those people earning average weekly income in 1983 when the Government came to power was 30 per cent. That figure is now 43 per cent. The marginal rate of tax has gone up by almost 50 per cent under this Government. That certainly does not indicate a reduction in taxes and indeed, as we all know, any reductions that occurred last December and which are about to occur, on 1 July, have all been paid for by increased inflation and by the so-called bracket creep effect. The Government is only giving back what it has already taken out of the pockets of Australians by virtue of that silent robber, inflation.

That is a fair indication that people are certainly feeling the squeeze not only in respect of their living costs but also in respect of taxation. Taxation levels are clearly making a big difference to people's attitudes. That was seen in the reaction in the last few days to a leaked newspaper report of the Liberal Party's taxation policy, which indicated a very substantial, almost revolutionary, change to taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —A revolutionary increase in the deficit. You have got it up to $18 billion now.

—If one really looks at it, it is probably $25 billion. Why does not the Minister for Finance call it $25 billion? It may be $30 billion. The figures the Minister throws about are absolutely irrelevant because he does not know the policy. In fact, the document printed in the newspaper was not the Liberal Party's policy, and it has nothing to do with the point that the Minister is trying to make.
—You haven't got one.

—The Minister does not have long to wait. The policy will be out shortly, and the Minister will be astounded. He will find he has a real fight on his hands. The Australian people are sick to death of paying taxes. The reaction that occurred after the printing of that article in the Herald the other day indicates the extent of that sickness. The reaction members of the Liberal Party have had has been enormously positive. Clearly, our policy will be very attractive to the people, and it will show the direction that the Liberal Party's future taxation policy will take.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government gave us all the hint as to when the election would be by withdrawing last Monday its industrial relations legislation. Apparently the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has been working on it for three years. He has been consulting all over with the business community, the industrial relations community and the trade unions to get this brave new world of industrial relations into the field. When the crunch came and the Bill was to be brought into the Parliament, the Government found that enormous opposition to the Bill, which was aimed at keeping trade unions above the law, was growing outside and inside the Parliament, and it withdrew the legislation immediately it started to feel that opposition. In the first place the Government has not got the guts to carry through with that legislation, because it knows it is electorally unpopular, and, in the second place, the Government has misunderstood from the very beginning what it should be on about in the industrial relations area. All one can say about the Hancock legislation is that it is a payoff to the trade unions. It is a payoff to put the unions above the law, which no doubt the Government has promised the unions over a long period-ever since it came to government in 1983.

It is quite clear that by getting rid of the effect of sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act the unions would be on easy street. They would have had removed one of the major thorns in their flesh because of the very effectiveness of those sections of the Act. The Government's measures to try to water down those sections to such an extent that they became unworkable was clearly an attempt to put the unions into a privileged situation, above the ordinary rights of individuals in this country. That needed to be opposed, and certainly the Liberal Party was opposed to those measures in this Parliament. However, it means that the Government has now handed the Liberal Party an issue for the election campaign. The people know that if they re-elect the Labor Government to power on 11 July, they will get this legislation.

During the campaign we will have the opportunity of highlighting the effects of the industrial relations legislation, and the people of Australia will be able to make up their own minds what they think of it. Quite clearly, the choice will be very easy for them, as they will know that the Liberal Party of Australia opposes that nonsensical legislation. They will know that they would be handing over power to the trade unions-not to the Hawke Government-if they vote Labor. Consequently, the people of Australia will opt for the alternative.
