That is quite clear from the reaction of people on the street to the union issue. Only the other day a poll was taken; that showed that 70 per cent of trade unionists want a reduction of union power. In fact, only 37 per cent of people interviewed said that they supported the position of the Government in respect of trade unions. I suppose it is no wonder that the legislation was withdrawn by the Government.

The other point that I want to make about the forthcoming election concerns the position of the Australian Democrats. Notwithstanding Senator Mason's `farewell speech' that we have just heard, it is clear that the Democrats have been bought off. The situation is that we have seen the Democrats support the Government here today in relation to the guillotine to be applied to debate on legislation between now and 5 June.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I take strong exception to the statement made by Senator Messner that the Democrats have been bought off. It is an insulting and misleading statement which ought not to be made in this place, and I call on him to withdraw it without reservation.
—Senator Messner, do you withdraw that statement?
—I will withdraw that particular statement, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I think that even Senator Mason--
—They have done a deal.

—I was just about to say that I think that anybody with half an eye would have to agree with me when I say that the Democrats have obviously done a deal with the Government, and I refer to the question of preferences for the forthcoming election and to the fact that they have got themselves a double dissolution. Everyone around this place and all over Australia knows that the only way that the Democrats can survive in an election-which otherwise would have been a half Senate election-is by means of a double dissolution, where their quotas are reduced by half. All the commentators in the papers have been saying that the Labor Party has deliberately designed this election, on the flimsiest of excuses, in order to provide the Democrats with an opportunity. If that is not the basis of a deal, I do not know what is. The test of that--

—On a further point of order: I would again like to draw the speaker's attention to my resentment and total rejection of his suggestion that there has been a deal. I point out to Senator Messner that the double dissolution election will occur because the Government feels that it was given a reason for the double dissolution due to the rejection by the Senate of the Australia Card.
— Order! There is no point of order.

—I simply make the point, Mr Acting Deputy President-and I thank you for your firm ruling in this regard-that the test of whether or not a deal has been done will become very clear in the next few days when we find out how the Democrats will distribute their preferences on their how-to-vote cards for the forthcoming election.
—The choice is theirs.
—I will be very surprised-as indeed Senator McKiernan will be very surprised-if the preferences do not go to the Australian Labor Party.
—They will recognise the talent that we have.

—All honourable senators in this place recognise that the Democrats are the left wing of the Labor Party; they have been for the many years that they have sat in here. They have supported the introduction of these new taxes, like the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax, as well as the assets test on pensions, and also the lump sum superannuation measure. All of these things have been due to none other than our friends, the Democrats! When I say `our friends' I am referring specifically to the friends of Senator McKiernan. The fact is that the speech that Senator Haines made here yesterday, which was nothing but an apologia for the reasons for calling the election, showed quite clearly that she ought to be a member of the Australian Labor Party. I think it is obvious that a deal has been done and, indeed, I point out to Senator Mason that the test of it will be when we see what colour the preferences are on the Democrats' how-to-vote cards. Members of the Labor Party would be terribly surprised-indeed we would all be surprised-to find that those preferences were not going to Labor.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of Senator Short I shall move an amendment to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1986-87 which sets out the position of the Liberal Party on the matter of the reasons for the election. Accordingly, I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for-
(1) its decision to call an early election without informing the Australian people as to the content of the August 1987 Budget;
(2) its continued mismanagement of the economy which has caused:
(a) widespread and growing concern among Australians about their future;
(b) a sustained reduction in the living standards of all Australians, and in particular Australian families with young children, and
(c) fundamental weaknesses in the nation's economy as indicated by-
(i) declining economic growth rates,
(ii) inflation at four times the average of our major trading partners,
(iii) record relative interest rates,
(iv) an overseas debt burden of $105 billion, and
(v) the value of the Australian dollar being cut by one-third; and
(3) its failure to implement the genuine expenditure cuts in its May economic statement necessary to restore balance to its policies and reduce interest rates''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bills provide the Senate with the opportunity to note, with concern, the Government's total failure in relation to economic policy, the Government's uneasiness-and quite proper uneasiness-about the future of the Australian economy and, of course, in particular, the Government's concern about the sort of Budget that will have to be brought down later this year, if this Government were to stay in office. The reality is, and the whole of Australia knows it, that the Government is having an early election because it does not want to have to face the people after having brought down the forthcoming Budget. It is a simple and uncomplicated proposition. The people of Australia have every right to ask: `What has this Government got to hide? Why is it going to the polls before the forthcoming Budget?'. Well, we know perfectly well why. When the Government introduced part of its package, when it introduced its mini-Budget and when it was talking to the States, it was reassuring the markets that this was part of an overall plan and that the Budget itself in August would be the next stage. However, the Government has now turned around completely. It is now saying that it has put everything in place, that it does not need to wait until the coming Budget. What has happened magically to change the situation? Previously these things were only part of what the Government planned to do, with the Budget to be an important segment and with more and significant things to be done in order to placate the market, in other words, to soft soap the market-an attempt to sell the Government with words rather than deeds-while in fact now we find that the Government is going to an election.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now trying to placate Australian voters by saying: `Don't worry, we have in fact put everything in place, there is nothing left to do in the Budget, so do not worry about what is going to be in the Budget'. That is the sort of deception that we have had from this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) before every election. Let the Senate cast its mind back to the list of promises made before the 1983 election by Mr Hawke, the man with the record list of broken promises. Let us go back to the 1984 election and what he promised then. The assertion in those days was: `Yes, we will keep interest rates down. Yes, everything will be wonderful. All you have to do is vote Labor. Capital gains tax? No, I can give an assurance, in words that even the Opposition would understand, that there will be no capital gains tax.' It is the same sort of promise that was disgracefully and deliberately broken on every occasion that this Prime Minister has gone to the polls. On every occasion we have seen a deliberate determination to make promises which he had no intention of keeping, to make assurances to the people of Australia which were false and which were broken.

Here we have now this latest assurance: `Don't worry. There will be nothing in the Budget'. If the Prime Minister is standing on his track record he cannot be believed in any run-up to any election. He has a track record of disgraceful deception of the Australian people in pre-election times. If anyone is to be conned by an assurance from this Prime Minister not to worry about the Budget, one can just look at his record of deception in these matters and his continual assurances which are made in the knowledge that they will be broken. The essential element is that they are made in the knowledge that they will be broken. It is quite right that newspapers such as the Australian should point out:

The main difficulty facing the ALP is the holding of the election before the presentation of this year's Budget. The Government will have to work very hard to persuade the electorate that it does not have ulterior motives in calling an early poll, and, if it is re-elected and the subsequent Budget is found to contain unacceptable elements of which the public has not been warned, respect for its integrity will be critically injured.

This Government's integrity has already been critically injured on this score. It has no integrity in terms of statements made before elections, and in particular this instance when it is talking about one not needing to worry about the Budget is self-evident bunkum.

On what issue will this election be fought? Clearly, the state of the economy is a major disaster for Australia, and that has its effect on standards of living for ordinary Australians; it has an impact on the family; and it, of course, impinges immensely on the tax burden of Australians. These problems are now being compounded by the Government's determined and deliberate attempt to increase the power of union bosses. We have a situation where the former President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, now Australia's Prime Minister, is delivering to the present President of the ACTU increased power to thumb his nose at the Australian people, to disrupt the economy and to destroy the industrial base of areas such as mine, the Illawarra region of New South Wales, where there is massive industrial disturbance.

I remind the Prime Minister that he came to power and won seats in that area on a deliberate and straightforward uncomplicated lie, and that political lie was that there would be no more sackings in the steel industry and no more retrenchments in the coal industry in the Illawarra region. Thousands and thousands of jobs later, people are still being sacked-a couple of hundred were sacked from the coal industry only this week. There are still retrenchments in the steel industry-60-odd were put off in recent times. Yet that was the basis on which that man came to that area and sought the support of voters. He was elected in that area on a lie; he will be defeated in that area on a lie.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who's that?
—That is the Prime Minister who made false promises to people in that region at that time. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put on record the reasons for my arrest in the United States of America at the Nevada test site, when I partook in the Mothers' Day Action of 10 May. I know that there are some honourable senators who feel that this was not appropriate behaviour for an Australian senator, so I think it is important that I do place on record the reasons for my action on that occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: This was an action which involved civil dis- obedience by a large number of people. There were 3,000 people at the Nevada test site for the action, 780 of whom got arrested for trespass, for going over the line into the United States Department of Energy territory at the site. Civil disobedience has become quite commonplace in the United States when citizens have felt that they have exhausted all of the usual procedures for encouraging a change in their government's attitude on any particular issue. They have a history of non-violent civil disobedience which we do not share in Australia but which, I think, it was very appropriate for me to participate in on that occasion. The citizens of the United States have already written many letters, to their politicians; they have signed petitions; they have lobbied, they have public opinion polls on their side. Depending on which opinion poll you look at, at least 70 per cent of United States citizens want their government to stop the testing of nuclear weapons. Since the Soviet moratorium on weapons testing, which was in place for 18 months, they have become increasingly aware of the fact that it is their government-the United States Government-which is holding up the process of achieving a comprehensive test ban. This is something which the world urgently needs and something which I am glad to say our Government has fully supported. Our Government could have done more to persuade the United States, our friend and ally, to reciprocate to the Soviet's moratorium. It did not do that. I believe that our disarmament ambassador has worked tirelessly to put a comprehensive test ban in place. It is very clear to world citizens that it is the United States which is holding up this procedure.

With that background in mind, knowing that there are Bills before both the Senate and the House of Representatives of the United States Congress which, if passed, would limit funding for the testing program, civil disobedience has been considered by people who have long been opposed to the testing of more nuclear weapons as an appropriate action to take to draw attention to the issue. Mass civil disobedience must eventually make a change to the actions of any government, which can only govern by the consent of the majority. If the people refuse to co-operate on a mass scale the workings of a government will break down. The United States peace movement hopes that the United States Government will come to its senses before that stage is reached. There is increasing opposition to the tests because that Government has ignored the Soviet Union's 18-month moratorium proposal. The action taken at the Nevada test site on 10 May was the fourth major action at the site this year and further rallies are planned. So far this year almost 2,000 people have been arrested at the site. The stage has now been reached where the District Attorney of the county of Nye, in which the test site is located, has announced that charges of trespass will be dropped because the courts cannot cope with the number of people who are being arrested. The law is being made to look rather foolish because people must be arrested for trespass if they go across a given line, yet charges against them are not being proceeded with. This is an important stage in the whole process of civil disobedience.

People are invoking the Nuremberg Principles which should be familiar to honourable senators. They amount to invoking a higher moral authority than the law of any particular nation. Under international law certain crimes are punishable and people, as long as they are not forced at gun point, as long as they have any choice in the matter, need to feel responsible to a higher moral authority than the laws of their own particular country. Article VI of the Nuremberg Principles refers to crimes against peace-planning, preparation, initiation or waging of a war of aggression or a war in violation of international treaties. Clearly, the testing of nuclear weapons, which are weapons of mass destruction, is in violation of this international law. The Nuremberg Principles also refer to crimes against humanity, which include the extermination, deportation, enslavement or murder of a civilian population. Again, the testing of nuclear weapons and certainly the use of nuclear weapons or any weapons of mass destruction, would be against any international law. So it is important that people should respond to this higher moral authority if they are concerned about the common good of humanity as a whole, rather than their immediate loyalties to their own countries. If they think that their country's law is against the principles of the common good of humanity in general people may well feel obliged to take action against their own country's laws-hence civil disobedience. In fact, one of the large signs in place at the Mothers' Day Action on 10 May read `Nuremberg obliges us to act'.

The Mothers' Day Action was taken according to the principles of non-violence, clearly laid down and, with the permission of the Senate, I would like to have incorporated in Hansard both the Nuremberg Principles and the non-violent guidelines for the Mothers' Day Action in question.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
THE NUREMBERG PRINCIPLES
(i) Any person who commits an act which constitutes a crime under international law is responsible therefore and liable to punishment.

(ii) The fact that internal (i.e. national) law does not impose a penalty for an act which constitutes a crime under international law does not relieve the person who committed that act from responsibility under international law.

(iii) The fact that a person who committed an act which constitutes a crime under international law acted as Head of State or responsible government official does not relieve him from responsibility under international law.

(iv) The fact that a person acted pursuant to order of the Government or of a superior does not relieve him from responsibility under international law, provided a moral choice was in fact possible to him/her.
(v) Any person charged with a crime under international law has the right to a fair trial on the facts and law.
(vi) The crimes hereinafter set out are punishable as crimes under international law:
(a) Crimes Against Peace:
(i) Planning, preparation, initiation or waging of a war of aggression or a war in violation of international treaties, agreements or assurances;
(ii) Participation in a common plan or conspiracy for the accomplishment of any of the acts mentioned under (i).

(b) War Crimes: Violations of the laws or customs of war which include, but are not limited to, murder, ill-treatment or deportation to slave labor, or for any other purpose of civilian population of or in occupied territory, murder or ill-treatment of prisoners of war or persons on the seas, killing of hostages, plunder of public or private property, wanton destruction of cities, towns, or villages, or devastation not justified by military necessity.

(c) Crimes Against Humanity: Murder, extermination, enslavement, deportation and other inhuman acts done against any civilian population, or persecutions on political, racial or religious grounds, when such acts are done or such persecutions are carried on in execution of or in connection with any crime against peace or any war crime.
(vii) Complicity in the commission of a crime against peace, a war crime, or a crime against humanity as set forth in Principle VI is a crime under international law.
MOTHERS' DAY ACTION
Non-Violence Guidelines for the Action
1. Our attitude, as conveyed through words, symbols, and actions will be one of openess and respect toward all people we encounter.
2. We will remain nonviolent, verbally and physically.
3. We will not damage any property.
4. We will not bring or use any drugs or alcohol.
5. We will not run.
6. We will act in the spirit of the action scenario consensus reached by the affinity group spokescouncil. In the event of a serious disagreement, we will remove ourselves from the action.
7. If arrested, we will not actively resist.
8. We agree to fully accept the legal consequences of our actions and will not seek to evade these consequences beyond legitimate legal recourse.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It is important that these principles be clearly understood. It was very impressive to see the way in which this action was conducted, clearly along lines of non-violence. There was no verbal, let alone physical, aggression, and there were people present who supported the continuation of the tests. It was very impressive to see such discipline exercised by a very large number of people who were determined to make their protest according to these principles of non- violence. One of the important principles is that no surprise tactics be adopted, that there should be no running, that there should be no drugs or alcohol on the site and that people should refrain from verbal or physical abuse of any other person at the site. These principles were very clearly upheld by all of the participants in the action so it was conducted in a very peaceful and dignified manner. That for me was a very important component of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I think also that it was important that on this Mothers' Day, the day which in 1870 was declared by an American woman, Juliet Howe, as a day of peace and as an anti-war statement, the people who conducted this action were trying to get back to the original intention of the founder. What better gift could there be for any mother anywhere on the face of the earth than the gift of knowing that her children could live in peace? So it was highly symbolic that we should have been out there in the middle of the desert, where we were also in reverence of the earth, our mother, at the invitation of the Western Shoshone native American people. They claim that according to a treaty with the United States Government the land is theirs, further that that Government has ignored the treaty by allowing its Department of Energy to use the land as a test site. So there was also that thread to the protest action which lent it, from my point of view, a great deal of dignity. I felt that it was a privilege to participate in this action and, by going across the line with many brave Americans and people from other countries as well, show Australian support for the actions of peace movement people in the United States who are prepared to face the consequences of their actions. Many in the United States have suffered gaol sentences because they have stood firm for the principles in which they believe. To me, that is very laudable indeed.

Also, I felt privileged to participate because I believed that I was supporting this Government's stand, which is firmly against the continuation of nuclear testing in any environment and for all time. Also, it is exactly what I have a mandate from the people of Western Australia to do-work on the issue of nuclear disarmament and draw attention to the insanity of the arms race. With the current arsenal, under the arms race, standing at roughly 50,000 weapons, the last thing the world needs is to test any more weapons. This is clearly recognised by many ordinary citizens. Now it is up to the ordinary citizens of the world to influence governments which continue to test nuclear weapons-not only the Government of the United States but also, now that the Soviets have resumed testing, that government also, as well as, in particular, the French Government, which conducts its testing in the Pacific region. The world urgently needs a comprehensive test ban and I felt that it was quite appropriate for me, by participating in a peaceful demonstration, to draw this matter before the attention of the Australian people in that way and also show support for fellow workers for peace in the United States and in other countries, who need a show of support and solidarity by world citizens. That is really what it boils down to-the fact that people who are prepared to undertake civil disobedience on this particular topic are considering themselves as world citizens before they consider their loyalty to their own country, if they consider that it is involved in something which is basically immoral.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is about to head off to the South Pacific Forum meeting in Apia. This focuses our attention on the fact that the Australian Government has demonstrated its inability to understand the needs, aspirations and problems of the Pacific island states and the necessity to formulate an effective foreign policy. Instead we have witnessed the Government slowly lose control over the handling of our affairs in a region that is, of course, sensitive and fast becoming destabilised. The Government's shortcomings in the South Pacific vividly illustrate that in two successive terms in office the Prime Minister has neglected the strategic, political and economic realities that face this region.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1983, when the Australian Labor Party came to office, its much talked about platform contained many foreign policy promises. These included more and better aid, a greater balance of trade with the Asia-Pacific region, improved immigration programs and further promises of not only regional co-operation but also defence co-operation programs. Despite these promises we have seen a very different reality. Each of the areas that I have mentioned has in one way or another been diluted, ignored or mishandled.

Let me mention briefly the subject of aid. I will start by looking at the position which obtained before this Government came to office. The period after 1976 saw the most concentrated degree of aid being given to our region. In the period 1974-76 Australia's aid to the Pacific, excluding Papua New Guinea, totalled $15m. In 1976, with Soviet overtures being made to Tonga, the Fraser Government realised that the independent Pacific nations were in great need of economic assistance. That was tied, of course, to our immediate strategic concerns. The then Government quadrupled its aid to the Pacific to $60m in the 1977-79 period. The close links between strategic perceptions and Australian interests were further highlighted when the then Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, announced in 1980 that aid to the Pacific was to be increased further to $120m for the 1980-82 period.

At the South Pacific Forum meeting in New Zealand in 1982 the Australian delegation announced that aid to the Pacific would rise to $300m over a five-year period. This commitment represented three-year-forward civil aid of over 40 per cent, sending an Australian team to the islands to help assess the need for and technical requirements of maritime surveillance, the early conclusion of a non-reciprocal free trade agreement with the island Forum countries, the further strengthening of Australia's diplomatic network in the region and continued regional co-operation. Interestingly, this target was reaffirmed by the then Treasurer, Mr Hayden, in his Budget Speech of 1983.

What has happened has been, of course, a completely different story. This Government has presided over the most severe cuts in the Australian aid program that have been made since World War II. In its four years in office its annual aid budget has been progressively slashed to the lowest level in 20 years. Our aid now amounts to a mere 0.39 per cent of gross domestic product. In real terms, aid was cut by 2 per cent in 1984, 5 per cent in 1985 and 13 per cent in 1986-the toughest pruning, I would emphasise, that has taken place in any area of government spending. The 1986 Budget also cut 5 per cent off the funds allocated to Papua New Guinea. Honourable senators will be well aware that this unilateral decision, made without any consultation with the Papua New Guinea Government, caused a major regional upset. This year already, in the course of the May economic statement, the Government has cut $20m off aid programs for education-a field in the Pacific which, I would suggest, can ill afford to be cut, given the need to educate and effectively train people to overcome their country's development problems. The lack of skilled personnel is the single most important constraint to development in the Pacific. Madam Acting Deputy President, the Government has ignored the need for long term planning and the giving of a more assured level of assistance to the Pacific region, a course which would be more likely to foster a closer relationship between Australia and the countries of the region. Domestic political decisions which result in aid being provided on an ad hoc basis in response to perceived problems in the region do little to assist those nations.

Let me also touch briefly on the subject of the trade balance. The import-export balance of trade between Australia and the nations of the Pacific, with the exception of Nauru, from which we purchase phosphates, is predominantly in Australia's favour. The advantage to Australia is particularly evident in the cases of Fiji, Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands. In 1986 Australia accounted for more than 40 per cent of Papua New Guinea's imports, whilst that country accounted for only 2 per cent of Australia's overseas trade. Australia's entire trade with the Pacific accounts for about 3 per cent of total exports. At the Rarotonga Forum meeting in August 1985 new liberalising measures were announced by Australia. These were to commence in January 1987. They involved access to Australian markets being on an unrestricted basis for all products, other than those to which Australian sectoral policies applied-clothing, textiles, footwear, sugar and so on. Unfortunately, these are the areas in respect of which the island states need the greatest access to Australia's market. Therefore, the Pacific nations have not considered the announced changes to be of great benefit. This persistent imbalance in Australia's favour can only serve to illustrate the differences between Australia and the island states. The Pacific islands and Papua New Guinea have been important markets for Australian manufacturers, but we should reflect that the island markets are small and that the linkages established by Australian companies are being eroded by imports from sources other than Australia, particularly East Asian suppliers who, of course, are highly competitive. The result will be, in due course, a lowering of our market share in these islands and loss of influence that will flow from this.

The third area that I want to touch on as illustrating the failure of this Government's policies in the region is that of immigration. The Government has embarked on slow and laborious changes in this field, but has not looked at regional priorities. The populations of the Pacific islands, particularly the smaller islands, that most need outside employment opportunities are so small that Australia can have a significant impact on their economic development by enabling people to work or settle here. At present no preferential treatment is afforded such migration requests. One can contrast the situation with New Zealand. The Government, by more sympathetic treatment of Pacific island immigrants, can further the interests of the South Pacific and of Australia.

The fourth area that I want to touch on concerns regional co-operation. I would have thought, Madam Acting Deputy President, that regional co-operation was clearly essential in several areas, notably transport, communications and higher education, if obstructions to development were to be overcome and economic and political development in the island states were to continue. However, unfortunately Australia's support in the last Federal Budget for South Pacific organisations and programs decreased by 18 per cent. At the Estimates hearing on the provision made for the Australian Development Assistance Bureau in the 1986-87 Budget, it was stated that budget cuts to South Pacific regional programs were determined according to the assessed contributions of those organisations of which Australia was a member and those programs regarded as essential and consistent with sectors of emphasis in the Australian aid program. What that meant in practice was that the Government cut all funds to the United Nations development program's South Pacific program, to the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific's regional operation centre, to the Pacific islands development program, to the East-West Centre and to the Regional Teacher Training Centre for Health Personnel. Also, extra-budgetary contributions to the South Pacific Commission, the South Pacific Bureau for Economic Co-operation and the tripartite marine geoscience research program were severely reduced. The only commitments to be met in full by this Government have been those which presumably it cannot vary, such as to the South Pacific Commission, the South Pacific Bureau for Economic Co-operation, the Forum Fisheries Agency and the South Pacific Board for Education Assessment. So again the Government has not looked at the long term implications of such cuts in the region. It is understandable that in a time of economic constraint such as we are now facing economic rationalisation needs to take place. But if this is to be paramount for the Government why did it not, for example, support Papua New Guinea's proposal for the unification of the South Pacific Commission and the South Pacific Bureau for Economic Co-operation, which would have enabled economies of scale to be achieved?

The other area I wish to mention is defence co-operation. It is clear that a sense of insecurity and vulnerability has since independence prompted Pacific island states to seek protective and mutually supportive measures in the region-particularly as the vulnerability is basically economic and will inevitably have strategic implications. The Australian Government responded by announcing at the South Pacific Forum in Canberra in 1983 that Australia would develop, in conjunction with the South Pacific countries, a Pacific patrol boat project to meet the needs of regional states to patrol effectively their 200-mile exclusive economic zones. Unfortunately, as is now known, the Pacific countries criticised the fact that the boats were not of an appropriate design for patrolling open sea distances; that they were slow and unable to catch the fast craft being used by poaching tuna boats and drug-running vessels. The governments of Kiribati and Tuvalu withdrew from the scheme because their country's economies could not afford to maintain the vessels. Tonga declined from the outset. Papua New Guinea withdrew from the project in 1985 because of the operating expenses involved, but the Australian Government, of course, pressured it to reconsider and to take four boats. Similarly, Fiji withdrew but was also persuaded to reconsider and participate. So what we have is a situation in which patrol boats which many say are unsuitable are being provided and island states are taking them although their economies cannot meet the cost of properly operating them.

That brings me, in the last few moments of my remarks, having looked at that sorry saga of developing government policy, to the current situation in the South Pacific. The coup d'etat in Fiji and the drama that has followed have shown Australia how quickly things can occur in a constantly changing region. I would suggest that the events of the last few weeks have raised serious questions as to whether the Government has had a co-ordinated policy to deal with the South Pacific. The Government clearly should have taken greater notice of the advice put forward by the Department of Foreign Affairs in its submission to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in March of this year. That advice was that racial tensions were running high and could be expressed through civil disorder. As I understand it, available intelligence assessments determined that a coup was fomenting, though it seems that other intelligence assessments denied this. In fact there seems to have been an almighty mix-up in the intelligence assessments. The fact that there was such speculation as to what could be happening in Fiji and that it was ignored represents a significant error on the part of this Government. I remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that as far back as 1983 there were writings on the situation in our region. I refer specifically to the statements of Iosefa Maiva, who wrote in Pacific Perspective:

The secessionist tendencies in PNG and Vanuatu and the racial tensions in Fiji and New Caledonia may also provide opportunities for unscrupulous outsiders to destabilise the region overtly-encouraging break-away sentiments and violence. The unity of island states given their disparate compositions and relatively weak central governments could easily be undermined.

The Australian Government was at a loss to know how to handle the Fijian crisis. Its rather pathetic attempt to deflect attention by expelling from Australia the Libyan People's Bureau-which we on this side of the chamber have said should have happened months ago-gave no reason for any confidence in its regional policies. Finally, I simply remind the Senate that it is not just the difficulties over Fiji that we have to face. There are also the evolving problems in Vanuatu with its election in November, the referendum planned for New Caledonia in October and so many other matters that are not properly being addressed by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is not in the chamber because the matter that I want to raise is of some interest to him. For quite some time he has been engaged in a war of words with Australian Capital Territory doctors in relation to a dispute of long standing. I wish to raise a very serious question: Why has not the Government genuinely set out to resolve this dispute? Without taking sides in the matter I simply say that it is incredible that the Government should have made an offer to visiting medical officers in the veterans' affairs area which, in money terms, involves no more expenditure than the request made on an interim basis by Canberra doctors yet should have refused to make the same offer to the latter group. In other words, the Government is prepared to make an offer to one group of doctors-in New South Wales and other States-relating to veterans' affairs, for performing exactly the same tasks, but is not prepared even to consider doing the same when it comes to Territory doctors. Why is the Government being so discriminatory? It is urgent now, for the sake of residents of the Australian Capital Territory, that the Government stop playing politics with health in this area. If it is good enough for the Government to offer such a deal elsewhere, why will it not even consider the Australian Capital Territory doctors' interim proposal, which would cost no more? Until the Government answers that question effectively it must stand condemned for deliberately continuing the Territory doctors' dispute and so diminishing the supply of health services that should be available to the residents of the area.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the actual figures involved. We will not have an opportunity to debate during the life of this Parliament the annual report of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority. As I understand it, the presentation of papers is not to be included in the rush of legislation which is necessary to permit the early election which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has chosen in a desperate effort to avoid, firstly, the obvious economic problems that will be mounting later this year and, secondly, the consequences of any forthcoming Budget. However, it is interesting to note that on page 35 of the report medical fees are revealed as costing $3.7m, of a total expenditure of $156m-a pretty small proportion, by the way-of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority. To try to pretend somehow that settling this dispute at a rate that involves giving any substantial increase to doctors would be a costly disaster for the health system in the Australian Capital Territory is, of course, self-evident bunkum. The figure of $3.7m represents the cost in the financial year to June 1986, some 11 months ago. In keeping with this Government's lax financial control and incompetent reporting standards we have this report before us only now, almost at the end of the following financial year. The Authority has said publicly that this year the cost of the doctors' current contracts-if not changed-would be about $4.1m. The Government has offered an increase which would bring the cost to about $4.9m. The doctors made a claim which the Health Authority says would cost $7.5m. That sounds enormous, when compared with the $4.1m that would otherwise have been paid this year, until one compares it with what the cost would have been under the Macken decision-an arbitrated decision relating to what doctors should be paid in New South Wales. That would have brought Australian Capital Territory doctors a payment of $8m a year.

Let us have a quick look at the Macken inquiry which was, in fact, forced upon the New South Wales Government by the Federal Government. The Prime Minister put out a Press release congratulating himself upon having appointed Macken, a former judge, to undertake that inquiry. Now, of course, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance, in particular, are complaining about the umpire's decision. Whether or not it would be appropriate for Australian Capital Territory doctors to enjoy benefits such as would flow from the Macken decision, in fact they have put in a claim which at this stage would involve an outlay of $7.5m, or less than would be the cost to the Commonwealth if the Prime Minister's Macken decision involving an expenditure of $8m were applied. The doctors having made that ambit claim, if you like, put in another interim proposal, as they called it, which would have cost $6.9m, or some $2m more than the Government had offered. The Government has rejected that out of hand; it will not discuss it. That is incredible, when one recognises that the deal that is now being offered by this Government to exactly the same sorts of doctors in veterans' hospitals in New South Wales would, if it were transposed to the Australian Capital Territory, cost exactly $6.9m-the precise amount that has been rejected out of hand by the Government, which appears to be set on continuing the medical problems, the lack of medical services, the medical dispute generally, in the Australian Capital Territory. I do not know what its motives are. I do not know whether the Minister simply likes to maintain a situation in which he can get up in this place daily and bang his gums about greedy doctors. If it is not good enough that such an offer should have been made to doctors outside the Australian Capital Territory-an offer equivalent to that which the local doctors are seeking-why does not the Minister for Finance criticise the Department of Veterans' Affairs for having made such an offer? Obviously the double standards of the Government in this area need exposure. I believe that there is no will on the part of this Government to do something positive and sensible to resolve the Australian Capital Territory doctors' dispute.

Of course, other matters are involved. It is not simply a question of the level of fee or whether it should be a fee-for-service contract or a sessional payment. I must say that doctors to whom I have spoken in New South Wales say that the way in which the sessional payment is working under the Macken decision is wasteful; that they are being paid for spending a lot of their time waiting in public hospitals for patients to turn up. Sometimes more than half of their time is spent simply waiting, whereas under a fee-for-service basis they would be paid only when they were actually doing the job. Also there is a strong view among many medical practitioners that if they are paid on a sessional basis they become, in fact, employees for that period; they are not maintaining their independence. If they are paid on a fee-for-service basis they are paid for the work that they do. One can understand a preference for that approach to be adopted. But these are peripheral issues. The central issue is how much it would cost the Government. The Government's double standards and reluctance to do something positive and fair to resolve the dispute are such that it stands condemned. Certainly the empty rhetoric of the Minister in the matter is self-evident nonsense.

A couple of other matters need to be raised on this score. I will deal with only one of them. I have before me a letter from Mr Bissett, the General Manager of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority, in which the following statement is made concerning the suggestion that doctors now have less opportunity to deal with private patients:

While there is some truth in this assertion, it must be acknowledged that the Authority and the Government have recognised this problem and have responded positively to the profession's demands for more private hospital beds in the ACT. With a threefold increase in private beds over the next few years and a prevailing private health insurance level close to fifty per cent within the Canberra population, there is no doubt that across the total ACT hospital system, something near to the previous private/public balance will quickly be achieved.

I do hope that that does not suggest that more resources are to be allocated in the Australian Capital Territory in order to create more hospital beds. The reality is that already 34 per cent of the hospital beds in the Australian Capital Territory are not staffed. They have been put into mothballs. The annual report shows that of 1,445 beds in Canberra public hospitals only 953 are staffed. The Health Authority may simply be saying that some of the beds in public hospitals will be used in private wards and so on. One would hope that that would be the way it would be going rather than inserting additional beds in an area that is already massively over-serviced.

I will simply leave the matter there at the moment and call on the Government, instead of generating hostility as in the past, to do something positive to resolve the doctors' dispute in the Australian Capital Territory. At the moment there is a crazy situation in which residents are sent by the Health Authority to Sydney if they need a particular form of treatment and while there they are being treated by doctors who are being paid under the Macken proposals-which, of course, the Government is not prepared to offer doctors in the Territory itself. The same goes for veterans who may be sent to Concord. They will be treated by doctors who will receive the very reward that this Government denies their colleagues in the Australian Capital Territory. As I said earlier, I am not arguing the case for the doctors' initial claim. I am not arguing anyone's case. All I am wondering is why this Government should adopt such double standards in this matter; why it does not genuinely seek to resolve a dispute which has been of such major inconvenience to the people of the Territory.
Sitting suspended from 1.25 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Button in his capacities as Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. It concerns the industrial blackmail being engaged in by the Minister's Victorian Senate ticket colleague, Mr John Halfpenny, in his capacity as Victorian Secretary of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. Is it a fact that metal trades employers are at present negotiating second tier wage rises in accordance with the national wage case and subsequent directions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? Is it also a fact that Mr Halfpenny's demand for metal trades employers to agree to a 4 per cent second tier pay rise by today or face strike action was rejected by 25,000 to 1,000 at meetings held around Australia? Is it also a fact that Mr Halfpenny and his supporters were able to carry several area meetings in Victoria and that as a result strikes or bans will be either in effect or threatened after today at 30 companies in that State? Is one of those companies the vehicle parts supplier ANI? If the present strike continues, Ford and Chrysler will run out of parts by the middle of next week, and Nissan by 8 June. Will the Minister join me in condemning Mr Halfpenny's guerrilla warfare tactics which have been rejected by the vast majority of metal trades unionists? I further ask him: What advice does he have to offer the 30 companies that are the subject of this guerrilla action by his colleagues?

—It is true that under the second tier wage negotiations there has been a different approach to the negotiations in various States. The approach in Victoria, as I understand it, has been singularly different. I have had the opportunity of discussing these matters with some metal trades employers. I must say that I do not accede to the statements which Senator Chaney has made in his question which purport to be facts. I am not saying that they are not substantially correct; I am just saying that, from what I have heard, a slightly different set of facts is available.
—In what sense? I am puzzled.

—Senator Chaney referred to 30 companies; I have heard of a different number of companies. He referred to a number of meetings; I have heard different versions of those meetings-things of that kind. In saying that I differ on those matters on the basis of the information available to me, I am not saying that there is no substantial point in the question which Senator Chaney asked. Probably the most helpful thing I could do in the current circumstances is draw Senator Chaney's question and my response to the attention of the metal trades unions, and I will do that.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to clarify whether he is suggesting that the facts I have put forward in my question are in any fundamental way incorrect. If so, I would like him to draw attention to that. The fundamental facts are that around Australia a great majority of metal workers rejected the call for strike action and Mr Halfpenny is now carrying out action against 30 or so companies-it seems to me that the precise number is fairly immaterial to the import of the question-and strikes or bans will be in effect or threatened after today. There is in fact a national approach to this matter under the supervision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and Mr Halfpenny is clearly acting contrary to both the union at a national level and the dictates of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. There is a very significant impact upon manufacturers pending because of Mr Halfpenny's action. I ask the Minister: Will he condemn that action by Mr Halfpenny which is clearly destructive of the policies which the Minister has supported as a member of this Government, both as a Minister for industry and as someone who has promoted an approach to national wage fixation before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission?

—I condemn any industrial actions which are inconsistent with the policies of national union organisations and I condemn any industrial action which is detrimental to the welfare of industry. The point which was in dispute in my earlier answer to Senator Chaney is simply whether the facts which he alleged are correct in every respect. I say quite frankly that I do not know the answer to that. For example, in his supplementary question he suggested to me that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission had already given some directions in this matter. That is not my understanding. I will check that out but I understood that as late as yesterday this matter was still before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I will check that out for Senator Chaney and try to provide a more detailed answer.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Jones having addressed a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer-

Senator Chaney-Mr President, I rise with several points of order on that question. The first point of order relates to the final part of the question, which clearly calls for an expression of opinion from the Minister, which is in breach of the Standing Orders. Over the last few months the Government has been asked a series of questions in this place about leaked documents which have been put forward as the policy of the Opposition. This Government is not prepared to answer questions about what is going to be in its Budget. It is not prepared to answer all sorts of questions. To allow it to engage in broad discussions on hypothetical matters is quite clearly beyond the Standing Orders.
Senator Jones-Come on, what is the point of order?
Senator Chaney-Mr President, I direct your attention to standing order 99-if the honour- able senator has a problem about it. It reads:

In any event, this is a hypothetical question and clearly, in a Senate where debate on major matters brought forward by this Government has been restricted by guillotine, it is inappropriate to allow the Government to abuse the rights of this Senate and to engage in debate on hypothetical policy questions in the way in which the question invites the Minister to do.

Senator Lewis-Mr President, on the point of order: I also draw your attention to the part of standing order 99 which says that questions shall not contain hypothetical matter. I put it to you that this is a hypothetical matter. It involves a publication in a newspaper. There is nothing to say that it is the policy of the Liberal Party or will be at the next election. To allow Senator Walsh to get up and start raving on about this I think would be an abuse of Question Time and I suggest, Mr President, that you ought to rule the question out of order.

Senator Jones-On the point of order, Mr President: The matter I referred to was reported in the Melbourne Herald on 26 May. It is not a hypothetical matter. It was reported and I asked the Minister questions in relation to that report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rule in favour of Senator Chaney's point of order. A number of questions were asked and most of them were out of order. I suggest that the question could be rephrased in a way which would allow the Minister to answer parts of it, and I would be prepared to give the call to Senator Jones later in Question Time. I call Senator Robertson.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing--

—On a point of order, Mr President: I think the normal practice that has been followed in this place when a question is ruled out of order is to regard it as a question which has been asked and to give the call to the other side.
—I have never been in such a situation before. I called Senator Robertson, and I call him again.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Press releases issued by members of the Opposition since the May statement was made claim that there is some threat to the success of the Government's fiscal policy. Is there any substance to these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a threat to the Government's fiscal policies-I doubt whether it should be taken all that seriously-and it comes, of course, from the Liberal Party and the National Party. Both of those decrepit, creaking political organisations put out specific criticisms of measures contained in the May economic statement and said that the measures should be turned around. The Liberal Party said that $750m worth of the savings should be turned around, cancelled or reversed and the National Party-rather surprisingly, because the National Party can usually beat the Liberals very easily in this sort of contest-said that only $577m should be turned around. When it comes to the aggregate credibility gap, that is, the prospective deficit of either of these outfits, these squabbling aggregations of homeless politicians, the National Party would beat the Liberals very easily. The National Party has a $21 billion credibility gap, that is, a prospective Budget deficit of that amount if all of its proposals were implemented, while the Liberal Party has a $16 billion credibility gap.

ANSWER.PARA: I will give some of the details of the specific measures that various people in the Liberal Party have said should be implemented. Mr Howard said that the Opposition was concerned about the cut in defence spending. His shadow Defence Minister, Mr White-I seem to have heard that name before; I think he was once a member of the Queensland Parliament-put out a Press release suggesting that instead of cutting defence expenditure we should increase it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.
—Who said: `That's right'?
—I said that.

—Senator MacGibbon also believes that defence spending should be increased, so that adds a bit more to the $16 billion credibility gap that the Liberal Party already has. The Leader of the Opposition said that the family allowance was not a welfare payment and therefore it should not be means tested. That would cost $71m. Holding defence spending at the same level would cost $350m; obviously increasing it, as Senator MacGibbon wants to do, would cost more. Senator Michael Baume said that the changes to hospital charging arrangements were discriminatory and unfair. Abolishing these changes would add $80m to the deficit. Senator Baume is in favour of the Australian Capital Territory doctors union's attempt to grab a 69 per cent pay increase in one hit. It is running an industrial campaign based on work bans to grab a 69 per cent pay increase which translates into a $350 a week wage rise for a part time job, a job in which doctors spend about one-quarter of their time. Let it be put on the record that Senator Baume, the shadow spokesman for health, supports the Australian Capital Territory doctors union's pay grab for a 69 per cent increase, or $350 a week for a part time job, which it is pursuing by undertaking industrial action based on work bans. Let that point be put on the record. Mr John Moore, the shadow spokesman for transport, said that the road funding arrangements should be reversed, which would cost $180m, and Mr Peter Shack said the same thing about education. That would cost nearly $44m.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said earlier the National Party, surprisingly, is more modest than the Liberal Party. Mr Charles Blunt said that there should not be an assets test on unemployment benefit recipients, and that would cost only $12 1/2m. Mr Lloyd, the transport spokesman for the National Party, had the same attitude to road funding as Mr Moore and that policy would cost $180m. The shadow Minister for Communications--

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep going, Senator. I have never heard of half these people.

—I have not heard of this one either. The shadow Communications Minister for the National Party-someone called John Sharp-said that we should reintroduce sales exemption for a few Commonwealth commercial authorities and also Customs duty exemptions. Those measures would cost $310m and $75m respectively. The response to the May statement shows that each fragment of the Opposition, whether it is split into two, three or even four fragments as the Prime Minister suggested it was the other day, is as irresponsible as any of the other fragments and as irresponsible fiscally as the Opposition ever was.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of the decision of Mr Justice Beach in the Supreme Court of Victoria to grant an interim injunction against the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union to prevent it attempting to persuade workers to strike at the Don Smallgoods Co. Pty Ltd factory at Altona? Is he further aware that the judge heard testimony from the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, in which the union's secretary said:

QUESTION.PARA: You get nothing out of these bastards unless you belt them.

Does the Minister accept the view put to the court by counsel for Don Smallgoods that this was a case in which the Arbitration Commission had been unable to protect the company's right of freedom of contract and it had been forced to turn to the Supreme Court? Why does the Government refuse to guarantee the deletion of clauses from its industrial relations legislation which would have the effect of cutting off direct employer access to the normal courts of this land?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the decision of Mr Justice Beach to grant an interim injunction so I am unable to comment on the details to which Senator Lewis referred in his question. I am attracted by the comment of the union secretary-but not in relation to industrial disputes-namely, that `you get nothing out of these bastards unless you belt them'. It is a view I have always taken of the Opposition in this place and I propose to do just that in the next few weeks. The point of the honourable senator's question-if it had a point, apart from Senator Lewis's wish to make a speech-relates to what he chose to describe as the deletion of clauses which would give employers direct access to remedies under the trade practices legislation, for example, or perhaps in the common law jurisdiction. The industrial legislation which was introduced in the House of Representatives last week and which has been adjourned for further consultation with employer organisations and unions, did not contain clauses which took away the capacity for access to those provisions. All it did was to provide that a conciliation process, in effect, should take place before access to those provisions was available.

—Can the Minister representing the Attorney-General offer an estimate of the extent of computer crime in Australia? Is the Minister concerned that the legal system has not kept abreast of the information revolution and that the costs of the crime are passed by business on to the consumer? Will the Minister outline the problems associated with legislation dealing with computer crime, and indicate what steps the Government intends to take to help combat it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General advised me that it is not possible to offer an estimate of the extent of computer crime because it is not possible to quantify the extent of unreported and undetected computer fraud. As computers are just the tools for committing offences it is not possible to say what proportion of all reported fraud offences, for example, which we do know about are committed by the use of computers. What is known is that the use of computers to commit criminal offences-so-called computer-related crime-is a big problem in the United States. There is no reason why it should be thought of as any less of a problem here in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to the second part of the question, the Government is concerned to ensure that the legal system, in particular the criminal justice system, is capable of dealing with problems associated with the application of new technology. The Government is concerned that computer-related crime, like other white collar crimes, imposes economic costs, not only on businesses and ultimately their customers, but also on governments, which results in additional burdens for taxpayers and, ultimately, the whole community.

As to the last part of the question, the problems associated with legislation dealing with computer crime are being examined in the context of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. At the March meeting of Ministers it was decided that each jurisdiction should examine its own criminal laws to ensure that they are adequate to cover the range of criminal conduct involving computers. The complex areas of unauthorised access and unauthorised use of computers continue to be the subject of discussion among Ministers. The Government is examining both Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory criminal laws to ensure that they are adequate. We will take appropriate action where there is manifest deficiency. In this context it should be particularly mentioned, for example, that section 115 of the Crimes Act 1900 of New South Wales as it applies in the Australian Capital Territory creates the offence of dishonest use of computers which has a maximum penalty of up to 10 years imprisonment. No other jurisdiction in Australia has the provision of a similar offence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that the United States-Australian joint facility at Nurrungar in South Australia has played and could continue to play a role in the development of the strategic missile defence system, or star wars program, through the provision of information on Soviet missile and satellite launches, thereby making it a potential target? In case the Minister is not, I draw his attention to a defensive technologies study conducted in response to President Reagan's national security study directive. This study concluded in late 1983 that data such as I mentioned earlier provide high confidence that a space-based infra-red censor system can be developed to provide the sensitivity, clutter rejection, resolution and booster projectory accuracy to support boost-phase intercept requirements. Given that the Government has stated repeatedly that no joint facility in Australia participates in the star wars program, will the Government now insist that no further information relevant to that program be provided through Nurrungar?

—As has been made clear to the Parliament on a number of occasions, the Government does not endorse the strategic defence initiative program and believes that verifiable arms control agreements offer the best prospect of preventing war and ensuring international stability. The US Government is well aware of the Australian Government's position and has assured the Australian Government that none of the joint facilities is involved in the SDI program and that there is no contemplation that any of the joint facilities would be required for any system of SDI defence that might be developed. The Australian Government is confident that these assurances are valid and are being met. Certainly, nothing in anything quoted today by Senator Haines constitutes evidence to the contrary. As has also been made clear to the Parliament nor does Australia participate in research funded under the SDI program.

—I refer the Minister for Finance to a letter in Monday's Australian Financial Review from the Executive Director of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Andrew Robb, replying to the Minister's assessment of the Federation's pre-May statement expenditure proposals. In view of this response can the Minister undertake to investigate both the Federation's criticisms and the consumer price index effects of its proposals and give an answer to the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have done that; I will be sending letters in reply to the National Farmers Federation. What I had done previously was point out that the brilliant strategy devised by the right wing ideologues of the NFF to get interest rates and inflation down would have added 4 per cent to the consumer price index in the short term and, according to NFF logic therefore, 4 per cent to interest rates. My figures were challenged by the NFF Executive Director in the letter to which Senator Bolkus referred. The NFF claim that inflation would fall by 5.7 per cent if excise on refined petroleum product was removed is quite false. The weighting under the CPI of automotive fuel, heating oil and kerosene-that is, products bought by the household sector-is just under 4.9 per cent of the CPI total regimen.

ANSWER.PARA: If the excise were removed, the prices of those commodities would fall by a little over one-third and the CPI first round effect would fall by just under 2 per cent, not the 5.7 per cent which the National Farmers Federation was suggesting. Because petroleum products are also an intermediate good over time there would be some further downward effect on the CPI, possibly by as much as the original first round effect. So over time the CPI could fall by as much as 4 per cent. The rest of the National Farmers Federation figure was based on assumed cuts in government spending and the assumed CPI effects of that-in other words, on blue sky stuff which is unquantifiable. On the debit side of the NFF proposition, neither the National Farmers Federation nor the national priorities project paper from which the NFF appears to have taken its ideas is sufficiently specific to give a precise costing but it appears that its proposal is to save $5.8 billion on government outlays, that is State and Federal, by removing the provision for free treatment in public hospitals for public patients and removing medical and pharmaceutical benefits. If that were done and if people took out private insurance to cover their increased health liability, the CPI would increase by 6.7 per cent. The rule of thumb for that transfer of public expenditure to private health insurance expenditure is to add about 0.115 per cent to the CPI for every hundred million dollars so transferred.

So, the NFF should be far from complaining about my 4 per cent estimate of the increase in the consumer price index if the NFF brilliant strategy were followed because that figure was very generous to the NFF. One could argue that the immediate increase in the CPI would be of the order of 5 per cent not 4 per cent. Mr Robb also claimed that the NFF proposals in total were based on the Monash University's national priorities project analysis which he described as a highly professional analysis. In a number of ways the national priorities project so-called analysis falls well short of being highly professional but I do not intend to go into that, particularly at this time. I just say that the NFF did not draw from the national priorities project its suggestion that $577m could be saved from funding the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service. That is about $100m more than is actually spent. The National Farmers Federation suggested that we could save $100m more on the ABC than we actually spend on it. That did not come from the Monash University paper; that piece of amateurish misrepresentation was all the work of the National Farmers Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation. Is it a fact that the Government is attempting to shelve the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure regarding Mr Dick Smith's allegations concerning the Darling Harbour helipad fiasco? Can the Minister report any action taken by the Department of Aviation to reform those practices condemned in the report? Why will the Minister not heed the call by the aviation industry for an independent review into both the industry and the Department of Aviation, or has the Minister been Sir Humphrey Appleby?

—In response to Senator Sheil's interesting question, the only information that I have is that the Government has the review under consideration. Of course, it has called for public comment in respect of the May report. It has been giving consideration both to the comments and to the report. It is concerned about the future of our aviation industry. In due course, the Government will make recommendations and decisions arising out of that review.

—My question, which is directed to the Special Minister of State, relates to the election timetable. What is the last date for enrolment for eligible voters? Who is eligible to enrol and who is eligible to vote?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some information that might be of interest not only to honourable senators but also to members of the general public. The election timetable is as follows: If the dissolution of the Parliament goes ahead on 5 June, as has been agreed to by the Governor-General on the advice of the Prime Minister, and the writs are issued on 5 June, the close of rolls will occur on Friday, 12 June at 6 p.m., and I emphasise that particular time for the purpose of the latter part of my answer. The close of nominations will be on 18 June and, as we know, the election date is set for Saturday, 11 July. The return of the writs is set for 3 September and section 5 of the Constitution requires that the Parliament meet within 30 days of the return of the writs, so that would be some time up to 2 October this year.

ANSWER.PARA: The last date, therefore, for the enrolment of an eligible voter is Friday, 12 June at 6 p.m. Every person who is entitled to be enrolled as an elector is obliged by law to apply for enrolment and that includes anyone who is 18 years of age or more, is an Australian citizen or a British subject who was on the electoral roll on 25 January 1984, and has lived in one subdivision for one month. In addition, those who are aged 17 at present may enrol to vote but, of course, they are not entitled to vote until they turn 18. But should such persons turn 18 after the close of rolls on 12 June, but before the election day on 11 July, they will be able to vote. So 17-year-olds who have their eighteenth birthday falling within that one month period between 12 June and 11 July should get on the electoral roll now and they will be able to cast a vote in this most important election.

I do not intend to be partisan at all but I want to say that I think most honourable senators will agree that it is very important that young Australians get on the electoral roll and cast a vote in an election which will be very important for the shape of Australian society, for their futures and, of course, for the shape of Australian society into the next millennium. I certainly encourage them to do so. I cannot understand honourable senators on the other side of the chamber wanting to interject. I would have thought that we would all have an interest in this matter, particularly when we contrast it with what has happened, for example, in Fiji. All Australians who are eligible to vote should participate in a democratic electoral process.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate recall, in answer to a question asked by Senator Messner two weeks ago, describing as quite encouraging the real terms increase in manufacturing investment recorded in the December quarter of last year? Is the Minister aware that yesterday's Bureau of Statistics survey of private capital expenditure shows a real terms fall of 8 per cent in total private capital expenditure during the March quarter of this year? Is he further aware that the biggest component of that overall decline was a drop of 13 per cent in investment in new equipment and that the Bureau's survey of expectations shows an expected decline of 7 per cent in manufacturing investment in 1987-88? Does the Minister agree that these figures expose the dubious nature of the Treasurer's mini-Budget optimism on investment and help to explain why the Government is rushing to an election before the bleak economic realities become even more apparent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I do not agree with Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's wishful conclusions from the material contained in the body of her question. I certainly recall saying to Senator Messner or, perhaps, Senator Chaney a week or two ago-whoever it was scurried off to see whether the figures were correct-that there had been a real increase in manufacturing investment in the December quarter of 32 per cent.
—That is not right.

—I am sorry; Senator Chaney's question related to manufacturing exports. Senator Messner's question related to investment. I have not examined fully the national accounts figures published yesterday but, as I understand it, business investment increased at an annual rate of 12.3 per cent in the six months to March and that figure is revealed in the national accounts figures. I am advised that the Australian Statistician published investment figures showing a decline in the March figure but those figures also confirm that the overall figures are on track with the Budget forecast for investment in 1986-87 which, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle will recall, were not optimistic figures in respect of investment as revealed in the Budget. It is the Government's view that these statistics have been overtaken, to some extent, by policy developments in May and that they show a welcome increase in investment intentions for 1987-88 over previous figures.
—That is not right.
—It all depends on which mirror you look in. I am giving the answer from mine.
—You are looking in the wrong mirror. The intentions are for a decline next year, not an increase.
—There are all sorts of surveys of investment intentions--
—Get the figures right.
—Who are you to interject and say: `Get the figures right?' The first time you asked a question as shadow Minister for Finance you made about a $60m mistake. You would be a good person--
—You don't even know what is happening in the metal industry and you are supposed to be the Minister.

—I am not supposed to be the Minister for the metals industry. The honourable senator should get his facts right too. The fact that the Opposition is confused does not surprise me in the least. Only last night the Opposition's national President did not know who the Opposition leader would be at the next election which is only seven weeks away. That is all confirmed by what Opposition senators are saying here. Let me answer Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's question because she sought to draw certain conclusions from it. Let me just remind her of what was said today in New York about the economic performance of the Government following the May statement.
—They are asking you about that statement.

—The honourable senator should listen. This question was asked of the New York stock market: `What does the market feel about who wins an election?' The answer was: `I think they would very much like to see the current Administration in office for a long time'. Later on it was asked: `What are we likely to see happen to the Australian dollar if there is a change of government?' The answer was: `I would have to say that it would probably be a disaster and I would think you would see a big sell-off of the Australian dollar'. The fact of the matter is that, even as far away as New York, people know the quality of the Opposition in this Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections.

—Mr President, this Question Time is being broadcast and I can hardly be heard answering a question because of the noise from the other side of the chamber. That noise confirms one thing which every Australian knows-that the Opposition in this place is a rabble. That is what all the noise is about.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The Minister will be aware of Opposition statements that the 11 July election will be fought on taxation and other issues. Is the Minister also aware of support from major superannuation funds for the present tax regime on lump sum superannuation payments which, I should say, was introduced by the present Government?
