I ask the Minister: How much revenue is collected by means of that tax on lump sum superannuation payments? What is the policy basis of the support of the superannuation funds themselves for the tax as it exists at present?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of support from a major-in fact, I think the major- superannuation fund in Australia for the lump sum superannuation tax. It was reported in the Adelaide Advertiser of last Saturday, under the heading `AMP slams abolition of lump sum super tax', in these terms:

ANSWER.PARA: Abolition of the tax on lump sum superannuation would not make sense, a spokesman for Australia's largest investor, the AMP Society, said yesterday.

The spokesman in question was a Mr Graham Lewis, the national superannuation manager of the Australian Mutual Provident Society. He said that the society was not prepared to buy the Liberal Party's policy of abolishing the tax unless the Party revealed what taxes would replace it. Mr Lewis is then quoted directly as saying:
The Opposition haven't enunciated a position yet except that they will abolish the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the lump sum tax.

Mr Lewis said that he expected, and did not oppose, increasing taxation of superannuation through the raising of the age at which retirees became eligible for concessional tax treatment. Perhaps this next passage is the most important of all. The report continued:
Superannuation recipients should not be able to `live it up for 10 years and go on the pension', and such `rorts' would not survive in the current budgetary climate or in the long term.
The report went on to say:

He broadly defended the current system, saying it covered about 40 p.c. of the workforce and contained measures which encouraged people to preserve their superannuation rather than spend it. The tax on lump sums was one such measure, and others should be introduced.

I have not read all the report, but I think I have read enough to make it very clear that the manager of, I think, Australia's largest superannuation fund, the AMP, has explicitly endorsed, for all sorts of good reasons, the Government's policy of levying a tax on lump sum superannuation payments. The revenue from the tax in this financial year is expected to be around $85m, and that figure is expected to grow by about $30m each year for as long as 20 or 25 years.

If the lump sum tax were to be abolished, however, the loss to revenue would certainly be very much greater than the present $85m gain. It would be greater for this reason: If any government were silly enough to abolish the lump sum superannuation tax, the green light would have been given to employers to save themselves money by making payments into what would really be phoney superannuation funds, which payments their employees could then draw out at three- or five-year intervals tax free. In other words, what would be called superannuation would in fact be deferred wages paid free of tax. If ever any government were silly enough to abolish the lump sum tax, that is precisely what would happen, and it would happen very rapidly. Fortunately, however, there is negligible prospect of such a government being elected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that today's Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that new car sales during April were 33 per cent lower than they were in the same month last year, the worst result for that month in 20 years? Does the Minister maintain his view that the main reason for this disastrous slump in car sales is that the price of cars is too high? Is he aware that, since the start of his car plan, the price of a Laser has gone up by 53 per cent, a Commodore by 42 per cent and a Falcon by 33 per cent? Why has the Hawke Government pursued economic policies which have depressed living standards by pricing cars out of the reach of many Australian families, a development which in turn threatens the very future of vehicle manufacturing in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer this question slowly, if I may. Shortly after we came into government we made a decision that this society was very uncompetitive in international terms. Accordingly, we deregulated the financial sector and we floated the Australian dollar. The result of floating the Australian dollar--
—You overspent, overtaxed and had a silly wage policy.

—I understand that Senator Chaney has been languishing for many years without the opportunity to answer a question at Question Time, and he will have a great number of more such years ahead of him. That is no reason for interjecting and trying to answer when I am answering. The very floating of the Australian dollar drew attention to the lack of competitiveness, and the fall of the dollar has demonstrated that very much.
—The dollar didn't shift for 13 months. Tell the truth.

—Just a minute. The dollar certainly did not shift when Senator Chaney was in government because, on the admission of his then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, the former Government kept the dollar artificially high in order to keep down inflation. That is the admission of the honourable senator's then Prime Minister. That is what he said about what honourable senators opposite did in government. That did immense damage to Australian industry. Senator Short can nod his head. Noddy's head will fall off in a minute if he nods it too hard. The fact of the matter is that that is what the former Prime Minister said and did.

ANSWER.PARA: To return to Senator Kilgariff's question, a number of consequences flowed from the devaluation of the dollar. Import prices went up; Australian industry was placed in a much more competitive position in terms of exports; the prices of cars went up, particularly imported cars, for the very reason of the change in the exchange rate. The price of imported components in locally manufactured cars went up. The rate of inflation, to which the honourable senator sometimes refers, has never been as high under this Government as it was at the time we came to office as a result of the efforts of the Government of honourable senators opposite. It has never been as high. If we compare government with government, inflation has never been as high under this Government as it was under the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are deliberately misleading. It has never been worse relative to the rest of the world.

—Senator Michael Baume says I have been deliberately misleading. There is nothing misleading about that fact. I know Senator Baume was an adviser to the Government of the time. He probably gave it the sort of advice that he is trying to give me now-useless advice. The fact of the matter is that inflation under this Government has never been as high, in spite of a massive devaluation of the Australian dollar, as it was in the period of the Fraser Government. To return to Senator Kilgariff's specific question on the matter of motor cars, I was asked whether I maintain the view which I put earlier. I maintain the view that the car market has been suppressed in Australia because of two factors: One is increased--
—Button and Keating.

—Mr President, I object to being described as a factor. I maintain the view that the car market in Australia has been depressed for two fundamental reasons. The first reason is the increase in prices consequent upon the devaluation of the dollar, and the second is the success of Government wages polices which have restrained incomes, again in a manner which was never understood by the Fraser Government and never implemented by the Fraser Government. Those two factors produce this result, I confess: That people tend to put off buying motor cars for that reason. That is undoubtedly so.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator then went on to refer to the very difficult situation of the Australian motor vehicle manufacturing industry. I am extremely optimistic and confident about the future of the Australian motor vehicle manufacturing industry. That industry has had enormous levels of investment; productivity is improving immensely; the companies are all very busy at present. The export performance of that industry has improved enormously under this Government, both from the component sector and the vehicle manufacturing sector. If Senator Kilgariff wants any evidence of that, he should not hold his breath for more than a few days. Next year this country will be exporting $300m worth of motor vehicles, something that has not happened since the late 1960s.

So, in terms of the point of Senator Kilgariff's question, yes, I concede that the local vehicle market is depressed. I maintain the same reasons for that having happened as I have given earlier in the Senate, and the conclusion that Senator Kilgariff draws from that fact is entirely erroneous; it is wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is-again-directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to alleged reports on the taxation policy of the Federal Liberal Party as reported in the Melbourne Herald of 26 May? Does the Government intend to adopt any of the policies as proposed and, if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen that report in the Melbourne Herald, which purported to report on the Liberal Party's taxation policy. I understand from some comments that Senator Messner made before the suspension of the sitting for lunch that, in fact, the policy set out in that report is not the taxation policy of the Liberal Party. He is not saying anything now, but I certainly understood him to say before the suspension of the sitting that what was reported in the Herald is not the taxation policy of the Liberal Party-the reason for that being, I presume, that the Liberal Party does not have a taxation policy. It is trying to cut and paste one within the next couple of weeks but at this stage evidently it does not have a tax policy at all.

ANSWER.PARA: If the Liberal Party ever does get around to producing a tax policy, I certainly hope it does not produce a tax policy like the one that was outlined in the Herald last Monday. I say that for a number of reasons, not the least of which is that, on the admission of those who prepared that document, it would cost $5.7 billion in revenue. In addition to that, it would cost about another $1 billion to increase family allowances in the way proposed. That would be on the outlay side of the Budget. So, in total, there would be an increase in the Budget deficit of nearly $7 billion if such a policy were introduced, on top, of course, of all the other commitments the Liberal Party has given that would add to the deficit.

In the absence of specific spending cut proposals, to offset that loss of revenue and increased expenditure would require the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax, which would need to raise net revenue of around $8 billion after removing wholesale sales tax and compensating pensioners. That would require a 12 per cent across-the-board consumption tax, which, of course, would have a huge impact on the consumer price index, an impact of the order of 6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that what Keating proposed?
—Yes, and one of the reasons why the Government did not proceed with that proposal was the very point that I have just made.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The question was very cleverly reworked to bring it within the Standing Orders, and therefore I did not object, but the Minister is now clearly debating the question and he is now dealing with the Labor Party tax policy, which was rejected just after the tax summit-I think in a hotel room just over the lake here-by Mr Hawke, who sat down with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and did not bother to tell his Treasurer or anybody else. My point of order, Mr President, is that the Minister is debating the question. He is dealing with hypothetical matter and I think you ought to draw him to a conclusion and sit him down.

—Order! There is no point of order. The Minister is answering within the area of his responsibility. I would suggest, however, that not a lot of questions have been answered today and we should consider that aspect.

—Yes, I shall, Mr President. I shall conclude shortly, but I think I am entitled to respond to an interjection from Senator Messner. One of the reasons why the Government did not proceed with the broad-based consumption tax is that it would have boosted the consumer price index by 6 1/2 per cent, and no country in the world has ever had a one-off increase in the price level of that magnitude. Some very substantial macroeconomic dangers would have been incurred in any sort of policy that had that effect.

ANSWER.PARA: Last but not least, the reason why the Government would not adopt a tax policy of the type set out in the Melbourne Herald is the simple fact that almost all ordinary Australians would be worse off under such a policy. The effect of the policy, if the revenue lost were to be recovered by way of a consumption tax, would be massively to redistribute the taxation burden away from people on higher incomes towards people on lower incomes. I shall give just a couple of examples. A two-earner family with two children and an income of $30,000 would lose, net, some $23.50 a week. If the same family had a total income of $45,000, it would lose $19.50 a week. But if the income were $100,000 a year, it would be the winner by a net $68 a week. That demonstrates, of course, that the family on a $100,000 income would be a very significant winner under the sort of tax policy that was reported in the Herald, but if that family were on $45,000 or $30,000 dual income-and a lot of households have dual incomes of that size-it would be a substantial loser. If the other proposed revenue losses were incurred-through abolishing the fringe benefits tax and so on-the losses to those sorts of families would be greater again.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Is the Minister aware of a recent study commissioned by the Government supported Business Council of Australia that confirms that Queensland has the lowest level of State taxes in the country-16 per cent below average; that Queensland has consistently spent less than other States in the past 25 years-15 per cent below average; and that, in all, the study concludes that Queensland stands out as the low spending State? Will the Minister agree with the Business Council of Australia's warm praise for Queensland's long and excellent record of responsibility and apologise to the Senate and the people of Queensland for his unjustified smear campaign on the excellent management of Queensland's finances, which has resulted in the fortunate inhabitants of that State enjoying the lowest level of State charges in the country?

—My hearing is imperfect, but I am sure Senator Boswell referred to the `Government supported Business Council of Australia'. I am baffled by the comment, because if the Government pays any subsidies to the Council I am not aware of it. They must be sneaking through the Budget in a way I have not noticed. I am pretty confident that the Government does not pay any subsidies to the Business Council of Australia.
—He meant the Business Council supported the Government.

—I was about to say that. The Business Council-a seminar dinner of which I addressed last night, incidentally-both publicly and via a number of individual members, has supported the bulk of this Government's economic policies because it knows it is a better economic policy than any government in Australia has followed since 1950. That is well appreciated. While I am aware of that, I am not aware of any Business Council analysis of taxation levels in Queensland but I am willing to take Senator Boswell's word for it that such an analysis was done.
—I wouldn't.

—Some people may suggest that I am over-generous in taking Senator Boswell's word, but I am a generous and trusting sort of a chap by nature so I shall do that. I am, however, aware of studies done by the Utah Development Company two or three years ago which calculated that the Queensland Government was levying a hidden tax of $360m a year by overcharging for rail freights on coal and other minerals.
—Mount Isa Mines, too.

—It came to a similar conclusion. In any other State that sort of revenue would be levied by overt taxes. In Queensland it is levied by a covert tax applied by overcharging mining companies on rail freights.
—Just like New South Wales.

—Look Steve, or Patrick, or whatever your name is, if that $360m calculated by Utah-and more recent estimates put the figure at higher than that-is added to the Queensland tax aggregate, which it ought to be, one finds that Queensland is the highest taxing State and not the lowest taxing State.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present its report on metropolitan Canberra, together with the transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a comprehensive report of the metropolitan plan of Canberra, and I commend it to the Senate and hope that it will be read. There are a number of significant recommendations about the future development of Canberra, including a suggestion that the planning and development of Gungahlin should not go ahead according to the timetable that the National Capital Development Commission has previously had, and reasons are given for that. The Committee also recommends that the Department of Defence be relocated from the Belconnen area, Jerrabomberra and Harman Bonshaw, thus releasing valuable residential sites in the Territory. There are a number of other matters, but because we are being pressed for time today I will not deal with them in detail. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement dealing more fully with the recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Committee considers that the major issue underlying this inquiry is that of urban consolidation as opposed to continued expansion of the built-up area. The NCDC has ignored developments resulting from its own planning decisions which have made employment projections and self-containment objectives, as expressed in the metropolitan plan, misleading and inaccurate. In the preface to its report the Committee stresses the importance of developments which have occurred and the consequences of continued urban sprawl and its associated levels of high and increasing infrastructure servicing and social costs.

The Committee, in its report, has suggested ways in which the NCDC and the Department of Territories can improve the present land administration system and, with the benefit of a more comprehensive database, achieve a metropolitan Canberra which can realise the benefits of increasing density in established areas. This will make full use of existing service capacity and also limit, for the time being, further peripheral expansion of the urban area, until this is considered appropriate.

On the basis of available information, the Committee considers that the environmental and social costs of dispersed growth are greater than the costs associated with concentrated development. As a consequence, the Committee recommends that the development of Gungahlin not proceed according to the timetable previously proposed by the NCDC.

The Committee, in its final recommendation, proposes that the NCDC and the Department of Territories implement an urban consolidation strategy with community consultation which seeks to increase residential density in existing suburbs and make detailed information publicly available regarding the costs and benefits of such a strategy.

This strategy will only be successful if the Department of Territories, as the administering authority, and the NCDC work together to achieve the objectives set out in this report. It is expected that high levels of co-operation and improved communication will be achieved along with a better plan for Canberra's future development if recommendations in this report are carried out.

The Committee also considers that a crucial step in overcoming the shortage of critical data on which to base informed planning decisions is the establishment of a land development account. This has been recommended in previous inquiries both by this Committee and other review bodies. It is encouraging that some progress has been made in this direction and the Committee recommends that such an accounting system be established as soon as practicable. This should also allow judgments to be made concerning the costs and benefits of urban consolidation as opposed to further peripheral expansion.

The Committee further recognises that the NCDC's development process is hampered to some extent by a lack of commitment from government for longer term planning initiatives. At present while the Commission conducts assessments on the basis of 12-month and 3-year programs, the lack of certainty regarding continuing commitment to long term construction programs has implications for the private sector in terms of investment potential and maintenance of predictable levels of construction activity in the Australian Capital Territory. The Committee is of the view that a longer time frame for planning would, in the end, result in cost savings, and a more efficient allocation of resources and therefore recommends that the NCDC should be supported in its proposal for longer term planning and programming, particularly for major capital works. Where the Government has agreed to a particular planning initiative which requires the expenditure of funds over a longer period than one financial year, consideration should be given to a 5 year program of commitment.

Another issue related to accountability for planning decisions raised during the inquiry is the present lack of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. The Committee has adopted a de facto role as a major public consultative mechanism in the planning process and is seen as such by residents of the Australian Capital Territory. It therefore recommends that all future policy and development plans prepared by the NCDC be referred to the Committee for its consideration. Thus the Committee can comment on planning initiatives where this is considered appropriate in the public interest.

The Committee recognises the serious nature of traffic and parking problems in and around Civic and to avoid compounding the problem recommends that the Commission and the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services provide greater impetus for the development of other town centres by locating government departments and authorities not already placed in central locations in the new town centres. This has already been addressed in the Committee's report on the 89th series of variations relating to the development of section 38 in Civic and the Committee reiterates its support for an undertaking from the NCDC that a review of the Civic Centre policy plan be completed by June 1987.
Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory

During the inquiry the Committee was alerted to problems concerning the system of land tenure in the Australian Capital Territory and the administration of the leasehold system. The Committee has decided to pursue this by commissioning an independent study of the system.

The Committee was specifically asked in one of its terms of reference to report on the impact of the plan upon the south-east region of New South Wales. Any discussion of regional co-ordination and consultation should include the impact of Canberra's development on the surrounding region of New South Wales and the Committee notes that the recommendation of a report by a joint Commonwealth, State and local government committee in September 1976 that a Commonwealth and South East Region Advisory Committee be set up has not been acted on. The Committee recommends that priority be given to the formation of the organisation proposed in 1976 realising that the need for such a regional body is now becoming acute as problems relating to the expansion of Canberra and its increased population levels are already having greater and greater impact on the region as Canberra continues to expand.

The question of the availability of appropriate land for residential development in the Australian Capital Territory was also raised during the Committee's examination of the metropolitan plan. In investigating the scope for large scale redevelopment, the Committee was made aware of the potential for such redevelopment in areas presently occupied by the Department of Defence such as Belconnen, Jerrabomberra and Harman Bonshaw. The Committee tried to pursue this suggestion by asking for information and co-operation from the Department of Defence.

The Defence Department declined to appear before the Committee and did not respond to subsequent requests for information. The Committee is extremely critical of this lack of co-operation and as no evidence was given to the Committee to justify continued use of the areas by the Defence Department and, because of the high opportunity costs of such continued use, the Committee recommends that the Department relocate from the areas of Belconnen, Jerrabomberra and Harman Bonshaw thus releasing these valuable sites and redressing the high cost in lost opportunity for this land.

Finally, I would like to stress that this is a very important report and the first major public review of the Y plan which has shaped the development of Canberra since 1970. The Committee's report makes recommendations which will influence the future Canberra into the next century and marks another stage in the planning and overall development of Canberra as the national capital. I commend the recommendations to the House.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Construction of Department of Aviation Central Training College, Australian Capital Territory

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, I present the initial report relating to the construction of the Department of Aviation central training college, Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
The proposal referred to the Committee in January this year was for the construction of a Central Training College at Pialligo, Australian Capital Territory for the Department of Aviation.

In April the Minister for Aviation requested the Committee to extend the scope of its inquiry to include an examination of the cheaper alternative of locating the college at Watson High School which will close at the end of 1987.

It is intended to accommodate the Department of Aviation air traffic control, flight services, search and rescue, flight standards, administrative and ADP training schools in the Central Training College. A new air traffic control and flight services simulator is being acquired by the Department for training air traffic control personnel. It is due to be delivered in September 1988 and aviation required completion of the simulator building by that date.
However, the Department of Housing and Construction has advised that the earliest a simulator building can be completed at Watson High School is November 1988.
At present air traffic control, flight services and flight standards training is carried out in Melbourne. The other three schools are located in leased premises in Canberra.
The Department of Aviation submitted that there would be advantages in co-locating all training schools in Canberra.

Whilst Aviation's future responsibilities are unclear due to the establishment of the Civil Aviation Corporation, there will be a continuing requirement for specialist air traffic control personnel to be trained.

Accordingly, the Committee recommended that the air traffic control and flight service schools should be relocated to Canberra and co-located in the one complex with the other training schools already here.

The Watson High School buildings are basically sound, although it will be necessary to construct a new building to house the simulator because none of the existing buildings are considered suitable for that purpose.

The limit of cost estimate for the Pialligo proposal is $11.2m. Indicative costs for the Watson High School are $9.115m. Both costs include the provision of a simulator building at $2.45m. The indicative costs for the Watson High School proposal are based on achievement as closely as practicable of the requirements on which the Pialligo design was based. Cost reductions could be achieved if the Department of Aviation alters its briefing requirements.

The Committee accordingly agrees to the conversion of Watson High School provided that significant reductions in costs are achieved resulting from the Department of Aviation re-examining the scope of its briefing requirements.
The Committee will hold a further public hearing to examine the limit of cost estimate for the conversion of Watson High School.

In conclusion, I would like to address a number of matters relating to the reference about which the Committee is not entirely happy. They relate to timing and the consequential urgency attached to the examination of what was a most complex subject.

The Committee believes that the requirement for the continued training of air traffic control personnel, the arrival of the simulator in September 1988, the time taken by the Location of Australian Government Employment Committee to examine the proposal and the need for the Public Works Committee to consider the Watson High School proposal after the work had been referred placed considerable time constraints on the Committee and have given it very little option but to agree to the work proceeding.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1986-87[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (NO. 3) 1986-87APPROPRIATION BILL (NO. 4) 1986-87SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL1987-88SUPPLY BILL (NO. 1) 1987-88SUPPLY BILL (NO. 2) 1987-88]

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before this debate was interrupted earlier, I was saying that it was evident that the Government had something to hide by having this election before it had brought down its Budget in August. That explains, of course, why the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has once again broken his word. The question of what the Government has to hide extends, however, into the specifics of the Senate Estimates committees where, in fact, undertakings have been broken by Ministers of the Crown, in particular the Minister for Territories, Mr Scholes. Senator Gietzelt, on behalf of Mr Scholes, accepted that questions would be put on notice in order to expedite the hearings of the Committee but then refused to answer those questions in blatant and clear contempt of this Senate. It is a disgrace that an arrangement made simply to facilitate the proceedings and to assist the Minister has resulted in senators' questions raised at Senate Estimates Committee E not being answered, and the Government has no intention to answer them.

SPEECH.PARA: In a letter to Senate Estimates Committee E, Mr Scholes states:
. . . I have instructed my Department not to commit the resources necessary to answer the outstanding questions and would ask that you advise the Committee of my views . . .

The reason, he said, was that something like 1,000 questions altogether were asked at his Department's hearing. I understand Senator Vigor will have something to say on that because, no doubt, a large proportion of those questions were Senator Vigor's. However, the fact remains that at the request of the Minister questions were not pursued at those hearings and we were then sold down the river, just as the Australian people are continually sold down the river by accepting in good faith false promises by this Government.

Let us look at exactly what they were trying to hide and why the decision was taken, because that is what it is really all about. Mr Scholes' decision not to provide answers was in order simply to avoid the embarrassment of revealing what the Parliament House Construction Authority, for example, had said it was prepared to reveal. Details it was prepared to reveal would be of great embarrassment to it and to this Government because of the massive waste and misallocation of resources, and the massive incompetence that has been demonstrated from the level of government itself down through the structure at the new Parliament House site. At the Senate Estimates Committee I asked a whole series of questions, to which I was assured I would have answers but which officers did not have answers to at the time. They said there was nothing sinister about not having them there, that there were not secret reports. However, we now have the situation where the information is being denied us. This is a scandal.

The Waste Watch Committee already demonstrated in January this year that something like $200m of cost overruns have taken place on that project as a result of unexplained and apparently indefensible cost rises. At a previous Senate Estimates Committee hearing we established that there were something like 47 major contracts where the cost overruns were more than 25 per cent over the tender price, and this was in addition to those overruns that were due to escalation clauses in the contracts which allowed for inflation and other cost rises and which excluded any increase in the scope of the contract. Here was a situation whereby we had already established that 47 of the major contracts had had these massive and unexplained overruns. The new Parliament House Construction Authority felt under no obligation to explain them in its annual report or to the Senate Estimates Committee. Therefore, naturally, I pursued the matter at the recent Senate Estimates Committee hearings, which hearings resulted in the reports with which we are now dealing in the Appropriation Bills. I naturally asked what the present situation was with such cost overruns. I asked whether the new Parliament House Construction Authority would please correct its figures to take account of the fact that there are 5,000 unsettled claims for extra expenditure on work that has already been done. These 5,000 outstanding claims had not been settled and had not been taken into account when the new Parliament House Construction Authority said to me that 47 major contracts had overrun by more than 25 per cent. I want the truth from the new Parliament House Construction Authority; I want honesty from the Government. I do not want the Minister to instruct the Senate Estimates Committee that he will not commit the resources necessary to answer the outstanding questions, particularly in situations where the effort involved in getting this information should be minimal. Yet, here is a deliberate and determined policy of covering up. What does the Government have to hide?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is scandalous.

—As Senator Vigor says, it is absolutely scandalous. It is the biggest project that has ever been undertaken in the national capital; there is clear evidence of $200m of waste, and yet the Government will not answer simple questions put to it during the Senate Estimates committees-as senators have a right to do. This involves an arrogant Minister in an arrogant government, which claims to support the concept of open government but which has sought wherever it can to close the door, particularly to the Waste Watch Committee because it kept on evidencing disgraceful and indefensible government waste. During the Senate Estimates Committee hearing I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: How many major contracts now exceed their contract price by 25 per cent in money terms, after account is taken of scope variations and additional costs due to the normal cost rises?
However, the Government had considered that it was not worth while to prepare itself for such a question, and the response to my question was:
I cannot answer that question offhand. We would be happy to take it on notice and provide the information for you.

That was the response-that the new Parliament House Construction Authority was happy to take that question on notice and happy to make the information available to us. But the Minister was not happy to do that. The Minister said: `No you won't'. The Minister has something to hide. I asked whether the claims could be separated out and whether the amount by which costs exceeded 25 per cent could be provided as a proportion of those that were able to be assessed. I was making the point that it was not possible to assess many of these contracts because they had not yet been finalised; the claims had been resolved. The response was that, yes, they would separate them out for me, so that, out of the total contracts, the proportion of those in relation to which costs had exceeded 25 per cent would not simply be in relation to all the contracts, as many of them were open to doubt, but in relation to only those that had in fact been settled. The answer was: `Yes, certainly we can do that'. The new Parliament House Construction Authority was prepared, apparently, to provide the information. However, the Minister vetoed it. I then asked:

It would be self-evident, would it not, that there are many contracts, of a major nature even, where the lack of the processing of these 5,000 cost variations would in fact have significantly affected the number of major contracts that had been overspent by 25 per cent?
Mr Peatey, Senior Executive Officer, Administration and Finance of the Parliament House Construction Authority, said:
That is possible. Yes, I think that the answer to that will emerge in the information which we will provide to you.

I then asked about the details of a cost control report, or a report on the lack of cost control in relation to the new and permanent Parliament House, a matter that I had revealed from the Waste Watch Committee's exposure of the multi-millions of dollars of waste at the new Parliament House. I asked whether this report could be provided to the Senate Estimates Committee. After all, I understand that the report was highly critical of the management of the new Parliament House. I had not seen the report in detail; I had been told by people on the site of the thrust of the report, as many people up there, many good people up there, have been very concerned about what is happening. I had been told basically what was in the report but I had not actually had the report. I asked during the Estimates Committee proceedings:
Could the details of the McCain report-its recommendations and, alongside it, what has been achieved-possibly be given to the Committee so that we will have a view of it? You-
this is a question to Mr Peatey, the Senior Executive Officer-
mentioned that most of the matters raised by McCain had been met. Is the report so confidential that it would be wrong to release it?
In response, Mr Peatey said:

The report is not a secret report or a confidential report in that sense. It was a report commissioned for the use of the Authority in setting up this cost control and action group, but it is not a secret report.

So I then asked whether we could have it, and Mr Peatey said yes. The Senior Executive Officer of the Parliament House Construction Authority was apparently prepared to release this report that he claimed was not secret. I wonder who told him that he could not do that. As Senator Vigor says, the Minister refused the Senior Executive Officer the right to release that report. Why is the Government intervening in this way? I pointed out to the Senate Estimates Committee some ludicrous examples of contracts that had run over budget. For example, one of the plumbing contracts for the new Parliament House was tendered for at $2m but I understand that as at the end of March it was up to over $6m and had still not been completed. That was called a suspended hydraulics contract. I asked Mr Peatey about this and about another contract. I asked him for details about how these contracts for suspended hydraulics had gone, to which Mr Peatey responded:
Again, I cannot give you financial details, but they can be provided.

Mr Peatey was prepared to tell us by how much those contracts had overrun, but the Minister, in this secretive Government, would not tell us. This sort of thing is just intolerable. It is made more intolerable by the fact that Mr Gordon Peatey engaged in, if you like, a very strong set of disagreements with me when I released the January report of the Waste Watch Committee, exposing what had gone on in relation to the new Parliament House, in relation to which he said that I was wrong, that there were factual errors and that in fact everything was very fine up there. Anyone who listened to those broadcasts would have heard the way in which he was dismissive of the details and the factual material presented by the Waste Watch Committee. During the Senate Estimates Committee hearing I said that, as Mr Peatey was critical of what he described as factual or non-factual comments in my claims about cost rises, I wondered whether he would take on notice a question in relation to outlining where those inaccuracies could be identified. Mr Peatey replied: `We will take that on notice'. However, in fact, Mr Peatey cannot outline where the inaccuracies are, because there were no inaccuracies, and the Minister has again come to his defence in relation to banning the revelation of any material from the Parliament House Construction Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is dishonest.
—It is totally dishonest-a dishonest Minister in a dishonest government covering up a multi-million dollar scandal.
—In the United States they would have a Watergate inquiry.

—Senator Vigor is absolutely correct. In a matter of this significance a Minister is deliberately covering up a scandalous waste of money, refusing to stick by an agreement and protecting an authority which clearly has got itself into trouble by overspending and making grievous errors, many of which were prompted by the Government. Mr Scholes refused to answer questions which had been agreed by Senator Gietzelt and the officers who were there would be answered. Not only was that contemptuous to the Senate and destructive of the Senate Estimates Committee but also it represents, I believe, a degree of deception by this Government, which is intolerable. This leads me to a real questioning of the integrity of the Senate Estimates committees as to how a Minister can behave in this intolerable way. The Senate Estimates committees provide one of the few opportunities that honourable senators get of probing into those matters of government administration which are properly their right to examine.
—Our duty.

—Our duty, as Senator Vigor says. The contemptible and contemptuous approach of this Government to these committees has put them at a degree of risk. As it is, every honourable senator would agree that the manner in which the Government handled the Senate Estimates committee hearings this year was a total disgrace. We were given detailed information a couple of days before the hearings started. We were supposed to have understood and then based coherent questions on that material in a very short time. In other words, from the beginning of these Senate Estimates committee hearings there was a clear, deliberate and determined policy of this Government of limiting the effectiveness of honourable senators in those Estimates committees by not giving them access to information, not giving them adequate time and continually changing the times of meetings of those committees so that we did not know what sort of preparation we could do. There was a total shambles.
—Was it dishonesty or incompetence?

—One could be kind and say that it was incompetence. I believe the pattern of behaviour, particularly that established in Senate Estimates Committee E where the Minister refused to stand by the undertaking made by the Government, represents dishonesty. This whole pattern was an attack on the rights--
—I rise on a point of order. Senator Baume has called a Minister dishonest, and I think that is against Standing Orders.

—It is a very marginal case. I think Senator Baume said that the pattern of behaviour represented dishonesty. It might help the proceedings if the honourable senator were to withdraw that and then continue with his speech.

—I withdraw it. The facts speak for themselves. They show a pattern of behaviour which is totally unacceptable to any civilised, decent community. It may be acceptable to Senator Reynolds, but I find it intolerable that Ministers or a government should behave in this way. In these latest Senate Estimates committee hearings we had a clear example of an attempt by a government, which has an immense amount to hide, to seek to hide it. That fits in with the same pattern of behaviour that we see by a Prime Minister who seeks to hide what will be in his Budget by having an election before the Budget is brought down.

SPEECH.PARA: This leads one to another clear issue of this Government of deception seeking to hide facts. The Waste Watch Committee revealed enormous amounts of disgraceful expenditure and waste, particularly for example in relation to the community employment program which the Government has now decided to abandon. Yet, as I have complained to the Senate, there was a deliberate and determined pattern of refusing to allow the Opposition access to information-public information, in many instances-about the grants made under CEP. In the end, after a great deal of toing and froing, the Government agreed that it would provide the Opposition with a computer printout of CEP grants provided that the Opposition paid $400 to the Government for the provision of that information which should be readily available to the Opposition because it is in the public interest for the people of Australia to know the manner in which its tax money was being wasted by this Government, the manner in which long term unemployment money was being redirected into purchasing assets, such as vans for various strange groups-fringe groups-typewriters for the socialist workers party fronts and radio broadcasting equipment for a community radio station in Victoria which did not have a licence and which had never broadcast. The station said that it needed this equipment because it wanted to train three long term unemployed people for three or four months. The Government bought it a console, a turntable, a record player and tape recorders in order to give training. This radio station did not have a licence and did not broadcast, but it was going to train people with this equipment. The Government said that it would buy it for it out of the long term unemployment funds. What happened to the equipment when the program ended after three or four months? It remained the asset of the community broadcasting station in Victoria.

That sort of thing was spread far and wide throughout the CEP. This Government set out deliberately to block my access to that sort of information by refusing to provide me with details of CEP grants unless I was prepared to pay $400. I believe it is an absolute disgrace and part of a pattern which is manifested in these Estimates committees. I remind the Senate that it was the Waste Watch Committee which revealed waste over an enormous area. It was so effective that the Government appointed a damage control committee made up of Senator Walsh, Mr Mick Young and Mr Cohen. It set out also on a pattern of withholding information. The Australia Council which had previously put out its own list of grants every three or four months now does not do so. We have to wait until the annual report comes out eventually at the end of the year-usually well after the end of the year-and then have to look through the pages at the back of it. The Government is reducing the amount of information that was available to it because it is aware of how vulnerable it is. It is expert at hiding embarrassing material. What is happening now is another example of its attempt to hide, by having an election before the coming Budget, the next round of attacks that it will make on the Australian people, particularly those who are least able to protect themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This cognate debate on the Appropriation and Supply Bills allows honourable senators a deal of latitude to range over issues that are of concern to them, their electorates or their constituencies. This afternoon I want to direct some comment to the phenomenon which has arisen on the Australian political and industrial scene in the past 12 months to two years and which is known colloquially as the New Right. I want to examine some of the mutilations that it has engaged in to date and also particularly one of the societies that it uses most of all to promulgate the material and the work that it seeks to do to fulfil the aims of its organisation. I refer particularly to the H. R. Nicholls Society. I want to say something about the mutilation of that individual's name and how it has been misused by those involved in the H. R. Nicholls Society. I want to talk also of the growing confidence of the business community in the work of the Hawke Labor Government and why the business community will more likely than not direct support in the forthcoming election to the re-election of that Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The H. R. Nicholls Society is to meet next at Mooloolaba in Queensland from 6 to 8 June. Luminaries who are set to cast an eerie light on the hill-I want to say a little more about that later-include, in no particular order of merit, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen; Mr John Stone, who is temporarily working for Sir Joh; the Hon. Lindsay Thompson of Victoria; Mr Hugh Morgan of Western Mining Corporation; and Mr Charles Copeman-we will not forget him-from Robe River. The Hon. Neil Brown has been named but I understand that Senator Fred Chaney will go instead. Mr Paul Houlihan and Mr Wayne Gilbert will also address the meeting. From this place, Senator Peter Walsh and Senator Fred Chaney may be in attendance, unless election demands make their appearances elsewhere of more importance. I have every confidence that Senator Walsh, should he attend, will put forward his usual persuasive arguments and that he will not be forced to resort to carrying garlic cloves about his person or perhaps even a vampire stake in his suitcase as the clean living heroes in horror movies sometimes have to do. Doubtless, Senator Chaney will feel quite at home in Mooloolaba. Senator Chaney will be happy there because the Opposition draws most of its ideas on industrial relations from the New Right groups such as the H. R Nicholls Society. These people will be temporarily accommodated in Queensland, the pineapple State, for this meeting. I have to put on public record my commendation of Senator Walsh and his bravery. I publicly express the hope that he does not return to this Senate chamber smeared with some kind of snake oil or other potions that might be used there.

One of the more ghoulish acts of members of this society so far is to name themselves after the hapless Harry Richard Nicholls who in his dotage at the age of 81 became a reactionary newspaper editor. A contempt of court charge was laid by the Attorney-General against Nicholls in 1911. The case was heard in the High Court of Australia and it became more of an apologies, forgive and forget event than the present New Right advocates would have us believe. The H. R. Nicholls Society has been most selective in what it claims the man Nicholls believed in. It would be quite possible for a left wing or even a new left H. R. Nicholls Society to be formed. Nicholls, in his prime, can be quoted as saying that the workers:

. . . are here to found a great and glorious nation, by their labour, intelligence and virtue; not to toil, like the millions in the old countries for the aggrandisement and glorification of the comparative few, whom chance for the present has made masters of their destinies. No! Rulers and capitalists here must not be the masters of the people . . .

If Sir Joh, John Stone or others were going along to support the beliefs of the radical young Nicholls who fiercely defended the rights of the diggers in the Victorian gold-fields in the 1850s, what a wonderful change would come over Australian politics. As the words of the old saying go, pigs might fly. I regret that the greedy and reactionary will always be with us.

Before I turn to the second theme which I wish to address, I will first comment about the title of the H. R. Nicholls Society conference which will be held in June. The Society has called this conference the `light on the hill'. In the same way as it is abusing H. R. Nicholls's name, it is abusing a famous motto that is proudly borne by those of us in the Australian Labor Party. We see the light on the hill as something to aim for. In the words of former leaders of the Party, it will provide benefits for those people who are not as fortunate as others. It is unfortunate and regrettable that the H. R. Nicholls Society and those involved in it cannot think up their own themes in support of their greed and avarice.

The second theme I wish to address in my short contribution to this debate is the wide acceptance in the business community of this Government's management of the economy. The May mini-Budget has been an exercise in economic management which has been widely welcomed by the business community and the Australian public in general. This Government has demonstrated not only in the May economic statement but also in previous economic action that it is in touch with the true needs of Australia. In turn the Australian community has responded by demonstrating that it has the maturity to look beyond the solutions offered by the quick fix merchants among the disorganised ranks of the Opposition, beyond the fanaticism of the New Right advocates, and that it is ready and eager to look reality squarely in the eye and to accept that our ability to survive internationally as a nation is built around an effort by all Australians. At this stage in our economic existence we cannot afford the doubtful luxury of indulging in the type of internal political and economic strife which the divided Opposition and the New Right would dump us in.

The recipes which the New Right and the Opposition want to cook up for Australians seem to me to guarantee a dreadful case of national food poisoning in a very short time. Their recipes boil down to a few unpalatable ingredients. They would hammer the trade union movement, those organisations which are the only protection working people would have in the unlikely event of a reactionary ultra-conservative government being elected anywhere in Australia, perhaps with the exception of Queensland. They would hammer the unions and attack the working class through massive doctrinaire and totally unnecessary cuts in government spending. But they would make sure that the rich would get richer while making sure that their few remaining cronies were okay. I use the phrase `few remaining cronies' advisedly, for I can assure the Opposition that it has run out of cronies. Many of those opposite know that the writing is on the wall. It is on the wall for John Howard and for Sir Joh's Canberra power lust. I will not bother to mention `Sinkers'. For those that can see the wall, the writing was on the wall last Monday, 25 May, in the Australian Financial Review. This is the kind of cold comfort it served up to the Opposition:

As things stand, the response to the mini-Budget has been good, the Prime Minister is gaining in popularity, is confident and appears in control, and community sentiment on the state of the economy is healthy.
The article continues:
The Opposition on the other hand, is conspicuously divided. The coalition has dissolved, but more importantly, there is civil war within each party.
The Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, is electorally unpopular and is struggling to maintain control of his party.
It continues:

His tactical judgments have been poor. He has been successfully depicted as an extremist by the articulate `wets' within his party-a devastating criticism for a political leader in a nation that seeks out the middle ground.

That was the front page story of the Australian Financial Review-a newspaper that business people read-of last Monday. The editorial in the same edition was even more damning. It published the latest Business Review Weekly Hyatt business poll which showed that out of 180 chief executives from the nation's biggest companies, almost 56 per cent regarded the Government's performance as quite good or very good, while 94 per cent said that the Opposition was bad or indifferent.

Senator Messner, in his earlier comments, made great play about a recent poll-he did not give the source-in which 70 per cent of the people polled stated that they wanted a reduction in union power. If Senator Messner is to be influenced by polls he ought to look at the Business Review Weekly Hyatt poll which stated that 94 per cent of the people polled thought that the Opposition was bad or indifferent. I wonder what the late Sir Robert Menzies would have said about that. I doubt whether Menzies ever envisaged a situation in which the Liberal Party was getting such marks from the business community. But there we have it; the business community is almost unanimous in its view that John Howard and the Liberals are bad or indifferent. These are changed times indeed.

The heartland of the Opposition's support base is telling the Liberal and National parties something that they have never heard before, although I am not so sure about that because we on this side of the Senate have been saying this quite consistently for some time. Unfortunately, it takes some business leaders time to wake up. Hopefully, they are waking up. The business leaders and newspapers are also saying that the Labor Party is a party of consensus, the party that has been able to pick up the aspirations of every significant sector of Australian society. John `Rambo' Howard has few mates in the New Right but he has lost touch with the legitimate needs and demands of centre Australia. The main demand is that all sectors of our society must work together for the future of Australia.

We on this side of the chamber have waited for some coherence to come into the Opposition but we have waited in vain. The Opposition has tried Andrew Peacock; it is trying John Howard. John Elliott cannot get himself pre-selected; Ian McLachlan cannot make up his mind. Maybe another three years of introspection on the Opposition benches will improve them. At the moment this looks to be an extremely doubtful prospect. I suspect that 13 years will be needed to achieve such a major task. Thirteen years might be a fairer reflection of the disparity in the performance between this Government and the petty pretenders opposite. Who will lick the Opposition into shape when not only its leaders but also its possible leaders have been murdered? They are too weak, too inexperienced, some would say too conservative, to tackle such a major political task.

The Australian public will be the ones who will lick the Opposition into shape, and if they cannot lick it they will kick it into shape, at the next election, which is only just over six weeks away. That will be done at not only the next election but also the one after because there is no light on the hill being shone by those on the Opposition benches at the moment. The Australian people will keep the Opposition in the cooler for a long time, until it develops some compassion for the people of Australia, the ordinary people who make this country tick. The Opposition has flirted with the New Right extremists for too long. It has even got into bed with them. The people of Australia know what it has been doing and they are not about to commit national suicide by electing it. They know that this Government is in touch with the national desire of the major segments of Australian society so that we can have a successful economic future. The bulk of Australians are not about to be led up the New Right garden path. Australia may have a lot of sheep but it is real people who use the ballot box.

Senator Messner mentioned a deal that this Government had allegedly done with the Australian Democrats. He will wait with bated breath until their position on preferences is published in the very near future. I say to Senator Messner that we on this side of the chamber will also wait. I am not sure whether any assurances have been given or whether, if they have been given, they would be stuck to. These matters are fluid and change with time, as those who know Democrat senators would know.

TALK.START.PARA: —We go to our members.

—I do not reflect at all on Senator Vigor. I think the Democrats will have some difficulties in determining preferences. Previously they have been able to determine between what they used to call the socialists and the conservatives-Labor on one side and the Liberals on the other. They could give preferences to both parties by turning over the cards. When one has gone to a polling booth in the past, one has been given a Democrat how to vote card which states `Vote 1 Democrat-2 Labor' on one side and, on the other, `Vote 1 Democrat-2 conservative'. However, the Democrats will not be able to do that this time because they will need a seven- or eight-sided how to vote card. On this occasion they will have to choose between not only Labor and Liberal but also Labor and National. It is not even as simple as that because they will have to choose between the new Nationals-the Joh Nationals-and the traditional Nationals. Which Liberals can we vote for? There are the wets and the dries. There will be a number of other parties as well. Fortunately, the Alliance Party and the Workers Party will not be running candidates on this occasion. I sympathise with the Democrats, having to make such a choice, but it is a relatively simple choice to have to make when they examine the various groupings that make up the conservative parties in Australia today. It is a reflection on them and their leaders that they cannot even get agreement or unanimity.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that used to upset me most-I am not as thin skinned as most honourable senators-when I first became a senator was various senators from time to time talking about the Hawke socialist Government. At this very time people from the Liberal Party in Western Australia are talking about the Liberal socialist party. Even today's West Australia has an article headed `Socialist control of Lib. Party denied'. That article quotes a Mrs Rita Waters, a candidate in the last election-I do not know whether she is running this time-and she complained that the former State secretary of the Liberal Party, Mr Chilla Porter, had a case of sour grapes when he claimed at a dinner in his honour last Saturday night that the party had been dominated in recent years by the wets, by Trotsky socialists, more socialistic than the Liberals. That is a reflection on the conservative forces in the Liberal Party and most certainly on the leadership of the Liberal Party.

Before I sit down I make the following disclaimer: The Liberal Party in Western Australia is led by a gentleman by the name of Barry MacKinnon, and that is unfortunate because I have the problem of having to redirect Mr MacKinnon's mail to him because our names are so similar. I take every effort to make sure that people know my name and my address. I wish he would do the same thing so that people do not get me confused with him. There is no glory at all in my getting mail addressed to the leader of such a divided party back in my home State of Western Australia. I commend the Government's economic record to all Australians. It is proven and has set us on the path to recovery and it is a record that the Australian people will examine closely and thoroughly on 11 July. I am sure that after that examination they will fulfil the words of the leader of my Party, the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, that we will be returned to office, and not only will we be returned but with an even greater majority than we have this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the final days of this dying Government it is appropriate to start off this small dissertation on the Appropriation Bills by making a few relevant comments on the conduct of those opposite during their period in office.
—It will be the first time since you have been here that you have made relevant comments. It will be very refreshing.

—It might be a reflection on Senator Button's standard of consciousness that with an election coming along he has probably woken up for the first time in quite a long while. We have just been subjected to about 20 minutes of rambling by Senator McKiernan. His speeches are always devoted to worrying about imagined problems in the Liberal Party. We have enough people here to worry about our problems. The problems he faces in losing office after the next election are of such a magnitude that he should try to concentrate his mind as well as the mind of Senator Button-which is infinitely better than his-on dealing with them. I have been involved in Australian politics for decades longer than has Senator McKiernan. It is the hoary old cliche of the Australian Labor Party that the Liberal Party is the party of big business. The honourable senator has discovered in the last couple of days big business does not claim the Liberal Party. I congratulate him. That has been a fact of life since Federation because the Liberal Party represents the ordinary caring Australian who wants to raise a family, develop his career and indulge in the good and constructive things of life.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to return to some comments about the conduct of this Government because the acts that we have seen in the last few months are hardly the acts of a responsible government. Government is concerned with the exercise of power. It is also concerned with a responsible accounting for the raising of money from taxpayers and citizens. There is no more valid touchstone of the way a government handles its sense of responsibility than the way it is prepared to stand up and be counted for the way it has handled other people's money. By that test this Government is dishonest. The Estimates committees which are supposed to provide the Parliament-or one of the parliamentary chambers, the Senate-with accountability for how the money is proposed to be spent and how money has been spent in the immediate past were just a joke this time. Questions were put on notice and Ministers arrogantly refused to answer those questions on notice. Ministers obstructed their officers from answering relevant questions. I come to the other avenue of accountability, the Appropriation Bills. We find that the Government with those blackguard prostitutes of the political scene, the Australian Democrats, combined to guillotine the legislation so that we cannot examine what is going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't vote for it.

—I overlooked Senator Vigor. He did have the integrity to do the right, proper and correct thing. I apologise to him for inferentially including him. The committee system, which again enables ordinary members of the Senate and the House of Representatives to inquire into what is going on in the executive government, has become a joke under this Labor Party. Nothing more graphically illustrates, after four years in office, the inevitable trends back to the totalitarian system that is the end point of all Labor governments once they get wound up.

SPEECH.PARA: I go back to the time long before Senator McKiernan came to this country, when I was a small child. I can remember the cartoons in the Chifley and Curtin years of people with jackboots on and swastikas on their arms. The caricatures and cartoons represented the various Ministers of the Labor government of the time because people then lacked freedom. We had rationing, controls and restrictions on what we did. It all ended in 1949 with the Labor Party being thrown out of office for a generation or two. That is the situation we have reached today because we have reached the end of this Whitlam-Hawke Labor dynasty.

The party is over. Australia is left with a huge debt. This is the biggest spending, biggest borrowing government we have seen in our history. It borrows to cover the huge debt it got us into. It is the biggest taxing government ever. The Australian dollar under this Administration is at the lowest value it has ever been on foreign exchanges. We have the highest interest rates ever with home loans at around the 16 per cent mark-if people can get them. Bankcard, which most people use as currency, is at 23 per cent. Small overdrafts are at 21 per cent. We have a huge debt of $105,000m at December 1986, which has grown from $30 billion when this Government came to power. That is $26,000 that every Australian family owes and will be paying off for generations to come. We have the worst inflation rate compared with our Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development partners that we have ever had. It is four times higher.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the change to the policy.

—I say to Senator Button that it is no wonder that his industrial portfolio is in tatters. We cannot sell anything overseas because our inflation rate is four times that of our trading partners. We have the largest current account deficit we have ever had at 6 per cent of our gross domestic product. While the other things that I have mentioned are difficult and unpleasant and bite at everyone's hip pocket, the crucial problem is the current account deficit. We are living beyond our means in a grandiose way like drunken sailors. Is it any wonder in that environment that we have lost our AAA credit rating. This Hawke socialist Government that Senator McKiernan was prattling about before has lost the first AAA credit rating of Australia-to the Government's eternal shame. While Senator Button is reading the paper he might look at today's Courier-Mail. What struck my eye a few minutes ago when I left the chamber to get the paper is a heading on the front page `New-vehicle registrations lowest for 20 years'. What a credit that is to Senator Button's motor industry reconstruction policy. I would like to take a minute to quote from this article. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The motor industry is at crisis point, with April registration figures the worst in more than 20 years.
The figures, released yesterday by motor industry statistician IDAPS Australia Ltd, show vehicle registrations for the year are down 36,949.
Sales of cars and commercial vehicles in the year to date total 140,204, compared with 177,153 for the same time 12 months ago.

Motor vehicle sales are down because of the huge increase in costs that has come about under the industrial and economic policies of this Government and because people no longer have disposable incomes to buy them. That is some economic management that we have had.

Closing this part of the speech I just say that the number of long term unemployed is higher than ever in our history. In March 1983 when the Labor Party came in there were 159,000. In February this year they numbered 193,000, a lift of over 20,000 in the number of long term unemployed Australians who want jobs but cannot get them because of the economic policies of this Government. The Australian people are going to judge this Government in a few weeks. The Liberal Party is going to win that election. The Labor Party has run out of coupons as far as the Australian electorate is concerned. The one thing that every Australian understands is not the complexity of the economic argument or the other failings of the Government but that every Australian's standard of living has gone down-except for a few of the Labor Party's cronies in the media and big business world who fete government members and increase or double their wealth every year under a Labor government. But the ordinary Australian trying to eke out a living in this country knows that, for the first time in his life and since the four years of Labor, his standard of living has declined. He will have his revenge and his opportunity to correct that when the election is held on 11 July.

All this has been quite unnecessary. The Australian Labor Party has misrepresented the situation and it has said that it is due to overseas terms of trade, the low commodity prices for sugar, beef and everything else that we are trying to sell. We have had low commodity prices in the past. It is a function of life. Commodity prices are cyclical; they go up and they come down. But never before have we had the collapse in our standards of living that we have had under this Government.

Those are some of the failings of this Government within Australia. But just as this Government has created problems within, it has certainly created a lot of problems without. We now live in a region which is characterised by unpredictability and instability. We have active Libyan involvement pushing a terrorist pattern of behaviour in the region, we had the coup in Fiji last week, we have the Philippines and, above all, we have the Soviet penetration in the area. There has never been a time when Australia has had to look more carefully at its defence preparedness. But what has this Government done? It has done nothing but reduce the defence vote and Australia's level of defence preparedness. As the Fiji coup demonstrated, the need for defence and the need for intelligence, so that we know what is going on, are always there. It can be summed up in two words: `Be prepared'. This Government is not prepared to cope with any changes outside Australia.

If we look at the Fijian coup the one thing that stands out very clearly is that under this Government the Department of Foreign Affairs is not up to snuff. It did not know about the military coup until it had actually happened. It is the purpose of the Foreign Affairs Department to be able to supply intelligence as to what is going on in this region. But in recent times the Foreign Affairs Department has strenuously resisted employing the specialists in the intelligence gathering field that it should have. It prefers to do this itself. It thinks that it can do this over cocktails on the cocktail circuit, when really we have to get out into the market-place and on the highways and byways and talk to people if we want to know what is going on in the region.

But this fits in with this Government's low priorities for the South Pacific region. Coupled with this is the tendency that has been established in this Government's four years in office. I am glad that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, is in the chamber because he had a crack at me earlier in the day about wanting to spend more money on defence. I will show him the way he has run down the funding of the Australian defence forces in the four years that this Government has been in power. We have been faced with more and more cuts until we have now reached the stage where we have the highest level of resignations from the armed services that we have ever had. People will not stay in the Services because they see no point in serving the country when they cannot be paid ad- equately, when their conditions of service are deteriorating day by day, and when they are denied the opportunity to train to defend the country, which is what they joined the Services to do. They do not get the operational training that they need to get job satisfaction.

The facts are that equipment costs have gone up a lot in recent years. They have gone up at a much higher rate than inflation. We need to have modern equipment in Australia because of our population and our geography. We need to maximise technological resources to defend this country. The Liberal Party of Australia foresaw this when it was in government, when Senator Sir John Carrick was a Minister, and it made an intelligent and appropriate response. In 1982-83, the last year of the Fraser Government, the defence vote committed 17.4 per cent of its expenditure to new capital equipment. The projections from the Fraser Government were that by 1984-85 that 17.4 per cent would rise to 25.9 per cent and it was estimated that that would rise almost to 30 per cent through the latter part of the 1980s. Nearly 30 per cent of the defence vote would be going on new capital equipment and new buildings. If expenditure has gone from 17.4 per cent and has nearly doubled to 30 per cent, unless the aggregate goes up there will be a pinch in some areas. There will be less training, poorer conditions of service, no war stores will be bought and all the other things that the Services need to do will not be done.

To cope with this foreseen situation the Fraser Government, in its final year of office, set out in its five-year defence plan to achieve a 6.3 per cent real growth in defence expenditure for 1982-83 through to 1986-87. What did the Hawke Government do? When the Hawke Government came into office, no doubt under the guidance of the Treasurer, Mr Keating, and various other luminaries in that cabinet, its first act was to cut the 6.3 per cent agreed five-year defence plan vote to 4.5 per cent. Not content with that, in May 1985 it cut it back to 3.1 per cent-a figure, I might say, that it never attained. We then had the May statement which was delivered a couple of weeks ago, where instead of maintaining the 3.1 per cent growth in real terms of the next five-year defence plan, the Government cut it back to a negative growth of one per cent for the next financial year, and this was presented as a saving of $350m. This Government is proposing to have a one per cent real increase in 1988-89 and a 2 per cent increase for the 1989-90 fiscal year, and it will claim that it has made a saving of $1,400m.

It happens to be a fact of life that the way things are at present the barest level of real growth the defence forces can have to stay precisely where they are today is a 3 per cent growth in real terms. So the Australian defence forces will suffer grievously as a consequence of this action to cut spending to a negative growth this year and what will essentially be a negative growth next year and the year after. If the Government takes it out to the end of the decade with the proposals it has it will mean that we will have even greater levels of resignations from the defence forces than we have had up to the present and we will have an Australian Defence Force which is incapable of responding in any way when we need it.

We simply cannot meet the new level of capital equipment, despite the fact that, when the May statement was made, the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, said that the proposed $25 billion could be satisfied in the years ahead.
