It is absolutely impossible to do this with an inad- equate level of funding. Apart from the stuff that we have already agreed to buy we have a pressing requirement to buy new equipment. We must buy airborne early warning aircraft. We must buy APCs to replace those very dangerous M113s that the Army has. We need, as a matter of high priority, to upgrade the whole level of electronic counter measures that the forces have because we simply cannot survive on the battlefield with the techniques that we have in general for the three Services. Of course, at present we have no war reserve stores. If we have an emergency we just do not have the missiles or the ammunition that we need.

In this situation of constriction and inadequate funds we have this extraordinary saga of the submarine program. Nothing demonstrates the waste of this Government in the defence field more than the way in which this has been handled. It has been the most bizarre chapter in Australia's military history and it has been driven impetuously by the ego of the Minister for Defence and nothing else. There is no pressing hurry for Australia to replace the Oberon submarines. This Government proposed to replace them with a design which I, and everyone else who has been involved in this program, have grave reservations about. But even though the decision has been made for some weeks we have had nothing concrete from the Government as to the design parameters of the boats selected or the costing. We have heard all sorts of rumours but all we know about the costing is that it is open ended and it is enormous.

Australia is now exposed to a design which has inherently very high technical risks and which involves a huge financial commitment. Historically, it is a re-run of what happened in the Whitlam years with the FFG decision and the Leopard tanks. A more useless and a more dangerous ship has never been bought for the Royal Australian Navy than the FFGs, as can be seen from that incident in the Persian Gulf the other week when 37 United States sailors tragically lost their lives. The FFG is a product of a Labor government-a product of the Australian Labor Party's muddled equipment assessment programs-as was the Leopard tank. Fortunately we have not had to use the Leopard tanks anywhere, they are in hibernation.

I come back to the need for the new submarines. The boats we have were bought from 1967 through to 1978. They have a life which will take them through to the end of the century. The proposal that they be retired in 25 years is not an accurate assessment, because the Australian boats have been maintained, through their regular refit program, at a higher standard than any other submarines in the world. It is quite possible to run the oldest of those boats-the HMAS Oxley, which was commissioned and came into service in March 1967-for 30 years without any trouble at all. The design is capable of doing that. The earlier boats-the A class and the T class of the Royal Navy, which were built to much lower design standards in the 1930s and 1940s-all ran for a 30-year service life. So, if we accept that there is no pressing need for these new submarines, we have the ability to look at the matter and get it right, instead of being rushed into it in the way the Government has done.

We are now put in a position of having an unproven design; we do not know whether it is safe. I have real reservations about the safety of the design; I have reservations about its operational capabilities; I have enormous fears about the cost of it, because that seems to be uncontrollable. When the Liberal Party committee had the Swedish builders before it we could get no undertaking from the Swedes that they were prepared to underwrite and accept financial responsibility for any design shortcomings or for the integration of the weapons systems into those boats. I doubt very much whether the Government has managed to screw the Swedes' arms and get that commitment from them subsequently. But without that commitment the Australian taxpayer will pick up the tab-and the tab will run into billions of dollars-for making this design work.

I started out on this matter not to discuss the submarine program but to use it as an example of waste in this Government. As Senator Michael Baume said in his speech, the one thing that characterises this Government is waste. Earlier today in Question Time, Senator Walsh brought up the question of the funding of defence. He said it ought to be reduced. I take the contrary point of view. It can be increased, because it must be increased. The way to increase it is to correct the waste-the waste of having the layabouts and the people who are ripping off the social welfare system, and in every other program that this Government is involved in. If this Government were efficient in its economic management we would not have to have the high taxing that we have; we would not have to have the high borrowings; we would not have to have the high inflation. We would be able to have Australians living in their own homes, buying the cars that they cannot afford to buy now and looking after themselves instead of being locked in this vicious circle of serfdom that this Government has generated of taxing, taxing and taxing, so that everyone at the end of the day is dependent on the beneficence of Mr Hawke or Mr Keating for his daily bread.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Appropriation and Supply Bills. To understand and interpret the debate one must look at these Bills as one of five parts of an overall economic program. They form the first of those parts. A mini-Budget was brought down on 13 May, and that must be assessed also as part of the economic orchestration. There is also the recently held Premiers Conference, the effects of which are still to be evidenced to the public. There is the Budget-now seriously delayed-which is the main economic statement. That Budget, with all its papers, is the one insight that the public can have into the economic program. Finally of the five, there are the various State Budgets in September which will show the effect of the flow-on of the Premiers Conference and the Premiers' reaction, either negative or positive, to the Commonwealth Government's setting of the economic targets. We have only two, at the most, of those five parts of the program before us. In fact, the more important ones remain unknown and are to be deferred.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a statement announcing that he had sought and gained the approval of the Governor-General to have a double dissolution of this Parliament. The statement read in this Senate chamber was so implausible, so insincere, so factually dishonest, that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), when reading it out, could not stop giggling. He could not keep a straight face because he knew how insincere these statements were. He knew how totally implausible the tactic of the Prime Minister was. The Prime Minister, in making that statement and in taking that action, had broken once again major promises. Indeed, the insincerity of the statement is evidenced in that action. Only weeks ago he repeated that he would run his full term and that there was virtue in doing so. There was no question then of any danger in the holding up of identity cards or Australia Cards. That was all right and time would take care of it. He said that the could run his full term. But suddenly, in order to get a pretext, yesterday the Government in a panic action discovered the obstruction of the Senate. A greater nonsense has never been perpetrated on the Australian people, as honourable senator after honourable senator has pointed out. The best that the Prime Minister could do was to cite the Australia Card and the matter of the broadcasting Bills which had been held up for a day or two.

What the Prime Minister did yesterday was something that the Australian people must come to understand. Yesterday he showed that he and his Government are frightened to have their economic program implemented and exposed to the people of Australia. They are frightened to let the people of Australia see the consequences of their mini-Budget when it is implemented in all its forms. They are frightened to have the people of Australia see the nature and impact of their Budget and to read all the finer print of the Budget Papers. Above everything, they are scared to have the State Budgets brought down one by one, because they will show the very perversion of the economic program. Those State Budgets will show that costs are now going up, that the price of the Premiers Conference will be an increase in inflation and that taxes and charges are going up. In September and October we will pay the price. The Government is running now because it is running scared. It has always sought to have elections ahead of time-just as in 1984 the Government promised, after something like 16 months in office, that it would run its full term and then broke its promise; just as it went to the people and said: `There will be no capital gains tax' and broke its promise; just as in fact in a whole series of matters it has broken promises.

What the people of Australia have to understand is the reason why this Government decided to go to the people. So concerned is the Prime Minister for himself and for his Party that he is willing to do great damage to this parliamentary institution by doing what he has done. There was absolutely no need for a double dissolution. There was no need to pull the whole Senate out. Indeed, there may have been a bargain with the Australian Democrats. If that is so, that in itself would be a desecration of the parliamentary principle. The fact of the matter is that if the Government wanted the Australia Card and wanted its broadcasting legislation passed, it has a very simple procedure to follow: It can make them a principal part of its policy speech for the election. It can seek a mandate from the people and, of course, like all other governments that gained clear mandates, it would then implement them.

It has shown that it had no worries at all about a delay of a month or two or three with the Australia Card. Indeed, the Australia Card is not, if it ever emerges, to come into force for another couple of years or so, so time was not vital. There was no urgency at all and no need for a double dissolution. In any case, the absolute implausibility of this claim can be measured very simply. If the Government is arguing that it can win an election and then take the Australia Card legislation to a joint sitting, it knows and every honourable senator knows that it will be in a very insignificant minority in this chamber after the election, whatever the result, and that it will not be able to command the numbers if those independent senators who have in the past opposed the Australia Card are back here and keep to their principles.

So, no matter which way one goes, yesterday's statement-giggled at by the Leader of the Government in the Senate because he, of all people, knew he was talking nonsense-was an attempt to hoodwink the Australian people, to pretend to the Australian people that there was some kind of obstruction in the Senate, that he had to have urgency to get the Australia Card, that we were holding things up and that the Australia Card was part of his economic management. That is a nonsense and demonstrably so, because, if that was so yesterday, why was it not so a week or two ago when he said, `The Government will run its full term'? At the time when he said that the Government would run its full term he knew that he did not have the Australia Card. He knew there would be delays, if not total obstruction of it indefinitely; but it was no problem to him at all right through the months since the Australia Card legislation was properly rejected here. It was never an obstruction for him when he said: `We will run our full term'. It was an invention yesterday, a crude invention that the people of Australia will see through.

It was an invention yesterday in order to do one thing-and that the people of Australia must understand clearly. He could not have a half Senate election plus a lower House election in July. The Constitution would not allow him to do that. He could have it, at the earliest, on 8 August, and that would be too close to the date of 18 August set down for the Federal Budget for him to be able to explain why he did not have the Budget. Therefore, to get as far away as he could from the Budget he had to bring down the whole of this Parliament in a double dissolution. That is political conniving, political scheming, political engineering and a desecration of the parliamentary system. It does great damage to this institution, Madam Acting Deputy President.

This Senate is supposed to be a House of review with a continuity of purpose, but what the Prime Minister and his Government have done-and he knows this-is to desecrate this Parliament by their action in enlarging the Parliament for their own political purposes. What they did with this Senate was this: They decided, because they wanted to enlarge the lower House, that they had to enlarge the Senate-because the lower House must be, as nearly as practicable, double the size of the Senate-to 12 senators from each State. They did that in the full knowledge that that would create a hung Senate and a Senate that would from time to time be rendered inoperable simply because it would allow all sorts of groupings of people to come in. Whereas in a half Senate election it would take more than 14 per cent of the voters to fill a vacancy here, in a double dissolution it takes only 7.7 per cent. The Government has opened the doors widely to a fragmentation of this Parliament, not for any reason other than its need to have an urgency to have an election in early July.

So long as the people of Australia understand that the whole of the action yesterday was for one purpose, to distance the Government as far from the Budget as possible, they will clearly understand that the Government has massive things to hide. It is frightened of the impact of the mini-Budget, of the Budget and of the State Budgets and it wants the election over beforehand. It is willing to damage the Parliament to do that.

Let me again make it clear that there could be no greater nonsense than talking about the obstruction of the Australia Card. Let me repeat this: This is the pretext on which the Prime Minister went to the Governor-General-that there was obstruction-but on his own admission there was no thought in his mind of obstruction in the weeks when he repeatedly said that the Government would run its full term. There was no thought of that in his mind because he knew that if he went to the electors, made the Australia Card a major issue for a mandate and got that mandate, he could get it through and there would be no delay. There was nothing to stop the Government from putting into operation all of the pre-planning for the Australia Card if they wanted to, so there would be no delay at all. Therefore, yesterday's statement is, in itself, downright dishonest. Its aim is purely to allow the Government to run scared.

Another reason the Government gives for going to the election is that the Opposition is in disarray. My goodness, Madam Acting Deputy President, when one looks at the Labor Party and one looks at Mr Halfpenny, a senator-elect for this Parliament, doing everything in breach of Labor principles-a former Communist-and doing everything to disrupt and damage the economy, who is in disarray? When one looks at the Queensland branch of the Labor Party and realises that its members cannot even resolve their differences about the seat of Bowman, when one looks at all the fights inside the Labor Party, when one looks at the Unsworth Government and sees that it expelled Mr Petersen yesterday or the day before, all one can say is, `Physician, heal thyself'.

The Labor Party has been torn asunder by factions. The Labor Party has within it elements of its own destruction, but because it suits the Government to pick a pimple on the behaviour of the Opposition, that matter is played up by self-interests who want to see damage in the Opposition. There is no greater disarray around Australia than that in the Australian Labor Party. After all, Senator Georges sits in this chamber as a symbol of the disarray of the Labor Party, a senator who was willing to buck his Caucus and go with his conscience-and what for? It was to denounce the Australia Card. Where did the obstruction come from in that regard? It came from a Labor Party member.

Let me simply say that perhaps all I should have said is: Let Senator Button's demeanour, let his vacuous giggles yesterday, be the judgment on that statement. I never saw in this place a statement put forward with more disbelief and mistrust in it by the person putting it forward. That has to be clearly understood everywhere. Now the Government is running scared, and let us have a look at why the Government is running scared. Its misjudgment will sit ill upon the Government, because it will be defeated. The people of Australia have an innate sense of decency. They hate trickery and they will punish the Australian Labor Party because they know it is trickery. Indeed, the Australian Labor Party is making a grave mistake because it fails to remind itself of two major trends. There has been a major trend in the polls for eight or nine months putting the Opposition ahead of Labor, although it is having a dip at this moment, but the Government fails to comprehend that every by-election that has been held-and five of them have been in my State during the past year-has shown that the people given the chance to get at the jugular vein of the Labor Party, take the chance not in terms of a few per cent but in terms of 10 or 20 per cent.

Those by-elections show that the Treasurer was not game to participate in the by-elections in his own seat. He was told not to appear, to go on holiday. The two by-elections, for Bass Hill and Bankstown, resulted in a total rejection of the Labor Party, yet the Prime Minister has the gall to get up and say that the Liberal and National parties are in disarray. Was there ever a Treasurer in more disarray than Paul Keating, with his tail between his legs slinking from his own seat of Blaxland because he was a vote loser?

In looking at it, the public made a judgment and decided it wanted to sweep out the Labor Party. So half of the Treasurer's Labor stronghold of Blaxland is held by a Liberal State member at this moment. Despite that, the Labor Party says the Liberal Party is in disarray. Only last Saturday in the Northern Tablelands, in the heart of the countryside, a very popular candidate, who had been the de facto member in the time of her husband's illness, stood for election. The Premier of New South Wales, Mr Unsworth, said she was worth 7 per cent in her own right. The Labor Party took a hiding of nearly 5 per cent. According to Mr Unsworth's statement, that was a swing of 12 per cent. Who is in disarray?

Everyone must know that both the grounds for seeking a double dissolution are nonsense. It has been claimed that the Liberal Party in the Senate frustrated the Bill of Rights-36 hours of frustration, so Senator Evans said. Why do we not hear that the Government is going to reinstate the Bill of Rights? Why does it not make it a platform in its policy speech and say it will bring it to the people? I shall tell honourable senators why. In the public's perception, the Bill of Rights was bad. The public is proud of this Senate because it rejected the Bill and because of the way it has behaved. Do not let us have any nonsense about the grounds on which it is stated that members of the Liberal Party are supposed to be in disarray. The real disarray lies with the Labor Party itself. It has a Treasurer who has never been able to get what he wanted. Every time the Treasurer has said that something ought to be, the Prime Minister has taken it away from him. The Government had a great National Economic Summit Conference and the Treasurer was defeated; it had a National Taxation Summit and the Treasurer was defeated. This is the Government that says that others are in disarray. There is open evidence that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer hold totally different views. The Government is in disarray.

What happened to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in the last couple of weeks? A crisis was occurring in the southern Pacific, an area that is very important to Australia. Where was the Foreign Minister? Overseas. He was overseas because the Prime Minister told him to stay there. There has been no justification from the Foreign Minister; he has not tried to justify it. When he is asked why he was overseas and not where the real problem was, he says that the Prime Minister told him to stay away. Why? Because Mr Hawke wanted to big note himself. Who is in disarray when one considers the Northern Tablelands result for the Unsworth Government; the expulsion of the man Petersen from the Party; the Queensland Labor Party mess, with the Bowman situation; and the dirty tricks involved in trying to solve their problems by having a new ambassador for Greece? Who is in disarray when the left wing of the Labor Party in Victoria is dragging the Party by its nose? I cannot think of anything more nonsensical.

Why is the Government running to an early election? It is because of fear. The Government knows of these things I have mentioned, and it knows that, when implemented, the mini-Budget will hurt people and will be unjust in many ways. It knows, as those who are involved closely with social security know, that when the mini-Budget impacts on dual income families, it will cause hardship to many people. They know the mini-Budget is a phoney. Fancy trying to pretend that the mini-Budget provides a cut of $4 billion when $1 billion of that is from sale of property. Everybody knows that one should not attempt to reduce one's deficit in a once-off situation by selling capital. If that is done, it is a oncer. After all, the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) have simply shifted a $1 billion deficit from the coming Budget into the deficit for the year afterwards. It is a cosmetic piece of nonsense. In the last Budget, the Government was going to sell the Anzac Rifle Range. Has it done so? Not on your life! The more time goes on, the more it becomes absolute nonsense. The proposal was never a goer as most of the land was not capable of being sold for the purpose intended. Nothing has happened.

The Government is going to sell the Commonwealth offices in Sydney and Melbourne and lease them back. Time and time again I have heard Labor members say it is bad business to lease buildings around Australia for public purposes. The Government should be the owner of the buildings, it ought to hold the capital of buildings as it is much more costly to lease them back. What a piece of nonsense! Japan is a country in which Australia needs prestige, and it has a prime site there which, over the years, will increase enormously in value and add to Australia's prestige in that country. The Government is going to hive off a bit of that land for the purpose of pretending it has cut the deficit. When that is removed from the deficit and one looks at the $3 billion left, one realises that $1 billion must be taken up by the States. That is no hardship for the Government. So in the mini-Budget the Government has passed on the hardships to the people of Australia by selling its heritage and capital. It has passed on the pressures to the States, but it is going to make darn sure that it will have an election ahead of the time that the States bring down their Budgets and have to put up all their taxes and charges, their water and electricity rates, and so put up inflation as they go.

If the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance are so proud of their economic program, why will they not wait until the five pieces of their program-the Appropriation Bills, the mini-Budget, the Premiers Conference, the Budget and the State Budgets-can be seen together? That would be a fair test, but the Government does not want that test. The figures in the gallup poll have taken an interesting little dip at this moment, and the Government knows that it has a good chance of sneaking some type of election prospect. That is nonsense. The people of Australia know that it is a pretence, and that there was no need for a double dissolution and an early election and that if the Government had nothing to hide, it would wait until after September before calling an election.

I have heard the Minister for Finance and the Treasurer talk about the importance of having the Budget in place in time so the markets of the world would get to know the position. The Budget is so important that, for its electoral expediency, the Government will postpone and delay it for a month or more. Today honourable senators heard when the writs will be returned. The Government cannot say it has all its budgeting in place. Members of the Government cannot know what will happen to the economy in the months of June, July and August. The incoming government will need a month or two to put together the Budget papers. The figures will be out of joint by then. However, it is of no consequence to the Government, in terms of its own expediency, to delay the Budget for a month or two. Its idea is to take a quick trick while it can.

I have never heard a more disgraceful or implausible statement than the Prime Minister's statement yesterday. It was so disgraceful that Senator Button in this chamber could scarcely mouth it because he knew it was so untruthful and dishonest. He was giggling like any schoolgirl saying something she thought was naughty. Have honourable senators ever seen a more truant person than the Leader of the Government yesterday trying to mouth a statement he knew was utterly wrong? So what have we got? The people of Australia are being asked to vote without knowing what is in the box, without knowing what taxes and charges will face them. It is not good enough for the Government to say it has its Budget in place; what will happen to the State Budgets? What is to happen to things in the meantime? The Government knows things will get worse. Today there was further evidence from industry that industry in Australia remains on the decline and that investment in the real things of Australia, and not the spivvery of Australia, is also on the decline. The Government asks that it be judged on its record. I think that perhaps we ought to judge the Government on its record. Let us judge the Government on the fact that, whereas the average sustained unemployment over the whole of the nearly eight years of the Fraser Government was under 6 per cent-I think a little over 5 per cent-under the present Government it has been consistently 8 per cent or 9 per cent. The present Government has not been able to lower that figure. The Government has presided over the highest sustained unemployment since the Great Depression-and let the Government wear that. This Government has brought Australia's external debt from about $30 billion out to beyond $100 billion, wrecking the Australian budget-and they are proud of it. It is a government that has brought record high interest rates which have damaged the pockets of ordinary people, particularly home owners. The Government and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) year by year have been responsible for the further steady disintegration of industry in Australia. Year by year more and more people have been shed from industry, with more and more people becoming unemployed, and yet the Government maintains that it is succeeding. However, until it discovered the banana republic, for three years it said that everything was all right.

The present Government will be judged on its record. Australian citizens will judge it on falling living standards and a total and abysmal punishment of ordinary families. What does the Government say to that? It maintains that it is not its fault but that it is due to a fall in the terms of trade. It says that Australia cannot sell its exports at the prices that it used to. However, the Government forgets to say that Australia cannot export more or that it cannot stop imports because the unit costs of production in Australia are so much higher than those applicable to most of our competitors. Thus, this Government is costing us out of world markets and costing 600,000 Australians out of jobs. The Government refers to only one side of the coin. The real situation is that the Government has done nothing about creating more jobs and reducing unemployment. It talks about the fact that it has created more jobs, but on the Government's own say-so about four years ago, some 140,000 more jobs must be created each year just to keep up with the population explosion. So let us not have any more of those sorts of assertions. In fact we have had soaring inflation, soaring interest rates and indeed a collapse of industry, particularly in relation to the motor car industry.

In the statement made by the Government yesterday concerning the double dissolution we were asked to judge the Government on its merits. Well, the people of Australia will judge the Government. They will judge it as being so afraid of the consequences of its actions and that it is hoping to run before those consequences have been revealed. Further, they will judge it on its contributing to high sustained unemployment, high interest rates and inflation and the fact that it has never addressed the really important matter of the unit costs of production. The Government contributed to the development of a confrontationist society instead of a co-operative society. The people of Australia will judge the Government in the way that has been indicated over the past 12 months, that is, they will tip this Government out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now one week since the Government made its Mayday call, and one day since the Government finally bailed out into its election lifeboat. The mini-Budget was a final call for help by the Government to its friends in big business and the media to bail it out, and I believe that it is yet another kick in the guts for those young Australians, the unemployed, the Australian family and the aged people in Australia. It is a Budget of 1,000 cuts. The Government effectively managed to disguise this due to the Fijian coup which took place fortuitously, and hid the public responses to this. The Government has now hidden itself away by means of an election sham. As Senator Sir John Carrick has said, if in doubt, hide. The Australian Democrats believe in open government. The Bills that we are discussing are the main Bills which review the operation of the Public Service and the expenditure of this country. This Government has mismanaged the economy. The Australian Democrats believe that it is important that the Senate should be a House of review, that it should provide an effective review and scrutiny of the account of this country. Yet, in this regard I refer particularly to the Senate Estimates committee hearings this year; we were given only two days notice of the figures before the commencement of the first committee. Even in relation to questions that we had prepared that were direct and to the point, scrutinising what happens within the Public Service, scandalously, Ministers, like Mr Scholes, actually forwarded letters to the committee, after promises had been made by the various chairmen of the committees and after various public servants had undertaken to provide answers to those questions on notice, telling the committee that it would cost $10,000 to answer questions that had been put on notice. He said that because of that no answers would be provided to the questions. That is scandalous behaviour. That is the type of behaviour that we have come to expect from Senator Walsh who never answers questions in this place. It is the type of scandalous behaviour that we have come to expect from this Government. Members of the Government should hide their heads in shame.
—That is not right.

—Senator Walsh is one of the worst people in terms of being contemptuous of the Senate. I believe that it is extremely important that at the next election the people of Australia realise exactly what this Government stands for.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has shown a very laissez faire attitude in relation to leaving Australia exposed to the mercy of the large multinational corporations; to their friends, the media barons; to the greed of the large financial dealers; and to the general forces of the market-place. They are almost indistinguishable from the New Right, which Senator McKiernan was hitting at. I almost thought that I was listening to a liturgy of what the Hawke Government was doing when I was listening to the description of the ills of the New Right. I believe that the election is a final sell-out of the electors, following the ruthless sell-off of Australia's last remaining assets and resources, and I believe that it heralds an impending economic disaster of massive proportions.

The Government suddenly decided that it had to have a double dissolution. The Government has proved its failure to keep faith with Labor ideals and it is continuing to prove its failure to manage the business of government, and, what is more, as Senator Sir John Carrick has pointed out so ably, its failure to keep its word. It is a penny wise, pounds foolish government-it is exactly that which we see in all the types of edicts which come out of the Department of Finance. I believe that `penny-wise pound-foolish' will be the epitaph of the Hawke Labor Government. Its short-sightedness in cutting education expenditure and employment opportunities for young people, its savage attack on the State services and its further cut backs in overseas aid are throwing away many years of prior investments in goodwill and the skills of people in Australia. This is simply a short cut that has been taken.

The selling off of assets on the cheap has been simply a short cut in order to balance budgets. I believe that it is scandalous to sell off Australian ownership and control of our industries, land, infrastructure, banks, energy and mineral resources, and our media. This will make it almost impossible for Australia to recover from the type of profligate attitude of the Government involving waste and penny-pinching cuts that have been undertaken. It is the across the board cuts in the Public Service which have led to cuts not only in the areas where savings could be made but even more particularly in areas which are essential to government revenue, and I refer to areas like the Department of Communications, which is actually providing and collecting money for selling services such as those provided on our airwaves. Any sensible business would recognise that the income which comes into general revenue from such departments should be sought after. Instead of that, there are cuts in the number of people essential for producing that revenue.

We are faced with the prospect of becoming a manana republic. This is what the Hawke Government has created by its incompetence, by Labor's betrayal of Australian control over its resources and by putting off until tomorrow the debts it is running up today. Everything is being deferred-defence spending, communications spending and the whole infrastructure of our roads. Airports and the expenditure on almost all fronts are hit at in a completely unreasonable way, in the name of getting our national debt down. Our national debt is mainly in private hands, and we are subsidising it through various tax measures. We are subsidising it through the taxation system by negative gearing arrangements and by encouraging foreign people to come in and overheat our stock markets. More seriously, industrial development, business investment and small business viability are being deferred by this Government.

This Government came here yesterday and said: `Let us finish the job'. Basically it seems to me that the country cannot afford to have this Government finish off what it has been doing to small businessmen, farmers and people who have been at the tender mercy of the deregulated economy, deregulated banks and deregulated exchange rates. High interest rates are diverting savings away from the productive investments, which would increase our industrial base, into speculative stock exchange activities, into unproductive financial and property deals. Small business people cannot meet these interest rates on borrowings, and that is why they are finding it very difficult to survive. They will be the people-I can tell Senator Walsh that there are many of them-who will show the Government what they feel at the next election. Future investment has had to be cut to survive. Effectively all those businesses which expanded recently, after listening to Senator Button's proposals for a great, new economic era in industry and technology, have been the hardest hit. It is no wonder that unemployment is again souring, that takeovers have reached a record level and that businesses which seemed to be doing well are grasping for cash. There is no way that business can support the level of interest rates that this Government has thrust upon us.

The most serious cost for the future is the attack on Australia's investment in the future, our young people. Priority One has turned into priority lost. Cuts in technical and college education, employment programs for the young and skills training leave our young people high and dry without any support. It is amazing that a government which is supposedly socialist and supposedly caring has actually hit at these key people. We came in with this dream of Priority One, of an exciting future for youth, but we have actually cut out the incentives for these people. We have cut out the support and much of the money which used to go into the technical and further education area and we have cut out the community employment program. It might have had some failures, but it really deserves to be continued in hard hit areas.

This Hawke Government has let the economy run the people, not the people run the economy. It will indeed be remembered by the words `penny wise, pounds foolish'. It certainly does not pay to be a supporter of the Australian Labor Party. It certainly does not pay to be thought of as a safe voter for the Labor Party. Students, young unemployed, disabled, older unemployed, women and migrants, who have been some of the strongest supporters of the Labor Party, have been sold down the river by this Labor Government, and most recently by this mini-Budget.

Because the Government could not face delivering another Budget, it has had to call an election. The welfare system is in tatters. Our education and training system is a disaster because of the tertiary administration fee. Thirty-two thousand people qualified to go to universities are unable to take up places because those places were not made available. The future cost of supporting these people in the community will fall on the wage earners and salary earners. The unions and the wage and salary earners are facing pressure for deregulated labour markets while they pay ever increasing taxes and interest rates to support tax-free rorts and a labour squeeze. The fact is that this Government has not been prepared to take on the larger rorts in the taxation system. It has not been prepared to pursue transfer pricing. It has not been prepared to pursue satisfactorily the rorts associated with overseas tax havens. It has not been prepared to apply the same types of measures to negative gearing in company takeovers as it did to the individual pensioner who might own a flat. It is really quite unreasonable.

The Government is penny wise, pounds foolish. It appears to have no plan of management, no plan of development and no planned economy. It is acting, to some extent, like an opposition. It is saying: `Look, the Opposition is in disarray; it has no policies'. The Government is spending much more time talking about the Opposition's disarray than looking at its own. It cannot see the log in its eye but is seeing the spot in that of the Opposition. It is really quite unreasonable that we should have to put up with this type of government. I welcome the election, even though it has been called a sham, because it will allow the people of Australia to look at what this Government has done.

I now turn to the other side of government activities-the spending side. I believe the Hawke Government has been afflicted with the Yes Minister syndrome. It has been very lucky that we have had that clever television series to show us many of the tricks which the Public Service and public servants may be trying on the Government. Ministers should be forced to view this show. I believe the Public Service has made an effort to escape scrutiny. The Government is failing in its long term scrutiny and control of existing expenditure and, to some extent, failing to understanding the processes of government.

I have been involved in investigating in Estimates committees these types of processes. The set of Estimates committees associated with these Appropriation Bills has been one of the most disappointing. Three departments have been totally scandalous in the way they have handled these Estimates committees. One of them, the Department of Territories, hid behind its Minister, Mr Scholes, who accepted the Government's statement that, to answer questions put on notice last month by the Estimates committee, would cost $10,000. Mr Scholes failed to recognise that the questions had been put on notice in an open meeting of the committee to save time and money and that an extra meeting of the committee to question officers of the Depatment would have cost at least $10,000. Mr Scholes also failed to question why the Department wished to avoid any scrutiny by not answering the types of questions which were asked. Some of them were the types of questions which Senator Michael Baume raised relating to Parliament House, where enormous overexpenditures have occurred. A large number of these questions dealt with maladministration, which is the hallmark of the Department of Territories.

It is the Senate's responsibility to oversee this expenditure. When we pass these Appropriation Bills we accept that expenditure is going to be effected. If we cannot answer reasonable questions about how this expenditure is carried out, how efficiently it is ordered, and what type of inefficiencies exist within the Department, we have a real problem. It is our job to scrutinise the departments. The failure of the Department of Territories is a disgrace. In this particular case the questions which were not answered dealt with the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, and with the Australian Capital Territory Fire Brigade, which has been a running sore within the Department over the years, for various reasons. We were asking questions to bring that out into the open. Questions were asked in relation to community housing activity in the Australian Capital Territory and the inability of the Australian Capital Territory properly to manage and administer the lands in its control. There were problems with the National Capital Development Commission in handling the new developments and in ensuring that environmental protection criteria are applied within Canberra.

These were the types of simple and reasonable questions asked about the operation of government. There were not large numbers of them. The Minister responsible for the Department of Territories probably used the formula of the Department of Finance which, I believe, added 72 per cent in overheads to the time used in answering questions in order to justify that figure of $10,000. It is quite unacceptable that the Government should treat the Senate with this type of contempt. I believe that the people of Australia will respond by voting in a senator to make certain that whatever the complexion of the government we get, it will be answerable to the people, that people elected senators will have scrutiny of what the public servants are doing. We are elected for only short periods-three years or six years or whatever it may be. During that time we are forced to break in, to start to understand the processes of the Public Service. By the time we get to be reasonably proficient and knowledgeable, the departments either hide behind the type of unacceptable behaviour which the Department of Territories does or resort to another level of Yes Minister activity. The Ministers should take the responsibility of reviewing what their departments do and they should welcome the Senate's scrutiny of what is happening in the Public Service and work with it. What has happened in these Estimates committees is scandalous.

I would like to take another example of a department in which we have not had good information and in which we have been `Yes Ministered'. I refer to the Department of Communications and Australia Post. The management of Australia Post, as far as I can see, is in a shambles at its headquarters. I have been pursuing the questions of printing, distribution and destruction of stamps for some time. It has been a sore spot within the organisation for some time and has resulted in comments in the Auditor-General's report. Australia Post has failed to exercise adequate supervision and checking at all stages of stamp printing and distribution. In answer to questions on notice I was told that there were stringent procedures for destroying surplus or misprinted stamps, with two people involved in most procedures. Yet in the past few years several individuals have been charged with siphoning off hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of stamps. That does not square with Australia Post's answers.

Its explanation of philatelic reasons for disposing of commemorative stamps after six months is of a banana republic standard. I still have no answers from the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) to a question without notice about the oversight he has shown over these stamp matters. That is just a very small matter but millions of dollars are involved. We have the responsibility of checking and handling these matters for the people of Australia. The Auditor-General's Office has also ducked the issue, pointing out that it investigates and makes findings and it is up to others to try to do something about the problems. It is important that we get investigations into what has been going on over the last five years and why the management of Australia Post has not solved this problem. We need an inquiry. We are having an election and, temporarily at least, this matter will be lost in the election fever. I hope it is only temporary and that it will be taken up by somebody, if not by me.

Also, an enormous amount of information is being withheld from us. I have been trying to get information from Australia Post about the closing down of the Watson post office. The saga is far too long to go into in detail at this stage but basically the Department has been carrying on a legal battle with the postmaster. It has been making statements which were inconsistent with previous statements. It is in a complete mess. It is looking at closing down this post office. It has not succeeded because a local group has taken this matter to court, has fought it through and has kept feeding material to people such as me, who have kept the matter alive. Eventually these public interest groups face massive costs if they want to follow such matters legally. They have now been further squeezed by the raising of freedom of information costs which this Government-which prides itself on its alleged open government-has presided over. Now it is not possible for people freely to get information other than personal information from the Public Service.

The Public Service spends an enormous amount of time trying to make certain that information asked for is not able to be treated as personal information. It is quite unreasonable for organisations such as Australia Post and the NCDC to go into legal battle against public interest groups and to use the might of the public purse to push those groups out of litigation in which they are trying to pursue a matter in the interests of the people of a particular district or in the interests of Australia as a whole. It is quite unacceptable that public moneys should be used in this way and I have been pursuing this matter through the Estimates committee. We have not been getting the support we need from the Government in the answers that have been given.

In the remaining five minutes available to me, I point out that yet another problem hits the Parliament when it has to oversee government expenditure. It will probably not be realised by most people that only 30 per cent of total government expenditure is handled through the budgetary process and through these types of supplementary Bills. Some 70 per cent of the government expenditure undertaken on behalf of the people of Australia is not directly subject to the scrutiny of this Parliament. These Bills include special appropriations of which there is no proper or regular scrutiny. Ministers do not scrutinise them and it is only through secondary questioning at Estimates committee hearings that one can actually get at some of the figures. Essentially, enormous slush funds are available on which we can get no reasonable accounting figures. That situation needs to be changed.

I undertake that, if re-elected, I will continue to pursue accountability in government. Whether by some outside chance the Labor Government actually manages to get back into office or whether another party is elected to govern, the Public Service must still be beholden to Parliament and must respond to it. During this Government not only have we had more and more appropriations by way of special appropriations and special Bills-this allows the Public Service a completely free hand without any scrutiny from the Parliament-but also we have seen more and more government by Press release, which is also government by department and Minister. This shows contempt for the Senate. If we are to be a proper House of review, if we are to scrutinise properly the operations of the Public Service and look at every piece of legislation and make certain that it is good legislation for the people of this country, we must squash the government by Press release which has been the hallmark of the Hawke Government. I say to the Hawke Government that it must answer to the electors for this government by Press release and for more and more handing over of its responsibility to other people and blaming other people. It is blaming others at every stage, whether it be for our terms of trade or whatever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I congratulate Senator Vigor on his most interesting speech. The Government ought to be taking notice of what he said but, unfortunately, the only member of the Government in the chamber is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt). That shows the contempt in which the Australian Labor Party holds this legislation. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, has called an early election. On April Fool's Day the Prime Minister told the people of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To have an early election may have brought into question the Government's resolve to make the tough decisions needed to meet the economic challenge facing this country.
I want to tell the Australian people that we will not shirk our responsibilities in making the unpalatable, though necessary, economic decisions.

On April Fool's Day he ruled out any likelihood of an early election. He said that the May statement would be tough but fair. But in true characteristic style, what do we have? We have an early election. A month later that Prime Minister stated that this promise was to be forgotten. What other promises has this Government made that have been cast aside as easily as that promised? Mr Cain said at the Premiers Conference:
You and I and people around this table took part in deregistering the BLF because it didn't keep agreements.
He indicated that the Government had not kept its promise to the States of the year before. What was the answer of the Treasurer, Mr Keating? He replied:
John, you say we've broken our commitment to you and you liken our commitment to Norm Gallagher. The fact is the world's broken its commitments to Australia.

What utter rubbish. The Treasurer has been hiding behind the fact that the world is not giving us the prices we want for our commodities, the high prices for which we have become accustomed, ever since he has been in government, ever since he found that he could not manage the economy of this country. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, got it right. Last year, at the Australian Labor Party Conference in Hobart, Senator Walsh said:

I know some people believe, that budget deficits don't matter. They do matter in the degree to which they lock in future expenditure. If we had a public debt interest payment, the same level of outlays as it was in 1982-
that was the last financial year during which the Fraser Government held office-

we would in this financial year have about $4 billion extra to either cut taxes, increase welfare spending or whatever else you wanted to do with it. But because we have run a sequence of high budget deficits, we are lumbered with a crippling public debt interest payment which restricts the ability of this Government and Governments for the foreseeable future, to deliver the programs they would like to deliver elsewhere.

Senator Walsh was honest enough to say that this Government has squandered $4 billion and it is because of that that we needed the May mini-Budget. We did not need it because of overseas problems or because, as Mr Keating said, the world has broken its commitments to Australia; it was because this Government has squandered money, as Senator Walsh said, through a series of high Budget deficits and given us crippling public debt interest payments. Those factors are restricting the Government's ability to manage the economy in a responsible manner.

This Government has sold its soul to the media barons and thus it thinks it can get away with an early election. It will have all the media barons on side but I can tell it that there will be a backlash. The people of Australia are responsible and without any doubt-I assure Senator Gietzelt as the Minister present-the people will throw out this Labor Government as they did in 1975, and just as thoroughly. There will be a backlash. Mr Hawke has said that he needs a mandate to finish the job. Why does he need a mandate when already he and his Treasurer have presided over the lowering of Australia's overseas credit rating for the first time in Australia's history? Let us face the facts. This means that Australia no longer has an AAA credit rating and that any overseas borrowing will now be at a slightly higher interest rate. He wants a mandate to finish that job? What will our credit rating be by the time he finishes?

The Treasurer-the best treasurer in the whole wide world!-is saying that we are becoming a banana republic, yet Mr Hawke wants a mandate to finish the job, to bring us into a true banana republic. That is what we have been promised by this Prime Minister. He wants certainty and continuity. Let us look at the job those opposite have done. We have a list of the top 10 broken promises. What happened to the first promise on home ownership? Mr Hawke, in his policy speech in 1984, said:
We pledge ourselves to bring home ownership once again within the reach of ordinary Australian families.

Within the reach of ordinary Australian families? In March 1983, average loan repayments were 19.2 per cent of a median family's income. The figure is now 26.9 per cent, as of December 1986. Monthly payments on a typical $50,000 home-not a lavish home-over a 25-year period have risen by $172 a month. Yet Mr Hawke says that he will bring home ownership within the reach of ordinary Australian families. The hypocrisy of it is sickening. Let us look at Mr Hawke's No. 2 promise on interest rates. In November 1984 he said:
Australia and Australians will during 1985 reap the interest rate rewards that are flowing from successful policies of the past 20 months.

Let us look at those interest rates. In November 1984 at the time of his speech, the prime interest rate was 13.5 per cent. The latest figure is 18.5 per cent. When Mr Hawke made that statement home loans were at 11.5 per cent. The latest Commonwealth Banking Corporation announcement was a rate of 16.5 per cent. The Bankcard rate at that time was 18 per cent. It is now 22.5 per cent and small overdrafts have moved from 14.5 per cent to 20.5 per cent. Let us compare that record with that of our immediate trading partners. It is most interesting to compare prime interest rates because such comparisons can be made only with countries to which we are trying to sell our goods. As I said, at the moment our prime interest rate is 18.5 per cent whereas in Japan it is 5.2 per cent, in the United States of America it is 7.5 per cent and in West Germany it is 5.45 per cent. What a wonderful broken promise that was. And we should give him a mandate to finish the job? Australians would be mad to do so.
The next promise concerned petrol prices. Mr Hawke promised:
Any fall in Saudi prices must be passed on to Australian motorists in lower petrol prices.

What did he do? He put on a 10c per litre excise. We all remember the promises to lower petrol prices. The Australian people know what they are paying for petrol. There is no need for me to say anything further. Then we come to promises made to ordinary families. In February 1983 Mr Hawke promised concerning the dependent spouse rebate:
The major points of Labor's tax reform will be . . . increases in the spouse rebate.

Under the previous Fraser Government, the dependent spouse rebate went from $400 when we first came in after Mr Whitlam, for a dependent spouse with dependent children, to $1,030. For a dependent spouse without dependent children the sum more than doubled from $400 to $830. Not one cent has been given for the dependent spouse rebate by this Government. Yet Mr Hawke promised that Labor's tax reform would mean increases to the dependent spouse rebate. Let us go further to the Medicare levy. We all remember that promise, do we not? In November 1984 in that good policy speech of Labor-anything to get it into government but with no intention to have a commitment to any of the promises-Mr Hawke said:
And I now give this undertaking-that for the term of our next government, the Medicare levy will not be increased.

What dreadful fraud. In the 1986-87 Budget, the Medicare levy was increased from one per cent to 1.25 per cent and the ceiling on the levy was abolished. In the mini-Budget the Government has done a lot more-it has done things that had never been thought of, so Mr Hawke has got away with not having made promises about them. I will come to that later. Let us look at promise No. 8. Mr Hawke said:
In our next three years of Government the overall level of taxation will not increase as a proportion of Gross Domestic Product.

What has happened since Mr Hawke said that in November 1984? In 1985-86 it went up by 0.2 per cent and the next year it went up again another half per cent-but Mr Hawke said the promise would stand for three years. In breaking that promise the Government raised $400m in additional tax in the first year. He said he would keep the promise for three years but he broke it in the first year and raised $400m in tax and $1,400m in the next year. So much for that promise. We all remember him telling us so clearly that that promise at least would never be broken. The next promise was the wine tax promise. We all remember that. It is of no use Senator Gietzelt turning off his hearing aid because the people of Australia will tell him when the election comes and he will have to listen to them. Mr Hawke said:
Labor has pledged not to impose a sales tax or an excise on wine.
That was in Bob Hawke's rural policy speech. In the 1984-85 Budget he imposed a 10 per cent tax. What did the Prime Minister do in the 1986-87 Budget? He increased it to 20 per cent.
I now come to the Prime Minister's famous promise on the capital gains tax. I know that Opposition senators certainly remember that because these were his words:
And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.

We all know what we have. We have a capital gains tax. Senator Gareth Evans said by way of interjection that the promise was for one election only. What credibility could any government have when it makes a promise and then backs off so quickly?

Those are the top 10 broken promises that I would like to deal with tonight, and I am dealing with only 10. Are the people of Australia going to give this Government a mandate to finish the job and to break more of its promises? I do not believe that they will. What has this Government been responsible for? More people are living below the poverty line than ever before. More married women are being forced into the work force because it has become necessary to have two incomes to support the family. We have the highest level of company and personal bankruptcies in the history of the nation and the highest level of personal taxation that Australia has ever seen. This Government has a contempt and a lack of compassion for the people of Australia that has never been experienced before. Jobs and grants for the boys and the friends of the Australian Labor Party are also on a scale that has never been experienced. This Government has a list of broken promises that has never been equalled by any government before it. Are we really going to give this Government a mandate to finish the job?

What about the trade unions? We all know that Mr Hawke, coming fresh from being President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, has had to kow-tow to the ACTU to ensure that the money rolls in for the election. He introduced industrial relations legislation into the House of Representatives that we were all able to have a look at. The business community decided that it would fight that legislation tooth and nail to the death because it would give the unions so much power and a court of their own which would keep them out of any civil court. It would have given the unions such power that they would have been well above the law that applies to any other Australian citizen. Because the Government introduced this legislation, because we were all well aware of it, because the Opposition made it so clear that it would never allow the legislation to get through, and because business decided that it would fight the legislation so hard, this pragmatic Government withdrew the legislation as it announced the election date. Are we going to give this Government a mandate to finish the job, a mandate to give the ACTU powers in this country, and a mandate to make the foreign affairs policies that it is making at the moment over Fiji? Not on your life! No mandate will be given to this Government to finish the job.

What sorts of standards do we have in this Government? We have the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Young. The people of Australia will be reminded of Mick Young's long lunch. Mick Young is one of six Cabinet Ministers on a sub-committee on national and international security-I suppose one of the most important committees in Australia-yet he was not able to keep his own counsel. He had to tell friends over a prolonged lunch that he was about to kick out a Russian. Mr Coombe was involved. The Prime Minister rang Richard Farmer and said: `I will not tell you much about it but do not waste your money by going into business with Mr Coombe'. Those are the sorts of standards we have in this Ministry.

We had Mick Young bringing undeclared goods into this country. What happened? The Customs officers were so appalled that they told us about it and Mick Young was thrown out of Cabinet for a short while so that an inquiry could be conducted. What a disgraceful situation when Ministers of the Crown can get away with things that the citizens of this country cannot get away with. What a disgrace! Of course, to cap it all we had the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who decided that he was above the law and that he would not pay his tax or put in a tax return. I have a copy of the letter from the Commissioner of Taxation which states:
Dear Mr Keating,
The purpose of this letter is to draw to your attention the need for you to file your 1986 tax return which is now outstanding.
As recently discussed your 1985 return is also well overdue.

The Commissioner of Taxation writes personal letters to the Treasurer of the country pleading with him to pay his overdue tax and to send in his overdue returns, yet the citizens of this country are being fined if they do not do it. They do not get letters from the Commissioner of Taxation. Mr Keating's only excuse was that he was too busy to fill in his tax forms.

This same Treasurer is ripping off the people with the highest taxes that Australia has ever experienced. He is also ripping off these people by saying that his home is really in Sydney. He collects a travelling allowance for living in Canberra. His wife and children live in Canberra, his children go to school in Canberra and he claims a daily travelling allowance because he fraudulently says that he lives in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —His Canberra address is on the electoral roll too.

—His Canberra address is on the electoral roll. So he votes in Canberra but he still says that he lives in Sydney, and he collects a daily travelling allowance. What a fraud this Government is! What sorts of standards does it have? What sort of control does the Prime Minister have over his Cabinet? He has no control at all. If he puts Mick Young out of the Ministry for a while his colleagues put Mick Young in again. The Prime Minister has lost all control over the standards of his Cabinet Ministers. Can we afford to give this country the same again? Can we afford to give this Government a mandate to finish us off? There is no way in the whole world that the people of this country will give this Government a mandate to send them broke and bankrupt, to make Australia a banana republic and to allow this Government to continue its sordid standards and remain in government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —By tradition, this debate gives us the opportunity to examine not only the legislation before us-the Appropriation Bills and Supply Bills-but also related matters of economic management. In today's climate it is proper, too, that we examine the Australian Labor Party's headlong rush into an election, one which it will lose. The folly of Labor's cupidity and poor judgment will become clearer with each week of the campaign. We are pleased that the battle is joined; we are delighted that the election has been called on. We are delighted that we can now take on and tip out this dishonoured, dis- honourable, cynical and opportunistic Labor Government. But the timing of the election is revealing. It is an eloquent statement of what the Government is hiding, of what Labor will not tell us. It is a particularly eloquent statement of the Government's determination to hide from Australians the shape and nature of the Budget to come down in August.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me pose a simple question: What is the difference for this or for any government between an election held in July and an election held in September? Let us acknowledge that there might be some differences. In September, the Government could have an election for only half of the Senate; in July, it could call for a double dissolution. This is being done so that Labor can assist the Australian Democrats to an election in the most propitious circumstances with the smallest possible quota for a Senate election. That is a judgment that the Labor Party has taken. The preservation of the Democrats, after all, is in the interests of the Labor Party. Sadly, it is not in the interests of Australia; nor is it in the interests of the good government of the country. But never mind, we will accommodate that challenge. But the July date is notable too for the opportunity it gives to seek votes without first revealing the shape or nature of the Budget due in August. We will accommodate this, too, because we will ask the Australian people: `What is it that Labor is hiding? Why go in July? Why does it not reveal its Budget? Why does it not wait until the people know what package they are buying? Why buy a pig in a poke?'. We will ensure that Australians know that Labor has bad news hidden until an election is behind us. The election of a Liberal government is the only way to avoid some of the bitterness and betrayal that the election of a Labor government would bring.

The July date is most notable because it gives us, the Liberal Party of Australia, the earliest chance-an earlier chance than we had anticipated-to meet and to defeat the Hawke Government. Since the May economic statement was brought down this is something that I have been hoping for with all my heart and with considerable anticipation-and Labor has now delivered it to us.

Let us look at why this is so. That May economic statement, the so-called mini-Budget, was a cruel and cynical document. It was a typical Labor Party exercise in looking after its mates and its own voters at the expense of the weak and powerless in Australia. It did achieve some savings-very few; too few; some of them illusory, many of them overstated; but these savings have been achieved and can be achieved only at great social cost to this country.

In the areas of health, education and social welfare, Labor will achieve savings. It will do it by reducing protection for the genuinely needy, by increasing barriers to make it more difficult for people to become personally powerful and autonomous with control over their own lives.

Labor has reduced or withdrawn benefits for some people; it has imposed harsher conditions upon welfare access for other people; it has increased waiting periods for yet others. The Labor Party has targeted widows, the unemployed, some families, jobless school leavers, single sickness beneficiaries, widows over the age of 45 years, students, those unlucky enough to have complicated or catastrophic illness, those who are in hospitals as private patients and so on-a sad litany of the most needy and most deserving in our society.

Honourable senators may not be aware that since 1982-83 Labor has already reduced income support for individuals through the social security system as a percentage of total outlays, just as it has reduced support for families since 1982-83. With the economic statement that came down this May, income support programs will be cut again.

The burden of this mini-Budget is to be borne by the weak and politically powerless-in the short term electoral interests of a Labor Party determined not to alienate powerful voting groups. Labor has done all this to the weaker, poorer, needier members of our community-the widows, the students and the unemployed-while leaving most well off, middle class people absolutely or relatively untouched by the economic statement. What an abandonment of the role of protector, initiator, shield and ally that has been the traditional boast of Labor senators and Labor governments. What an eloquent statement of social values and priorities! Labor today preserves tax cuts for those in jobs, including senators, while preaching restraint, belt tightening, benefit withdrawal, harsher conditions and more difficult access for those in greatest need or with the greatest disadvantage. While the weaker and the poorer have taken the brunt of the expenditure cuts, we, the better off, have retained our promised tax cuts and, for the most part, have retained our payments from the welfare budget. Yes, it is a great mini-Budget statement! It hits the weak and it preserves the powerful.

Let us just look at some of the details. Savings have been effected from family allowances; from payments to widows; from levels of payments to the jobless; from benefits to unemployed school leavers; from access to benefits by the young jobless; from single sickness beneficiaries; from widows with student children; from technical and further education, as it tries to add to the skills of the young in Australia; and from higher education, as it tries to make Australia more competitive by training people.

A Sydney economist, Paul Gross, says that the decision to reduce Commonwealth rebates for certain hospital patients will mean higher costs of private health insurance. It might mean that some doctors withdraw from the care of hospital in-patients, and it could mean that certain effective, non-invasive and advanced diagnostic techniques are withheld from patients who need them. All these things are eloquent declarations of priorities and intent. Mr Gross is also aghast at the reduced funding for geriatric assessment teams-one of the cornerstones of any rational policy for aged persons' residential care. What a tragedy it is that Senator Grimes has gone. While he was Minister this would never have happened. The Labor Party is reducing funding for geriatric assessment teams which, of course, help to make people able to cope without going into residential care. If we add to this the decision in the mini-Budget to reduce the Commonwealth commitment to home and community care we see that the vulnerable aged are also being asked to bear an undue proportion of the burden of Labor's cost cutting. Reduced medical rebates, another part of the package, will leave the sick, particularly the chronically ill, with larger net medical bills to pay. What a great priority for targeting cuts! What Labor is doing is saving nothing in absolute terms, but it is shifting costs of medical care from the public sector back to the sick-to the sickest and most vulnerable, to those with major progressive complicated medical disease and to those in hospital. What a statement of priorities that is! Some savings! It is merely a transfer of costs to the weak and needy by a Labor Party out of touch with Australia.

We now know, too, that up to 20,000 qualified young Australians were refused entry to Australian universities and colleges of advanced education this year. We are now told that one of the priorities of the Labor Government, expressed in the mini-Budget papers that came down a week or so ago, is to withdraw yet more money from the higher education sector-an amount of $132 million in a full year. Oh, what a statement of priorities that is! It can mean only less opportunity in education and that less opportunity in education will be one direct outcome of the priorities adopted by the Hawke Labor Government. Not only has the Labor Party reduced its expenditure on education; it has reduced its expenditure on aged persons, in spite of evidence put forward from within its own ranks, from Mrs Marie Coleman, from its own Policy Co-ordination Unit, just to take the case of the aged, that in the next five years-from 1987 to 1991 inclusive-we will see increased numbers of people over the age of 75, increases of the order of 22 per cent. This is no area for expenditure reduction, certainly not while the comfortable and affluent remain untouched.

I am angry at this document, angry at this Government, angry on behalf of so many people called on to suffer so that we, the well off, can all be better off from 1 July. Ross Gittins, the journalist, made this clear in a fine statement in the Sydney Morning Herald when he said that other options might have actually involved those of us who are better off in bearing some of the burden contained in the recent expenditure cuts. He even made specific suggestions of what kind of cuts could have been made to spread the load more equitably than has been done, rather than concentrating it all on the weak and disadvantaged. Some of his proposals are not consistent with the policy of my Party, but no matter; the fact is that he was suggesting that there were ways to spread the expenditure cuts more fairly than has been done. Some of his suggestions do no more than suggest that the well off should share some of the same sacrifices that Labor is demanding from the weak and the poor.

Members of the Liberal Party, those from a philosophical liberal tradition, operate within a different and better philosophical framework. Ours is the political philosophy based on individual persons who come together to create and define and renew and modify and maintain a society. We talk about individuals who have rights and who have needs and, most of all, who have obligations to each other. We believe that individuals acting rationally and with co-operative goodwill can shape society to avoid past errors and to correct injustice. It is not possible to do that if one orders one's priorities to make the weak bear all the burdens and the powerful enjoy all the benefits. We believe that individuals have rights. We believe that individuals should be equally able to participate. We believe, too, that individuals have obligations to each other, and that individuals should be able to pursue their own goals within agreed bounds. On that test of what liberalism is about, we Liberals have to condemn the Labor Government of Bob Hawke. It has displayed no compassion, no sense of obligation, no sympathy and too little fairness in the statement we had in its mini-Budget a fortnight ago.

As David Kemp has written in the past, the overriding goal of liberalism is the realisation of human dignity for all people. Other people have also given us tests for designing public policy. The Harvard philosopher, John Rawl, has added some thoughts about his concept of justice as fairness. It is a useful concept for this debate. Rawl's idea is encapsulated by his challenge to make rules for a society on the assumption that we do not know what role we, individually might be called on to take in that society. For example, we could not assume that we will be senators; we could be anyone in society. He then challenges us by asking: `What would we consider to be a fair society if we might have ended up as someone else?' It is not a bad test.

My vision is of a society where those of us designing and implementing policy can meet Kemp's challenge, can answer the questions of John Rawl and can satisfy the standards of liberal compassion and concern. Although I do not accept that small government is a social goal in itself, or that processes such as deregulation or privatisation are valid political goals in themselves, there are many occasions on which my goals, related to individuals, will be served by reduced government, by lower taxation, by specific acts of deregulation or by some degree of privatisation.
