I do accept, and my colleagues accept, as a proper starting point the extent of the economic crisis facing Australia and of the central need, as part of the solution to that problem, for us to reduce the burden of government on Australian citizens. The argument then shifts to how this might be approached with justice and equity and, in particular, how government might still direct its benefits preferentially towards protecting and empowering those in society whose needs are greatest. I do not believe, as Labor apparently does and as Labor displayed in its mini-Budget, that Australia will be served best by reducing the imposts on the wealthy by removing or reducing the benefits for the needy. That kind of formula, which was displayed clearly in the mini-Budget, is a disgrace in terms of social priorities and social theories. We Liberals want a welfare system that displays efficiency, neutrality, simplicity, fairness and acceptability. They are features that should sound familiar. Most economists agree that those are the features of a good tax system. But if one wanted to add liberal values in welfare, one could include the empowering of individuals, responding to need-one has to accept that the whole concept of need itself is value-dependent-keeping to a minimum the level of unmet need in society, the encouragement of the maximum degree of independence and dignity, and the provision of maximum incentive for self-provision. Yet the Labor Party has not addressed this question fairly in the priorities it has addressed, particularly in its miserable May economic statement.

The statement has been produced, after all, by powerful Ministers, secure on ministerial salaries and with guaranteed political support and pensions. These people have laid the burden of their strategies on the weak and the needy in an unfair and discriminatory way. Whatever else happens, they know that they will not-except perhaps, for some of them who have young children and may suffer some loss of family allowance-be called upon to share in the sacrifice or the burden they are laying on other people. I believe what they have done is morally reprehensible.

I want to say a little about the context in which welfare policy exists in this country. People are fond of attacking welfare expenditure. Some people say that it has increased too fast, that too much of it is wasted and that too many of the recipients are, as people put it, `undeserving'. I will have no part of that. The record shows that since 1982-83 outlays in social security and welfare have increased at the same rate as expenditures on defence. The figures show that income transfers to individuals have increased at a lower rate than have outlays for administration or outlays for subsidies for goods or services. So, let no one tell us that welfare is blowing out quicker than other expenditures. The figures do not bear it out.

It is a sad commentary on the motive power of greed and self-interest that many of those who most criticise cash provision for other people when it is provided through the social welfare system in Australia are the very same people who are at the forefront in advocating the extension of benefits for themselves when they are paid through the taxation system. Too often there is a call to restrict the eligibility for benefits under the social welfare system and a simultaneous and associated call-a demand, in fact-that benefits available through tax rebates be extended. It is even sadder that a Labor Government has taken such a clear position against the neediest and the most vulnerable while leaving the strongest and most affluent relatively unscathed. The Labor Party clearly has no qualms when it comes to choosing between the desires of the powerful and the needs of the weak. It chooses the powerful all the time. Where hard choices have to be made, the Liberal Party will generally favour the weak and the poorest and the claims of needs-based programs. As a result of this Labor mini-Budget, life will be harder particularly for the poorer in society, but also for many more.

Mr Deputy President, I put it to you and to the Senate that extended middle class welfare should not be favoured in any but times of the greatest national affluence. More middle class welfare should not be favoured especially when unmet social need is great and when a national economic crisis demands that expenditure is limited where it can be. Given the dimensions of the economic crisis facing Australia today, the Liberal Party will give the highest priority still to the requirements of the most needy and give lowest priority to the welfare demands of the affluent. It is tragic that Labor did not do that in the mini-Budget honourable senators had to listen to a fortnight ago. Just by concentrating on the most needy, members of the Liberal Party believe we can achieve the welfare savings necessary to help overcome part of the economic crisis.

A Government with a littered path of broken promises behind it is taking us to an early election in an attempt to hide the Budget it was due to bring down in August. The Australian people will understand that. They understand that the reason for the election is phoney and contrived. They understand that there is no legitimate reason of government to take the nation to an election in July. We know that following the election a Liberal government will have to pick up the pieces and try to do something about the economic mess it will inherit. It will do that against the background of an Australia with reduced living standards for all, trade unions being given undue power and higher taxes year by year.

Since March 1983 when this Government took office, the weekly tax bill of the family on average weekly earnings has risen by $65 dollars a week. It has more than doubled, to more than $100 a week. Those Australians with home loans have to pay off their mortgages at a rate of something like $200 or more extra every month. The same families are having to pay more than $5 a week extra for private health insurance which many people in Australia are determined to maintain because it is their life line to treatment in times of crisis. These same families have received a real increase in wages after inflation is discounted of only $9 a week. Those families are now considerably worse off than they were previously.

The Liberal Party has a story to tell the Australian people; it has a message to take to them-a message of hope and renewal. It is a message of social priorities that will encourage those who are less advantaged rather than the priorities that were set out in the disgraceful mini-Budget which came down two weeks ago and which seemed to target the weak, the needy, the unemployed and the widows with such viciousness and which apparently gave the Labor Party such pride. Members of the Liberal Party look forward to the election; it cannot come quickly enough for us. We have wanted the chance to tip this Government out and we are now getting that chance. Although the Senate gets up next week, we look forward to being back here a few weeks later and sitting on the other side of the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Opposition's amendment to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1986-87. It is appropriate for the Senate to take note of some of the points raised earlier in the debate by Senator Messner. The amendments refer to the decision to call an early election without informing the Australian people of the content of the August 1987 Budget; the Government's continued mismanagement of the economy, which has caused widespread and growing concern among Australians about their future; its continued mismanagement of the economy, which has caused a sustained reduction in the living standards of all Australians, particularly Australian families with young children, to which Senator Peter Baume has just referred; the fundamental weaknesses in the nation's economy, as indicated by a declining economic growth rate; an inflation rate of four times that of our major trading partners; record relative interest rates; an overseas debt burden of $105 billion; the value of the Australian dollar being cut by one-third; and the failure of the Government to implement in its May economic statement the genuine expenditure cuts necessary to restore balance to its policies and reduce interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Australian people why the Government is running scared and wanting to have an early election; an early election which, only some time ago, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had said was not on the cards. The Prime Minister tells us we should trust him, but he said there would be no way there would be an early election and that the Parliament would definitely go to the end of the year or, most probably, into 1988. Why is the Prime Minister having an early election? I say he is running scared-running scared because this Government is not game to bring down the August Budget. It will be left to the Liberal Party when it wins the election to do that, and that will be a good thing for Australia as it will do something that will make the country the beautiful place it used to be.

Is the Government calling the early election because of the industrial relations legislation lying on the table in the other place? I hope the Australian people will take full note of the fact that that legislation has been hastily withdrawn and laid on the table in the House of Representatives so that this cynical election could be called and the ire of all the people in the community would not be brought down at this stage on the Government. When people consider the legislation, they will see the damage it will do to the whole of the community. It puts the trade union movement well above any other people in the community; it puts the trade union movement in a position of power that it has never had before. The legislation is lying on the table in the other place ready to be put in place if the Government is returned. Thank goodness the Government has given us the opportunity of fighting an election so that we can make sure that the legislation does not see the light of day.

Why a double dissolution? I would have thought that if one wanted good, solid government on one side or the other, one would not have a lot of Independents in the Senate. One would not have the Australian Democrats in the Senate to go cap in hand to every time one wanted legislation passed. Obviously a deal has been done between the Democrats and the Labor Government because the Democrats have voted with the Labor Party more times than it has voted against it. The Democrats will obviously be expected by the Labor Party to come up with the goodies if, perchance, it is re-elected. The Australian people must realise that if the Labor Government is returned to power and if people vote for the Democrats, they will be voting in the industrial relations legislation currently lying on the table in the other place, along with all the other nasties that are just around the corner.

As I have said, the Liberal Party has been given the opportunity of winning the next election, and it will win the next election and it will get Australia back on its feet so the country will no longer be led down the garden path as it has been over the last five years of the Hawke Labor Government. Australia's current inflation rate is around 9.4 per cent. During the last calendar year, it was 9.8 per cent. The inflation rate in the United States is 1.1 per cent, Japan's inflation rate is only 0.2 per cent and West Germany has an inflation rate of minus 1 per cent. I refer to an article, which was received in my office only today, from the National Australia Bank `Monthly Summary' which states, in part:
According to the leading article in the June `Summary', inflation in Australia is likely to remain disturbingly high and out of line with other Western economies.
Such chronic inflation, the bank suggests will dissipate the benefits of the depreciation of the Australian dollar and may trigger further devaluations leading to a prices/wages spiral.

So, that is just around the corner, if we cannot get this country back on the road. That will be the case if we cannot win this next election, although, as I have just said, we will win that election, now that we have been given the opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will win.

—Of course we will win, because the Australian people will not be fooled by a cynical Prime Minister. Mr Hawke has tried to fool the people of Australia for too long. Just because he thinks he has some charisma-you know `old silver', who has charisma-when the people out there realise that they have been hoodwinked yet again by this Prime Minister they will vote accordingly. They will vote with their pockets and with their heads; they will demonstrate that they want the Liberal and National parties to have a go at governing this country, to ensure that it returns to the way that it used to be before the present Prime Minister and this discredited Labor Government came to power.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to our living standards. Every time something happens in Australia, one of the Labor Party Ministers blames it on the bad market prices that prevail or on something else that is occurring elsewhere in the world. However, I suggest to them that these situations have occurred before. We have had bad market prices in the past but we have not had factors pertaining to a high inflation rate or to the cost of production prevalent in Australia as is the case at the moment. In the past, when we had Liberal and National Party governments in Australia, we were able to live with the bad commodity prices, as we did not have the price spiral or our input costs to contend with. At the moment the thing that is killing especially the farming community is the input costs; it is not so much the commodity prices on the world markets. This is the biggest taxing government in peacetime history. In 1986-87, receipts from tax accounted for something like 25.5 per cent of the gross domestic product. Government outlays as percentages of the GDP in the four Keating Budgets have been the largest in post-war history, averaging 29.2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The more times you repeat it the better.

—That is right. Would the honourable senator like it from the start? This Government's outlays as a percentage of the GDP in the four Keating Budgets have been the largest in post-war history, averaging 29.2 per cent. This the biggest spending government in peacetime history.
—That means that it is the biggest taxing government too.

—It is the biggest taxing government. It is the biggest everything. Those in the Government are the biggest muckers-up of the economy that this country has ever had. The votes in the ballot box will certainly indicate what the people of Australia think of the Government. The size of government in 1986-87, even after the mini-Budget, is still larger than the average size of government under Mr Fraser. In relation to interest rates, everyone thinks that the Government has done something about bringing down interest rates, but it has done nothing about that. The Government has not done a thing about bringing down interest rates in this country. Most probably the American economy has had a bigger effect on bringing down our interest rates than has the Government. To give the Government a little bit of praise-maybe for the first time in some time-the Government has pulled the Reserve Bank off the back of the dollar, with the bank no longer holding up the dollar. It may be that that has helped a little.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the prime commercial rate for loans over $100,000, in February 1983 in Australia the rate was 14 per cent, while in February 1987, just four years later, the interest rate was 18.25 per cent. Of course, while our interest rate in Australia is 18.25 per cent, I point out that those in other countries are: United States of America, 12 per cent; Japan, 3.75 per cent; Italy, 7.5 per cent; and Canada, 9.75 per cent. Further, in 1983 Bankcard customers were paying 18 per cent but they are now paying 20 per cent for their money. In 1983, overdrafts under $100,000 attracted a rate of 13.5 per cent to 14 per cent, while now the interest rate is something like 20 per cent. What about people who are paying off their homes, those who have taken the average loan for their house? Those people are now paying $50 a week more because of the policies of the Hawke-Keating Labor Government. In New South Wales, since 1984 the average loan repayment has increased from some $472 a month to $678 a month. It is all very well for Senator Evans to smile and laugh about the economy, as he did a little while ago, but I point out that the people who are paying those interest rates on home loans will have the chance on 11 July, when this prematurely called election will take place, to indicate what they think about those high interest rates and the problems that they are having in paying off their homes.

The present Government is supposed to be one that cares about the family and one that is concerned about the need for young Australian families to have homes of their own. However, I would venture to say, when considering some of the legislation that has been brought into this place, that the Government is more interested in the big monied interests of Australia-the big companies-than in the average Australian family. I refer to health care costs, which Senator Peter Baume mentioned earlier. Before Medicare, the net weekly cost of medical and private cover for a family on average weekly earnings was $9.66 but by the end of 1986 that had increased to $14.30. That is an increase of nearly 50 per cent. During 1986, health care costs rose by some 26 per cent. In those circumstances one cannot consider that the economy is under control and on the right road. Thank goodness that we have been given the chance to vote this Government out of power.

I could go on for quite some time talking about the problems in the economy and the fact that this Government has a total disregard for the ordinary people in Australia. By means of the mini-Budget the Government has thrown various costs back to the States. Supposedly, some $1.6 billion has been cut off the Federal Budget-although this is a bit shonky-but it has asked the States to cut $2 billion off their Budgets. One would think that the party asking for the cutting to be done would lead from the front and not from behind. But that is not the case and the Federal Government will have to contend with less in cutbacks than it has asked the States to endure. Of course, the States will have to pass on the costs involved, and that will cause further inflation. In turn, that will cause further problems for the ordinary people in Australia going about their business in the workplace.

Before concluding, I shall quote from some comments that were made about the outlook for the Australian economy. I shall be brief because I know that Senator Hill wants to say something in this very important debate. I refer to an article by David Potts published in the Australian newspaper on 14 May 1987. This article relates to the economy and to the fact that all that is likely to occur in the foreseeable future is that the inflation rate will rise by 7.25 per cent. That is wonderful, is it not? It is still probably at least seven times more than that of some of our trading partners. David Potts says that the slump means that worse might be still to come. He goes on to say:
Missing altogether-
he is talking about the mini-Budget-
is an account of where we have come from and where we are going.
We are told the forward estimates of spending rose. But we are told nothing of revenues, or of the likely Budget deficit we face.

A minute ago Senator Peter Baume made the point that taxes will go up under Labor. The so-called tax cuts that it talks about will leave a single income family with dependent children $15 a week worse off than it was four years ago. What a wonderful thing to give to the Australian people! David Potts goes on:
Mr Keating told us the deficit next year would now be `under 1 per cent of GDP'. This is a limit of $2.9 billion. We know spending will be $78.4 billion, which means revenues must be $81.3 billion.
So the hidden figure is a 14 per cent rise in revenues, compared with a rise of 11 per cent last year.

There will be more revenues, more money coming into the till. By a sleight of hand or a devious little trick, this Government is trying to fool the Australian people that the economy is on the good side of being bad rather than what it is-on the bad side of being good. I repeat what David Potts said:
So the hidden figure is a 14 per cent rise in revenues, compared with a rise of 11 per cent last year.
I have repeated that because I think it is well worth doing. He continues:
We do not know yet how much taxing this will be because we do not know how much the Reserve Bank is going to make from its increasingly lucrative foreign exchange dealings.

This Government has not told all the people all the truth all the time. It is high time that it told the truth even a little of the time. I am quite sure that during the next few weeks of the election campaign we will expose this Government for what it is doing: It is playing charades with the Australian people.

Let us look at the rural sector. This Government has done nothing for it, except to make the lives of people in it more difficult. It has saddled the rural economy with massive interest rate problems. It is overseeing an economic environment in which our goods are unable to be afforded by most of our trading partners. Even in the death throes of the Hawke-Keating Labor Government it is saddling the rural community with unnecessary legislation, forcing statutory authorities such as the Australian Wool Corporation to adopt equal opportunity guidelines. That is an example of one of the things that it is doing at the moment. The industrial relations legislation is lying on the table in the other place, to be brought out from under the carpet if this Government were ever to be given another chance.

With rural Australia in danger of suffering a major collapse, what does this Government do? It runs to the polls to avoid the problems. It is not game to bring in the August Budget first. It pushes through useless legislation that will simply push up costs in the short term. The average income of farmers this financial year will be only something like $9,300; we can understand the problem. That is an increase on last year's figure of $2,000, but it is still less than half the average weekly earnings. The average real rate of return on capital for all the farm industries has fallen to minus 6.9 per cent, and land values are down 30 per cent. This Government should be condemned for what it is-a government that has led a country with so much potential, which had so much going for it, down the road to economic ruin. I am sure the people of Australia will condemn the Government for that in the 11 July election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This cognate debate on the Supply and Appropriation Bills provides an opportunity to examine the economic malaise that besets Australia and this Government's very significant contribution to it. The economic indicators show Australia to be in dire straits. In 1986 Australia's economic growth was a mere 1.4 per cent, lower than that of all Western nations except Greece and New Zealand. In 1987-88 the Government is hoping for a 2.5 per cent growth, in itself a reflection on the failure of the Government which earlier forecast a 3.5 per cent growth. The motor vehicle industry, an important industry in my home State of South Australia, experienced in 1986 the lowest level of new motor vehicle registrations since 1972-a mere 526,000 registrations. The forecast for 1987 is a maximum of 500,000 new registrations which would be the lowest since 1969. Regrettably, according to figures made available today, it now appears that it will more likely be about 460,000, the April registrations being 20,000 less than for April 1986, a 38 per cent fall.

SPEECH.PARA: Housing is well below Budget forecasts. Approvals and commencements are down by 17 per cent on the same period in the last financial year. The number of new commencements this financial year is likely to be only 118,000, well below the minimum 135,000 promised under the Government's housing package. A record number of people is on public housing waiting lists-154,400 compared with 109,800 before Labor came to power. This 154,400 includes 40,000 applications on behalf of 100,000 individuals in South Australia. Despite this, $52m has been cut from housing in South Australia. This could mean a reduction of 1,000 homes in a building program of some 3,000 homes. This is against a backdrop of 100,000 homeless in this, the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless.

As one moves through the various indices the same depressing picture recurs. In the labour market unemployment remains unnecessarily high. The number of unemployed has risen by 64,000 in the first 10 months of 1986-87 to a total of 641,000. The unemployment rate similarly rose from 7.5 per cent to 8.3 per cent. It is worth remembering that the unemployment plateau averaged 5 per cent under the Fraser Government; under the Hawke Government the rate has been 8 per cent. The average duration of unemployment also has risen dramatically in the last four years of the Labor Government, from 35 weeks to 50 weeks in March 1987.

The youth unemployment rate of 23.1 per cent is higher than when Labor announced the Priority One program in August 1985, despite traineeships, Austudy and all the public relations that we experienced following the introduction of Priority One. Australia's rate of increase in labour costs is still almost twice that of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development nations-7 to 8 per cent as opposed to 4 per cent. It is little wonder that industry is making such little headway in the international market-place, despite the readily eroding value of the Australian dollar. Australia's inflation rate remains disturbingly high. At 9.4 per cent, it is some five times that of our major trading partners. If one looks at the Government's expectation of 7.25 per cent in 1987-88 one sees that that is still a mere four times the rate of those trading partners. Under the Hawke Labor Government Australia's inflation rate has exceeded the OECD average every year. I suggest that this is hardly surprising considering, for instance, the 18 per cent rise in the health and personal care group of the consumer price index in the last year, reflecting the Government's Budget measures. The May statement effects have yet to be reflected in the CPI, but no doubt they will maintain the surge of Labor health cost increases.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break, in the context of debating the Supply and Appropriation Bills, I was referring to a few of the economic indices which indicate the mess this Government has made of the Australian economy. I had reached the stage of referring to Australia's balance of payments, which under this Government has deteriorated in the last few years. In 1985-86 our current account deficit was $14.4 billion or 6 per cent of gross domestic product. A current account deficit of that proportion of GDP was last experienced in 1951-52. Australia's figure was the second highest in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The forecast for 1987 is that Australia will maintain that position-not surprisingly, when our current account deficits appear to be averaging about $1 billion a month.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the lamentable state of Australia's foreign debt. Australia's gross foreign debt has grown alarmingly under Labor. The lame excuse we hear from Labor Ministers, that takeover activities are the cause, simply does not stand up to examination, because $41 billion of our approximately $105 billion foreign debt is in the public sector. That debt has grown faster than the debt of the private sector over the four years of the Labor Government. Australian gross foreign debt has risen threefold under Labor, from $36 billion in June 1983 to, as I said, $105 billion in December 1986. Our net indebtedness is much the same, having risen from $23 billion to $81 billion. Related to our debt situation has been the collapse of the value of the dollar under this Labor Government.

I could not but mention interest rates. Under this Government interest rates are at record levels. Home loan interest rates of savings banks are at a record 15.5 per cent, compared with 11.5 per cent at the time of the last election. The same record rates are contributing to the downturn of the motor vehicle and housing industries, which I mentioned before the dinner break, and to the unacceptable level of bankruptcies and business failures that we are experiencing. These interest rates are harming consumers and businesses alike and I would respectfully suggest they record a sorry indictment of this Government's policies.

Taxation has been the hallmark of this Government. The Government might like to be reminded of a few of its initiatives in this area-a new higher tax regime for lump sum superannuation payments; biannual indexation of excise on alcohol, tobacco and petroleum; the Medicare levy of 1 per cent, and now 1.25 per cent; a wine tax of 10 per cent and now 20 per cent that particularly hits producers in my home State of South Australia; abolition of the concessional expenditure rebate; abolition of negative gearing; removal of the Medicare levy limit; disallowance of entertainment expenditure; disallowance of investment allowance; capital gains tax; fringe benefits tax; substantiation provisions; reduction of objection rights; new sales tax; large increases in petrol excise; an increase in the corporate tax rate from 46 per cent to 49 per cent; and of course, the foreign tax credit system. Similarly, in the wings we now have the threat of the resource rent tax.

I would suggest that is quite a record. Even after the 1 July tax cuts are in place, all single income families with a dependent spouse will be paying a higher proportion of their income in pay as you earn tax than in March 1983. For a single income family on average weekly earnings the average tax rate will have increased from 17.5 per cent in March 1983 to 20.5 per cent in July 1987. Its marginal tax rate increased from 30 per cent to 40 per cent. After July this year such families will still require an additional income tax cut of $15 a week just to restore them to the same average tax rate position they faced when the Hawke Government came to office.

These calculations reveal that the 1 December 1986 and 1 July 1987 income tax cuts merely give back to taxpayers some of the additional tax that four years of fiscal drag has taken from them. Despite $3.6 billion in cuts in government outlays, the May mini-Budget maintains the Hawke Government's status as a big spending, big taxing government. Even including the once-off assets sales and deferrals contained in the $3.6 billion figure, outlays in 1987-88 will still be around 27.4 per cent of GDP. By subtracting for assets sales this figure rises to 27.8 per cent. This figure compares with an average in the Fraser Government period of 27.1 per cent.

The cuts the Government has made have been made from a very high base. Had the Government adopted a greater restraint in spending in its earlier years, particularly 1984-85, current expenditure would be at a considerably lower level today. If Government outlays had increased at the Fraser Government average of 2.1 per cent during the last four years instead of at around 4 per cent, total outlays over the four-year period would have been almost $20 billion less and the Budgets would have been in surplus in both 1985-86 and 1986-87. This is the background against which these pieces of legislation are debated. As I suggested, it records a sorry state of affairs.

The Supply Bills provide interim appropriations for the services of government, expenditure on capital works and services and payments to the States and the parliamentary departments. The extent of the increases in interim appropriations is illuminating as they involve increases on last year's amounts of 8.2 per cent, 13.6 per cent and 11.2 per cent respectively. These figures do not suggest any restraint in government spending at all. The May economic statement was a prelude to the cuts cynically passed on to the States at the Premiers Conference. When one examines these figures carefully one finds that the Federal Government is not interested in restraint. What it has done is purely cosmetic. For 1987-88 the Government has claimed that it will reduce spending by $2.641 billion. Take out the deferrals of expenditure, the minor asset transactions and the buck-passing in the expenditure cuts to the States and local government and the actual figure is much less. To be more specific, if the figure is then reduced by $1 billion for the buck-passing to the States, $350m for defence deferral, $180m for roads deferral, $41m for housing deferral, $7m for local government deferral, $90m for Telecom and Australia Post buck-passing, $82m from the sale of minor assets and capital items, $10m for cancellation of the civil works capital item, $7m for national broadcasting deferral and $10m for the engineering assistance deferral, the total is reduced by a total of $1,797m. Actual expenditure cuts in real terms then come down to only $844m.

The Government has done everything but restrain its own spending. It has lavished money on every fringe group, supported its trade union mates and wasted money. The Opposition's Waste Watch Committee has only just scratched the surface in this area. There is duplication between the three levels of government and enormous waste at each level. Only recently it was reported that the Economic Planning Advisory Council and the Advisory Council on Prices and Incomes will be merged. In many areas of government there are overlaps, duplication and sheer waste but I ask the question, as it has been asked so many times before: Where is the action by this Government?

A recent Senate Estimates committee hearing provided some revealing answers concerning the Government's application of public moneys to promoting, and what it spends on promoting, or selling, its new taxes. I refer specifically to Estimates Committee C and to the advertising campaign on the Government's taxation measures on which it spent $7.197m in 1986-87. Some of that money is for routine advertising and $2.75m relates purely to selling and promoting in the community the Government's fringe benefits tax. The response of officers of the Australian Taxation Office suggests another year of big advertising spending in 1987-88 if this Government remains in office because there are a host of measures to sell-principally, again, the fringe benefits tax and also substantiation, the quarterly payment of provisional tax, the capital gains tax and dividend imputation. The massive advertising campaign for the fringe benefits tax was approved by the Government after its review of the tax in October 1986 when it found that it was a liability and that it needed to be hosed down as an issue.

It is not surprising that the firm retained for polling to provide the research for the campaign was the Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd, the Australian Labor Party's pollster. No doubt it provided daily advice to the Government on the public mood. It received $135,000 for its efforts in selling to the public the fringe benefits tax. Furthermore, not only was $135,000 paid to ANOP but also $221,000 was spent on public relations. It was paid to the firm of Hill and Knowlton. When officers of the Department of the Treasury were questioned about what this firm had to do to earn $221,000, the answer from Mr Gleeson was that essentially it had to come up with ideas for dealing with aspects of the Government's tax reform measures. So that firm was to be paid $221,000 to come up with ideas on how to sell the Government's tax package. Later Mr Gleeson elaborated, when he stated:
As I indicated before, essentially the firm was engaged to undertake the strategic and creative ideas for dealing with the tax reform awareness program.

It did that for $221,000. This is how this Government wastes taxpayers' money, while at the same time talking about how we must all share the burden. As all of the contracts with ANOP, advertising firms and Hill and Knowlton are deemed to be commercially in confidence they have not been made available to the Estimates committee. So much for this Government's accountability. The lines of control and the agencies responsible for recruiting these private sector suppliers of services are intriguing in themselves. The Information Co-ordination Branch of the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism engaged the advertising firms of Magnus Nankervis and Curl DDB, USP Needham Australia Pty Ltd, and Monahan Dayman Adams, while the Treasury engaged the services of ANOP for polling and Hill and Knowton for public relations. More curiously, the Treasury was not directly involved in briefing the advertising agencies. ANOP was responsible for this function while the managing of the advertising agency was helped by the Information and Co-ordination Branch of the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism.

It is little wonder that Treasury and Taxation Office officials were unable to provide satisfactory answers to the Committee's questions. Their answers were quite inadequate, confused and showed they were completely unprepared for what should have been reasonably expected Estimates questions. The awarding of contracts to advertising agencies was done in an extraordinarily short time-about a week from when the proposals were submitted. It is a great pity that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is not so expeditious with responses to Estimates Committee C in relation to the matters I have outlined. Hearings were held on 31 March and 3 April but no response was received from the Treasurer's office until 26 May. That is more than seven weeks for a response.

The campaign to sell Labor's tax changes, I regret to say, is part of the Government's wider self-promotion campaign at public expense of which we have given so many examples to the Senate over the last few years. Labor failed its test with its May economic statement. As I have said, the statement was merely an opportunity to set the scene for an election. The initial welcome reception given the statement has given way to scepticism. Syntec Economic Services Pty Ltd highlighted the fact that in the space of a few weeks the inflation forecast has risen a full percentage point. The Brisbane Daily Sun noted that families with teenage children have been hit hardest in the economic statement. The Australian Financial Review questioned why the economic statement did not hit harder and more equitably. David Potts, of the Australian, summed it up well when he said:
Paul Keating has just pulled a swiftie over the media and the market.

In conclusion, this Government has failed to make the tough decisions that are necessary to put this economy back on an even keel. Never has it been more apparent that a change of government is necessary in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have several small points that I would like to raise concerning the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. One of the answers given to the Estimates committee was that the affidavit presented to the Supreme Court of Australia by the Secretary to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet in the Peter Wright case was endorsed by the Australian Government. Will the Government be providing further assistance to the Thatcher Government in the latter's appeal against the original judgment? I would be pleased to get a view on this. We have also some questions which follow from the material supplied by the Department in relation to the closure of the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations. Until the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations Act is repealed, if it ever is, there is a formal annual reporting and auditing requirement of which the Department should have been aware. There is also the point that the ACIR was subject only to directions given at a Premiers Conference. The request of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for it to wind up its affairs was clearly beyond his power. I ask: Has there been any formal Premiers Conference decision to abandon the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations as required under section 4 of the Council's Act? The Department claims that the Commonwealth, the State and the Northern Territory are involved in a rationalisation exercise to identify and remove significant areas of overlapping administration. Can the Minister provide some details about who is conducting this exercise, whether any of the proceedings are public, and when any of the results can be expected?

SPEECH.PARA: While the Minister is seeking advice I would like to raise another matter. At Estimates Committee A hearings officers from the Office of Multicultural Affairs seemed very vague about their eventual numbers and about quite a few of their duties. Has the Government arrived at a final staffing figure and a statement of structure and functions now that more than nine months have passed since the decision to abandon the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs as a savings exercise? Last week there were advertisements for five senior positions and in each case a salary of $40,000-odd was offered. One of the job descriptions was basically that of a manager of propaganda to be sent out to the ethnic media. Is there now a timetable for filling all the positions in the Office of Multicultural Affairs? What are the Government's plans in this area because I believe that all three aspects are extremely important in terms of the decision which people will have to make in choosing a future government at the forthcoming election?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know, nor do the officers present, about the Wright case. From my recollection, staff numbers in the Office of Multicultural Affairs within the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet are to be of the order of 30.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year, after the 1986-87 Budget, we had Estimates committee hearings at which I asked the Department of Defence a number of questions on notice. I received no answers to those questions on notice. On 27 November, during the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1), I asked very specific questions concerning restrictions on exercise resources for the Australian Defence Force. These were the questions which I asked on notice at the Estimates committee hearings last September:

SPEECH.PARA: What were the bids for exercise resources for 1986-87?
Has the Government applied restrictions?
What restrictions if any have been placed on flying hours for the RAAF . . .?
Have any reductions been made in steaming time for the Navy . . .?
Have exercise hours for the Army been cut?
If in fact restrictions have been applied, is it not true that they will seriously impair training for the next financial year?

I received a wordy answer at the Estimates committee hearings to the effect that, overall, the major activities of the Services were expected to be held at about the same level as achieved in 1985-86. In other words, I received no specific answers to very specific questions. I also asked again whether my questions would be answered and I gave these questions as examples:

What is the average number of exercises held per infantry battalion in the last year? What is the average number of exercises per infantry battalion intended for the coming year? How many times will the brigades exercise and when will the next divisional exercise be held?
During the debate on the Appropriation Bills former Senator Grimes, in answer to my questions, said:

Senator Newman has given some examples of questions for which she received unsatisfactory answers on anybody's judgment. Senator Michael Baume did the same . . . Senator Sir John Carrick has been trying to get an answer for three months on a certain matter. I would not be too pleased if that happened to me . . .
He went on to say:

I think there is a need to reform the system . . . If Senator Newman's experience of questions on notice is anything to go by, that is not fine at all. I think we really have to come to grips with this matter . . . I will seek proper answers to the questions that Senator Newman asked.

I am not in a position to know whether former Senator Grimes did seek answers. But, as I understand the system in this Parliament, the departments are very well aware of what takes place during these Appropriation debates. I have still not received answers to any of those very specific questions and I question the attitude of the Defence Department in continually refusing to answer proper questions put to it in a proper form on notice. I even dispute whether they should have needed to be on notice, but on notice they were. I now ask the Government whether it can obtain answers to the questions I asked first of all last September. I would also like to have the same questions answered for the current year.

Since then we have had the mini-Budget. We all know that $350m has been cut from the defence budget. There has been very little objection to this and I think it is largely because the populace is perhaps not taking a proper interest in defence. It does not mean to say that it is not a matter to which we in the Senate should give serious consideration. It is obviously of vital importance that our country is properly defended. This Government is prepared to cut $350m off the top priority for any government in this country-that is, to protect its citizens. It does so because its natural constituency is probably not there and it will not worry at the polls about what the soldiers think. I can tell the Government that there are plenty of other people who really worry about what it is doing to the defence forces. We are very aware of what has happened to the bright and shining White Paper that was produced a few short weeks ago, that was going to be such a marvellous new world for the defence of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just words.

—They are just glossy words. But we would like to know now just where those cuts in the mini-Budget will fall. Will it be in the area of operating costs? Will it be in the steaming, flying and exercise time? What about man days for the Reserve? The Reserve has just been given a role. We can hear the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) saying: `Highlighted-a role for the Reserve'. Proper it is that the Reserve should have an identifiable role, but the man days that it had previously will in no way enable it to deal with its new role. What do we find? Inevitably, the man days for the Reserve, post mini-Budget, will have to be cut. I can see no alternative for the Government, and that is a disgrace.

—Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. I do not believe that any of this self-indulgence by Senator Newman has anything to do with Appropriation Bill (No. 3) because that concerns this financial year and the May statement concerns the next financial year.
—Senator Newman must be relevant to the estimates before the Committee, which is this year's appropriations. I ask her to address her remarks to that area.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman. Senator Walsh may be the Minister for Finance but it is quite clear that he does not seem to know about the way the five-year defence plan--
—I am just sick of your egomania.

—Abuse does not make much difference as we are pretty used to that from the Minister. Clearly, the problem in the defence forces is one of the morale of the personnel. It is very clear that this matter has been proceeding for the four years that this Government has been in office. If Senator Walsh is concerned about what I might say about the future let me remind him that in the four years that this Government has been in office defence personnel in this country have been leaving the forces in droves. We have paid good taxpayers' dollars to train those people whom he is currently being too miserly to support and keep in the forces. He was prepared to cut 2 per cent out of the base of their future pensions, and they will not forget him for that.

SPEECH.PARA: It looks as though the deferral of the service allowances is inevitable. At least half a billion dollars is owing to the defence forces for the extra hours that they work without any chance of overtime. Service people are currently working approximately 53 hours per week with none of the assistance which the Minister's mates in the Australian Council of Trade Unions expect as a right to be handed to them on a silver platter. It is very convenient to forget those defence forces and to make noises in this place and try to shout me down, but I can tell the Minister that there are Reserve officers and men throughout this country and their mates who know exactly what this Government has done to them.

At this stage I do not want to go on to deal with the way that this Government is not maintaining its defence property, because that comes under Group C. I will refer to that later. But I suspect that, once again, that is one of the ways in which this Government will be saving money shortly on the defence vote. There is no reason for this Government to bring out glossy papers at great cost after the many man-hours-man-years, if you like-of work that went into first the Dibb report of the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and then into the Government's White Paper while continuing to refuse to recognise the basic problem facing the Defence Force; that is, the question of morale of the forces that are trained at such great cost. If the Government ignores the personnel problems, if it cuts back on training and the operating costs and maintenance of defence assets, the you beaut subs, the frigates and the radar systems might as well be placed in mothballs. We will have no one to operate them expect `Rambo' Beazley.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is: That the votes in Group B stand as printed.

—Mr Chairman, am I to assume from that that the questions are too difficult?

—Mr Chairman, I assume that some of the gentlemen sitting in the Ministers' advisers' seats are from the Department of Defence. I would find it very strange if somebody cannot advise this Minister who seems to know nothing about such a large part of the Government's Budget. I have asked some very specific questions of the Minister and of the Government. I asked them last year. The Department of Defence did not see fit to answer them then. I am calling on the Minister now to obtain those answers. If the questions are too hard for him to answer, I ask him to give a guarantee that he will obtain answers to them and let the Senate have them. When will he do it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support very strongly what Senator Newman has said. I think it is about time that this Parliament expressed its disgust at the performance of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is at the table now. Apart from the personal abuse that he has been levelling at Senator Newman and others in this place for far too long, he is abusing the privileges and the rights of members of this Parliament. It is the right and the responsibility of members of the Parliament on this side of the chamber to ask the questions that Senator Newman and other honourable senators have been asking of the Department of Defence, the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and other departments for months and months now. For the Minister for Finance to refuse even to acknowledge the dilatoriness of departments and their Ministers in supplying this information is to treat this Parliament with a contempt that does neither this Government nor the parliamentary and democratic system of this country any good at all. As parliamentarians, regardless of which side of the chamber we sit on, we are here to represent the interests of Australians, and we are here to ask right and proper questions of Ministers and their departments. There could be no more important ministry of state than the one which provides for the defence of this nation. I find it quite extraordinary that the Minister refuses to acknowledge or even say that he will follow up questions, the answers to which are still outstanding.

SPEECH.PARA: A White Paper on the whole area of defence was released only a month ago. As Senator Newman said, it was supposed to be a show piece of this Government. Decisions have been taken in the last few weeks, particularly in the May mini-Budget, which show every sign of blowing that White Paper strategy to pieces. The questions that have been asked in Estimates committees do relate to this year, but I am sure that Senator Walsh would be the first to acknowledge that one year's spending cannot be separated from that of the next year when it comes to looking at sensible approaches to major items of government activity such as the defence budget. I say to Senator Walsh again that I believe that he does all of us in the Parliament a great disservice by refusing to acknowledge the need for answers to right and legitimate questions that any senator in this place puts, whether they come from this side of the chamber or from the Minister's own side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am appalled at what I see happening. We are here as part of what is supposedly a House of review. It is indeed a case of penny-wise and pound-foolish that we are seeing from Senator Walsh at this stage. We came in here with a co-operative attitude towards trying to determine a few extra matters concerning the Estimates committees. The Department of Defence is one of the worst departments in terms of its performance at Estimates committee hearings. It turns up with 100 or so people for a couple of days. These people find that they cannot answer the questions, so they are actually put on notice, although they are quite simple, referring to such things as the contents of the annual report. Nobody of the 100 or so people can actually answer these questions and the Minister agrees to this. We keep being told that some of the issues which are being dealt with are policy issues and we put these questions on notice.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to Senator Walsh that there is no way that the people of Australia who do believe in the Senate will put up with this type of behaviour from a so-called Minister of a government which I believe is being discredited by this type of behaviour. I would like Senator Walsh to actually endeavour to get those answers. In the meantime, I will ask him a few simple questions relating to the Attorney-General's Department, which is also covered in the area we are debating. The Minister is obviously not properly briefed in the defence area-although he is the best that the Government can present to us. Perhaps he will then have a chance to at least give a reasonable, sensible and civil answer to Senator Newman. I know that he believes that he has, in fact, the control of this situation because he has a guillotine device. But that particular type of power can be removed as easily as it is given. I put that on notice. This Senate is responsible for the business of the Senate and there is no way that, just because the Minister happens to be in Government, he can get away with insulting people who are elected to be here to represent the people of Australia. That type of insult is quite unsatisfactory.

Anyway, I return to the Attorney-General's Department. Some of the information which was supplied to the Committee by the Attorney-General's Department has been downright misleading. We were told during the Estimates committee proceedings that the yacht in which members of the Orionia community landed in Australia was handed over to authorised representatives of Orionia Ltd, Israel, on the basis of documentary evidence produced by that company which, in the eye of our Attorney-General's Department, was sufficient, in the view of the Commonwealth legal representatives, to establish that the yacht was owned by Orionia Ltd, Israel. I was basically quoting that evidence. I believe this is quite misleading, from information that has come to my knowledge. No one, indeed, disputes that Orionia Ltd Israel owns the schooner in question. What is in dispute is the control of Orionia Ltd Israel and who is authorised to represent that company here. That is the nub of the question, which has seen two people, a certain Dr Hempel and a Mr Etheredge, remain in Canning Vale Remand Centre for month after month as extradition proceedings are brought against them. It was also recognised as a problem area by the Australian Government Solicitor, whose personnel in Western Australia pointed out that the information available was not sufficient. Interestingly enough, the ground of legal professional privilege was invoked by the Department as the excuse for not giving the Committee information about the advice given to the decision makers before the boat was handed over. In fact, the boat now has left Australia. That particular claim of legal professional privilege was challenged before the Australian Appeals Tribunal or the courts, I understand, and the information was then supplied to various people. So, I believe we have a double standard applying-one for the Parliament and one for the courts. This is quite unacceptable.

I am very glad to see that the Government has brought into the chamber a Minister who I hope will treat the chamber appropriately and I hope the people who are here representing the Department will be able to give Senator Ryan both the information necessary to answer Senator Newman's question and also the information necessary to comment on and answer my question to the Attorney-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a few points concerning the Department of Communications. I would like to point out, and I believe I will get support from other senators, that some of the questions that were asked about communications at Estimates committee hearings were not fully answered. However, in no way was the situation in this regard as bad as it was with the Department of Defence or the Department of Territories, which matter we will consider later. The question that I want to follow through with the Special Minister of State-and it is nice to see that we have a co-operative Minister in Senator Tate at the helm; it is fantastic-concerns the case involving Australia Post's attempt to close down the Watsons Bay Post Office. I have asked various questions about this matter and I referred to it in the second reading debate. This has brought to light Australia Post's failure to adhere to its proper procedures when considering the closure of postal agencies and post offices. The judge in this case, Mr Justice Wilcox, was quite scathing about the sloppiness with facts, the failure to consult, and the failure to consider what the closure of the post office would mean to the elderly in the Watsons Bay area who use that post office. I would like to quote from parts of the judgment that was handed down in Sydney on 1 April of this year. For instance, on page 11, we find that the decision-maker visited Watsons Bay before he decided to close the post office. But, Mr Justice Wilcox says:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Broadbridge failed to notice a TAB office and a supermarket in an arcade in the shopping centre. The opinion he formed was described in this way in his affidavit: `It was clear to me that many goods and services were not available to residents on site at Watsons Bay and as a consequence I formed the view and made the assessment that residents would need to attend other shopping locations (at which they would be likely to find postal facilities) on a regular basis in order to satisfy their normal consumer needs'.
The following comments were made at page 19 of the judgment:

The possibility of establishing an agency service at Watsons Bay was fleetingly referred to in the memoranda exchange between Mr Broadbridge and Mr Cumberland. In his initial memorandum of 12 May 1986 Mr Cumberland suggested only two options: One was to close the post office and sell the property and the other was to close part of the post office and leave the Postmaster, Mr Stammers, in residence. He did not in fact canvass the possibility of making the existing post office more cost efficient of the possibility of substituting an agency. In his reply, Mr Broadbridge commented: `There is a major omission in your assessment of the options associated with Mr Stammers's quarters', but he did not raise other options for providing a continuing service.
The question of an agency is taken up further on page 21 of the judgment, and it reads as follows:

There was considerable evidence from Mr Broadbridge about the possibility of an agency. Much of the evidence was given in response to questions asked by me because I found considerable difficulty in understanding the Commission's approach to the use of agencies. Since the hearing I have re-read the whole of Mr Broadbridge's evidence but my difficulty remains.

As Mr Eddleston's memorandum-in which he quotes from paragraph 7.1 of the Manual-reveals the Commission's policy does no contemplate the possible conversion of an official post office to an agency; but, ordinarily, only where the work load is less than one full-time job, equivalent to 125,000 work units. Where the volume of business is greater-as in the case of Watsons Bay-the available choice, according to the policy, is between keeping open a full post office-perhaps uneconomically-or closing down altogether. It seems that, within a certain range of figures, the greater the demand for postal services in an area the less chance there is of their being provided.

I could go on speaking in relation to the procedure followed in this case. The Australian postal service was misleading in relation to the situation at Watsons Bay and, in fact, the judgment was made against Australia Post. It is important that we make certain that Australia Post behaves much better than that. Although none of the facts associated with Australia Post's bad behaviour in the attempted closing down of the Watsons Bay Post Office are in dispute, Australia Post has not sought to justify its failure or to in any way correct the incorrect observations that it made. What has Australia Post done? It sought to have the judgment set aside on the grounds that the applicant did not have sufficient standing to bring forward the matter-the applicant being Mr Stammers, who is the Postmaster.

The major problem that we have here concerns a large organisation like Australia Post using its might against a small individual and refusing to allow that individual to have access to the law courts at reasonable prices and using the might of taxpayers' money to suppress information and to push its own procedures. I ask the Minister: What has been done in the light of the Watsons Bay case-which Australia Post lost-to improve the type of situation occurring in a number of areas, and that includes my local post office in Canberra at Aranda which is currently in the process of being closed. A number of places are involved and it does not seem that any lessons have been learnt from the Watsons Bay case. I believe it is extremely important that we make certain that large organisations like Australia Post be subject to proper scrutiny and that they do in fact follow sensible procedures. What is the Government doing about making certain that they do and that the appropriate standards are properly followed and that lessons are learnt when they in fact transgress?

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators will be aware, I am not overly familiar with the matter concerning the closure of the Watsons Bay Post Office and the subsequent court action that was taken. Senator Vigor will be well aware that Australia Post, and Telecom for that matter, do have a certain independence and autonomy from government as statutory bodies and not only that but, of course, they are off the Budget-they are funded in a non-budgetary way. So, whilst Senator Vigor's questions are very interesting, they are not quite related to the question of the Estimates that we are considering at the moment, although I would not say that he is not entitled to ask such questions. I think Senator Vigor has raises some very valid points. I think that the most valid concerned the questioning of the use of the locus standi rules to exclude a citizen from possible contest against a major statutory body providing public services. If indeed Senator Vigor is correct in saying that the appeal against the judgment of Mr Justice Wilcox is not being contested on the merits of the case but merely by excluding the person who was successful in the lower court on the ground of not having sufficient standing, I would think that the matter should be looked into a little further. I do not have sufficient details to comment on the merits of the decision that was made. However, it is quite clear that if indeed Mr Justice Wilcox's decision stands then not only Australia Post but Telecom, when it makes decisions about the closure of various agencies, will need to take into account the sorts of values which Mr Justice Wilcox found were not sufficiently attended to in the decisions made to close the Watsons Bay Post Office. That is as much as I can convey to Senator Vigor at the moment.

—The points that Senator Vigor made regarding questions asked by honourable senators in Estimates committees but which have not been answered also concerns me. One matter that concerns me is the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The Estimates committees allow honourable senators to find out from departments, on behalf of Australian taxpayers, how the taxpayers' funds are being spent. If honourable senators wish to save the time of some of the departments by putting questions on notice it then behoves the departments to answer the questions and send the answers to the honourable senators in a reasonable time. Recently the ABC has been rather slow in answering some questions. It should be remembered by it that if we try to help out during the Estimates committee hearings it should send the answers back to us more quickly than it has done in the past.

—Senator Brownhill went from saying that answers were not provided to saying that they were provided in a very untimely way. I agree that, insofar as it is possible to provide Senate Estimates committees with answers to questions that are put on notice, as Senator Brownhill said, in order to save time at the committee meeting, that should be done as speedily as possible. Having a quick look through the file, I can see that many of the questions asked, particularly by my friend and colleague Senator Vigor, were of a very detailed and cumulative kind, and no doubt it has taken some time to have them answered. Senator Brownhill asked: What is the cost of the 7.30 Report? I see that an answer is on the record. I do not know whether that was supplied in a speedy way. Many questions were put on notice, and no doubt it required a diversion, but a proper use, of resources by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I am sorry that honourable senators feel that they were not provided in an entirely timely way.
—Would the Minister suggest that in future we should be asking more questions at Senate Estimates committee hearings and not putting them on notice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, honourable senators need to put questions on notice because an official at the hearing is not able to assist the committee at that time. The sort of chastising that Senator Brownhill is conveying to the chamber will be relayed, I can assure him, to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the question of housing for members of the Australian Defence Force. The Special Minister of State (Senator Tate) would be aware, I am sure, as would the Senate, of the parlous condition in that area of government housing, with 60 per cent of the service houses considered by the Department of Defence to be substandard. Of course, that is not the end of the story. In addition to the substandard housing there are thousands more married personnel than houses and what houses we have are extremely badly maintained. I do not intend to labour the issue, but it has to be clearly understood that this situation is not to continue. I understood that the Government was committed to getting rid of it. I understood from the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who made a great splash about it recently, that he would set up the Defence Housing Authority and that all these things would be got rid of by the wave of a hand and $750m. Nothing of the sort will happen, by the look of it, because this so-called important legislation has been dropped from the legislative list. Obviously a double dissolution is of much greater importance to this Government than is the housing of the Australian defence forces. When 60 per cent of the married quarters for servicemen in this country is substandard and thousands of servicemen cannot be provided with married quarters and what they are provided with is disintegrating, what priorities does this Government have? It is just not good enough.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage, I draw the attention of the Senate to the maintenance by the Department of Housing and Construction of the defence assets. In the efficiency audit report of the Auditor-General, dated May 1987, the audit identified that under normal circumstances the minimum period between the date on which assets were first inspected and maintenance needs were identified and the date on which maintenance work was commenced was in order of 18 months. That is the minimum. Further on in the report it was revealed that it can take up to 30 months before something is repaired. At this stage I wish to refer to page 13 of the Auditor-General's Report. It states that, of the 1985-86 backlog of $118m in the Department of Defence, over $64m relates to the Army Office. The Army had a number of reviews of its assets, and the latest one was completed in August 1985. That review showed that the maintenance backlog was between $72m and $92m. Projections based on estimated future funding levels show that the backlog will be $128m by the end of the five-year defence program to 1990 and that the fundamental cause of the current backlog had been inadequate funding. The report went on to say that the fact that the Army's buildings were not collapsing did not constitute a denial of the existence of a serious backlog of maintenance. The problem was being kept under control only by the use of funds for recurring maintenance and the forced adoption of an increasingly expensive repair when failed approach. Thus, only the symptoms and not the causes of problems were able to be considered.

This is an extremely serious matter. Any government is looking at ways of saving money would surely be looking to ensure that what assets it has are properly maintained before it buys some more `you beauts'. The Minister for Defence is a great man for `you beauts', but he does not seem to be able to spare the cash to maintain what assets he has. This concerns not only defence housing but also defence assets of all kinds. In this section of the Estimates I have to draw attention to the fact that the Government has not considered the Defence Housing Authority of sufficient importance to ensure that it stays on the legislative program rather than get knocked off by this double dissolution which nobody needs but which obviously the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) thinks is the only chance he has of getting back into government.

TALK.START.PARA: —A big blunder!

—It is a big blunder, and we have a lesson coming for him. It will be a very short, sharp one indeed. He will be able to ponder on it at leisure. When we have servicemen living in the kind of accommodation that I have talked about and we have the Auditor-General mentioning the way the defence assets have not been maintained by this Government, I have to ask: What sort of professional service is the Department of Housing and Construction giving or expected to give by this Government? What is the Department of Defence trying to do about it to see that it gets a better service? We are talking here about many millions of dollars. We are talking about many millions of dollars in capital investment and many millions of dollars being spent on the stop-gap measures that are being used to try to keep the thing going. We have the forced adoption of an increasingly expensive repair when failed approach. What an indictment! What priorities does this Government have?

—I am delighted to reply to Senator Newman, who has given us a burst of rhetoric without much substance. Perhaps it goes down well in Tasmania. I inform honourable senators that the Defence Housing Authority has been established and in fact an interim board of that Authority has been operating for several months.
—And that is how you are going to operate it? You do not have an executive director. What are you going to do about that?
—I am about to tell the honourable senator. The chief executive officer will take up his appointment on 1 July.
—Who is it?
—Madam Chair, who has the floor? If Senator Newman wants to get up and ask more questions she can do so.
—Order! The Minister has the floor, Senator Newman.
—The chief executive officer will be-I wonder whether I am allowed to reveal this--
—Am I allowed!

—I do not want to go behind the back of the Governor-General or whoever may make the formal appointment, as you should understand, Senator Walters. The chief executive officer will be Mr Kirkby Jones, who has a very distinguished record in housing construction in Australia, as all honourable senators will know. I think that he will make a very fine chief executive officer. Insofar as the properly and permanently constituted board will come into effect and carry through the policies enunciated by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), I think that we are in a situation which is quite different from that which Senator Newman sought to portray.

—First of all, may I say that I believe the Government has made an excellent choice in its appointment. However, where is the vote that will enable this body to start work on 1 July? How can there be a permanent body without an Act?

—I am told that the appropriation is not within this group of appropriations. The Housing and Construction Authority acts as an agent for Defence in these matters. I do not have an immediate answer as to where the appropriation is in these papers, but I will undertake to provide it before the end of the consideration of Estimates.

—I would like the Minister to answer if he can. I understood that there was nothing on this matter in the defence estimates at all. I know that we have passed the defence estimates but we are still dealing with an area of the defence vote, even though it is under the housing and construction section. I do not believe that this appropriation was made in the defence vote.
—I am advised by my officers that the money is appropriated in Supply Bill (No. 1) 1987-88.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter relating to education which arose in Estimates Committee D and on which questions on notice were taken. It concerns student numbers in universities and colleges of advanced education. The question which I put and which has now been answered centres on a table which sets out for the years from 1974 to the present the number of equivalent full time students in universities and colleges of advanced education and the total number in higher education. This is a very important matter because this week we have received the report of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Committee of Principals and Directors of Colleges of Advanced Education. The report shows that this year between 13,000 and 20,000 students have been turned away from our universities and colleges of advanced education. That is a net figure. The gross figure of persons turned away from enrolment is 44,000. In South Australia more than one in four students eligible to attend a university or college of advanced education are being declined enrolment. That is a serious situation which shows an inability to accommodate the numbers of students who are eligible and able and who apply to enrol in our universities and colleges. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the answer given by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) which gives the figures for 1974 to 1987.
