TALK.START.PARA: —This table shows that the Minister has been totally misrepresenting the facts in three Press releases which she presented earlier this year. The first, on 19 January, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is making 3,000 extra places available to new students in 1987, bringing the number of new places we have created since coming to office in 1983 to 36,800.

That is incorrect. It is only correct in terms of the extra 3,000 places-a meagre number-compared with last year. It represents a very small increase between 1986 and 1987. The second Press release was on 25 February in which the Minister said that she was proud of the great achievements in education under the Hawke Labor Government. She went on:

In particular, the Government has dramatically increased the number of higher education student places by 40,000 since coming to power, compared with a miserly 8,000 places created by the Fraser Government in the previous four years.

This is a total misrepresentation of the facts, judging by the answer that the Minister gave in the Estimates Committee. The figure should be 32,900-not 40,000. The Minister has overestimated the gains that have been made since the first election of the present Government. Also she has underestimated the figure for the last four years of the Fraser Government. Instead of 8,000, the figure should be 13,400. Instead of there being a 5:1 comparison that the Minister subjectively sought to conjure up, there is a 2:1 comparison. I repeat that it is a 2:1 comparison, not a 5:1 comparison. In the first four years of the Fraser Government the increase was the same as that in the first four years of the Hawke Government. However, when the constraints of responsible government came to Australia in the late 1970s, there was a more established plateau which led to smaller increases. I acknowledge that this smaller increase was doubled-not multiplied by five-in the first four years of the Hawke Government. The present prospects are that there will be no increase at all.
The third Press release to which I refer was on 5 March 1987 when the Minister said:
While Labor has created 48,000 free higher education places since coming to power, the Liberals promise no new free places.

The statement should have read `36,000', not `48,000'. Not only has the Minister put out to the whole of Australia that the Hawke Government has created 48,000 new places when it should be three-quarters of that number, but also the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has quoted this figure several times in the House of Representatives as a result of information given to him by the Minister. The claim has been made that the Hawke Government has created a certain number of new places in higher education, in universities and colleges, when that has not been its true achievement.

Arising from the Estimates Committee answers that I have received, I want to clarify the facts. I draw attention directly to the table that the Minister provided. In 1975 the total number of enrolments in higher education was 222,700. Eight years later, in 1983, the figure was 264,700. During the eight years of the Fraser Government there was an increase in higher education student numbers-that is, equivalent full-time students-of 42,000. That figure of 42,000 is much greater than the lie that was put about by the Prime Minister and by the Minister that there were 8,000--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I ask for a withdrawal of the imputation that the Prime Minister told a lie.
—That is unparliamentary, Senator Teague, and I ask you to withdraw it.
—I am sorry to be so excited about this matter. I withdraw, but I demonstrate--
—There is no `but' about a withdrawal.

—I unqualifiedly withdraw. I wish to say that when this Government's representatives say `We have achieved 48,000 and the previous Government achieved 8,000', and the facts of the matter are that the achievements are much the same, it is a gross misrepresentation of the available opportunity for higher education in Australia. These figures give the lie to any statements that have been put forward before in this matter. In the first three years of the Hawke Labor Government the figure increased from 264,700 to 297,600. It is very clear from the table that has been incorporated in Hansard. It is an increase of 32,900 in three years. The comparison that must be established is that during the eight years of the Fraser Government there was an increase in equivalent full-time students in higher education of 42,000 and in the first three years of the Hawke Labor Government the increase was 32,900. I do not refer to the last line in the table, which is an estimate. It is acknowledged clearly by the Minister to be an estimate for this present year. I believe it is an overestimate because there is provision for 3,000 additional places for this year. This is shown in the Budget Papers and has often been referred to by the Minister. It appears in one of the ministerial statements from which I quoted a few moments ago. This is a crucial matter and I wish to make my statement clear to get the Special Minister of State (Senator Tate), who is now at the table, to acknowledge that my figures are correct. We have reached a completely inflexible impasse in the present Government's policy of providing new places in higher education. There were 44,000 people turned away from our universities and colleges this year. The university vice-chancellors and the principals of the colleges have brought that down to a net figure of 13,000 to 20,000. That is a considerable increase on the 9,000 to 14,000 of last year. This is a critical failure of the present Government's policies in higher education. The Liberal Party has put forward and published its own higher education policy. It is called a policy for growth in higher education and it opens the doors to those who have been turned away to be enrolled and to gain the advantages of a university, college or institute education. Through a scheme of higher education scholarships we propose that the same number of free places will be available as there is now but institutions will be able to enrol additional students on whatever terms they see fit. This lifting of the plateau and opening of the doors is a refreshing change for those who have been turned away by current policies. I make no excuse about the whole of the last decade; it seems to me to show a very slow growth pattern. I have given the figures squarely with regard to the Fraser Government. They are set out in the table, along with the figures from the present Government. One quarter of the growth is concentrated in universities and three quarters is concentrated in colleges of advanced education and institutes of technology. The latter are the cheaper courses, at an average cost of $6,000 per student compared with universities at $8,000 per student. The growth has been mostly in colleges of advanced education, which are cheaper for everybody, and that has been a consistent pattern in the last decade, as is very clearly set out in the table.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to spell out specifically one of the inadequacies in the Minister's three Press releases. There is no doubt that the 1983 student enrolment is an outcome of policies in 1982. Whatever moneys were provided in 1982 for student enrolment were determined by the Parliament and initiated by the Government. It is wrong to claim that the 1983 outcome is the result of the present Hawke Labor Government. In the same way, it is wrong to claim that the Fraser Government established the outcome in 1976, because that was determined by the Whitlam Government initiatives and parliamentary decisions of 1975. The figures in the Minister's statements vary from 36,000, 40,000 to 48,000-all of which are wrong. They mislead the Parliament and the public. These things are clarified in the table that I have had incorporated. I ask the Minister to acknowledge that there was a 42,000 increase in the number of full time students in the eight years of the Fraser Government compared with a 32,900 increase in the first three years of the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague presented a very complex set of figures. I am a little astonished by his enthusiasm for trying to diminish the achievements of the present Government, in particular the present Minister for Education, Senator Susan Ryan, by saying that we are only doing twice as well as the Fraser Government did in its last four years of office. He seems to think that somehow that is a matter of consolation but I do not believe it is. Even accepting his figures-and I have been unable to verify each of them and the various patterns that he was putting together as the speech was made-the claim that the Labor Government and the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, have done only twice as well over the last four years as the Fraser Government in its last four years is not something that the Liberal Party can take much consolation in.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to say that it is not merely a question of providing more opportunities for people to get into tertiary education institutions; it is also a question of providing the capital works-that is, the buildings for them to study in-and to have the support services, libraries and laboratories and so on for the educational process to be successfully undertaken. In that regard it is important to note that the building program undertaken in the various tertiary institutions throughout Australia has been quite significantly different-I would argue that it is much better-from that under the Fraser Government. On my campus in Hobart I know that, for example, the life sciences block which is presently being constructed is testimony to the interest and concern that this Government has in providing capital facilities. There was a huge backlog of such buildings on campuses of universities and tertiary institutions right across Australia, which is another factor in any comparative judgment to be made of the performance of the two governments. I am informed that there is some variation in figures caused by different ways of describing or characterising student places. Nevertheless, between 1983 and 1987 total student places in the higher education sector in Australia increased by some 42,400. I want to be accurate so will the honourable senator give me just a second to check?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand.

—This seems to be a plausible explanation in relation to the differences to which Senator Teague alluded. Under four years of Labor Government there has been an increase of 36,800 places fully funded by the Government in the tertiary sector. Of course tertiary institutions can take on more people than the number for which the Government actually funds that institution to provide education facilities. That makes plain some of the discrepancies which Senator Teague was concerned to point out.

SPEECH.PARA: The number of places actually occupied by Australians in higher education institutions is, I am advised, 305,000. If the honourable senator looks at the funding of higher education institutions under this Government-which has increased by $193m or 8.4 per cent in real terms to $2.5 billion-I think he will have a total picture of a commitment to higher education which, as I have said, is far superior to that achieved during the Fraser Administration. It is also not true to say-as I think Senator Teague was led in his enthusiasm to say-that no new places have been created this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the honourable senator looks at Hansard he may find that he made that claim in passing but 3,000 new places were created this year in such difficult times and I am glad that the honourable senator acknowledges that fact.
—I meant that the next year, 1988, there will be zero. There is no provision for new places next year.
—That matter is still to be considered in the Budget context. I am unable to say whether the honourable senator is correct in his forecast because that matter has not yet been determined.
—After the election.

—As per normal it will be considered in the Budget context. It is also important to note that the additional places have had an emphasis in the engineering, science and technology and business related disciplines. That has been a very definite emphasis of this Government in trying not only to meet the needs of students to be educated but also to anticipate their integration into the work force and their contribution to the sort of Australia that can create the wealth that can then be distributed so that we can all enjoy a fair standard of living.

SPEECH.PARA: The unmet demand is a very difficult concept. Gross figures are bandied about but, as I understand it, the Vice-Chancellor's Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals estimate for 1986 was between 11,000 and 16,000 places. I am advised that their estimate for 1987 is 13,000 to 20,000-an increase which is not unexpected given the 10 per cent increase in the number of year 12 students in 1986 which, in itself, is a commendable factor. At this moment that is as much information as I am able to give in response to Senator Teague.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up the time of the Committee much longer on this matter. I certainly appreciate the Minister's intelligent response to the matters I have raised. What I am saying to the Committee is this: The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) made three public statements-in January, February and March-all of which are patently wrong. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been induced to make comparisons which are very nice round numbers-40,000 places compared with 8,000 places. Those were the figures on his lips. He said `We have produced 40,000; the Liberal National parties, in a similar time, produced only 8,000' and those figures are wrong. The reason for my making the comparison 5:1 back to 2:1 is that in the extravagance of the first years of the Hawke Government there was expenditure beyond the ability of this country to pay given the policy guidelines for higher education of the Labor Government. The outcome in student numbers for the first four years of this Labor Government, compared with the last four years of the Fraser Government, increased by a factor of 2:1. However, over the whole eight years of the Fraser Government there was an increase of 42,000 places and the increase in the number of places during the first five years of this Government is less than that; it is 36,000 places. That establishes, in broad terms, a plateau, not a 5:1 advantage that the Prime Minister stated.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter bears on the question I put to the Minister on Tuesday and which was not answered in the Senate. The question followed the release on Sunday this week of the shortfall in the number of student enrolments, the unmet student demand. The Minister has confirmed that the figure for this year is 13,000 to 20,000, that is, a net figure after double entry, after all of the discounting that has to be sensibly undertaken, has been fully taken into account. Up to 20,000 eligible people who have applied for places and are ready to enrol have been turned away. That figure is more than a 20 per cent increase on the figure for last year. The pattern we are on, with the inflexible higher education policy of the Government, will see that number increase.

Given the state of the Australian economy, the overexpenditure of the first three years of this Government, the inability of taxpayers to front up to paying a greater amount in the taxpayer funded part of higher education, the Government's policy being inflexible and deriving only some $70m through the higher education administration charge and the Government indexing it and promising that it will never increase, the Government is totally locked in. There is no way, given the ceiling on taxpayer dollars, that there will be an increase in higher education enrolments. Yet the numbers involved in unmet demand are increasing.

Because this matter will be a major aspect of the higher education comparisons between the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party of Australia over the coming six weeks, it is important that the Committee notes that the propaganda of the Minister's Press releases in January, February and March and the Prime Minister's statements in the House of Representatives are not only distortions but also gross misrepresentations and that the correct table to measure any of the rhetoric from any party on this matter is the table that the Minister, through the Department, supplied to me in answer to a question asked in the Estimates committee hearing and which I earlier incorporated in Hansard. That table shows that if we do not change our higher education policies, this country is doomed to a plateau of zero growth in higher education places under this Government. This is not good enough to meet the technical and business needs of the community. I agree with the Minister's reply that the right emphasis is upon applied professions in business and technology. If we do not see a change of policy, such as that represented by the Opposition in this matter, higher education is doomed to stagnation.

I will conclude my questions by referring to that part of the question I asked on Tuesday in the Senate which the Minister did not answer. I asked: What are the Minister's precise estimates for reductions in student numbers next year in universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education institutions? What was announced in the May mini-Budget was a $12m reduction in funding for higher education in 1988. That sum is greater than the net amount that was to go to the 1,500 extra places arising from the higher education administration charge. By that decision in the mini-Budget of a $12m cut, the Government immediately has wiped out any ability for universities to increase student numbers next year. It is a worse situation in the TAFE sector. In that other most important area of post-school education, technical and further education, the cut is $30m for next year and $45m for the year after. The outcome in TAFE, despite the argument by the Minister that this will lead to the same student numbers except in stream six-the climb will occur in non-vocational courses-is not credible.

There will be a decline in universities, colleges of advanced education and in technical and further education as a result of the Budget cuts announced in the May mini-Budget. When asked about this on Tuesday, the Minister was not able to give any estimates as to what those reductions in student numbers would be. There is no credibility in saying `Oh, there will be an increase' because in the coming six weeks of this election campaign the public will want to know the Government's estimates for student numbers in universities, colleges of advanced education and in technical and further education. The public will not be content with hearing that there will be some manner of increase which we will all know about in the Budget.

I put it to honourable senators that with a $12m and $25m cut in higher education in two successive years and a $30m and $45m cut in TAFE there will be reductions that will add two extra lines to the table I referred to some minutes ago. Those reductions are in sharp contrast to the increases in student enrolments that will flow from the Liberal Party higher education policy and TAFE policy. There will be an enormous reduction in unmet demand as a result of Liberal Party policies.

At last, the distortion of statements by the Minister in the earlier months of this year has been exposed by her own table. The contrast between Liberal and Labor policies for post-school education is demonstrated to all. The public who wish to see mature age students and school leavers being able to apply successfully for a place in higher education or TAFE will be turning to the Liberal Party's policy as a basis for that achievement. I ask the Minister to say now what reductions there will be in student numbers in universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education in the next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be creating a funding situation where there will be a reduction in the numbers of student places in tertiary institutions in the next academic year, 1988. I am assured that the reduction of $12m in 1987-88 and $24m in a full year that Senator Teague hinges some of his expectation of reduction in places on, whilst it is equivalent to about one per cent of general recurrent funds for higher education, can be accommodated largely by recognising the efficiency gains in the system that have been made over the last decade. Nevertheless, it is recognised that the impact on various sectors and institutions will vary. Proper regard will be given to those institutions and sectors which have already achieved a certain amount of efficiency. There will not be an absolutely uniform, blanket impact on each institution to achieve that reduction of $12m in 1987-88 and $24m in a full year of general recurrent funds for higher education.

SPEECH.PARA: But it is quite wrong in terms of the Government's intention and expectation that any reduction in the number of places in tertiary institutions should take place next year. In fact, there will be continuing increases in the number of government-funded places in those institutions. As far as the constant dispute about figures is concerned, I am told that the previous Liberal Government in the last four years of its administration of that portfolio funded 8,100 places in tertiary institutions. In the four years of Labor government, we have funded 36,800 new places. If those figures are correct, and a Minister can accept only the best advice possible, and presuming that the computation is made with exactly the same basic characterisation of those places, then a ratio of 1:4 or 1:5 is implied in those figures. Insofar as that ratio is used in rounded terms in political rhetoric, there is some justification for it in the comparison of those two sets of figures. Therefore in that sense there is a proper justification.

I make the general political point that this problem-and it is a problem-that the Government and the nation is facing of ensuring that there are enough places in higher education, particularly for young Australians, has been brought about partly, which is somewhat ironical, by the great success of increasing the retention rates of students in the secondary sector. Certainly-and I know that Senator Walters from our Tasmanian experience would agree-in Tasmania, and no doubt in other States if figures were made available, there has been a very poor retention rate of students into years 11 and 12. The fact is that there has been an absolutely dramatic increase in retention rates across Australia of students to year 12. That has raised not only their level of education in the sense of completing secondary qualifications but also has raised their expectations and those of their parents. With the encouragement of their teachers no doubt numbers of them-this would have been inconceivable in the Fraser years-begin to think that they will apply to a tertiary institution, whether it be university, college of advanced education or some equivalent. In doing so, they create the so-called unmet demand which is so hard to quantify because we all know that many inquiries by students are made on enrolment days but are not always fully completed by proper enrolment by the Dean of Studies. Nevertheless, they are recorded-naturally it is in the interest of the institutions to record them-as fairly fully-fledged inquiries about the possibility of finding a place in an institution. So there is an unmet demand; there is no denying that. Its dimensions are very difficult to quantify exactly, but given the great retention rates that have been achieved in secondary education it is not surprising that there has been this bulge in those seeking places. That is why, even in this particularly difficult economic environment, the Government has funded 3,000 new places this year and, as I have said, will continue to fund places in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to move to a matter relating to the Austudy scheme. In brief, the Minister has strayed back and has claimed that there is a four to one comparison if we compare the first four years of the Hawke Government with the last four years of the Fraser Government. I assert that 1983 statistics are the outcome of policies determined in 1982. The 1976 statistics are the outcome of the Whitlam Government in 1975. Arrangements for the tertiary education assistance scheme and the provision of additional places in the calendar year of a university or college were determined by parliamentary and government decisions in a previous year. It is incorrect to claim that the 1983 outcome was achieved by the Hawke Government. The correct figures in that comparison are 13,400 additional places in the last four years of the Fraser Government and 32,900 places in the first years of the Hawke Government. I leave it to any objective observer to look at the table to which I have referred.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree that there is additional pressure with regard to unmet demand because of the retention of more Australian students in years 11 and 12 and that is a bipartisan goal in this Parliament. Both the Government in opposition and the Opposition in government sought to retain greater numbers of Australian school students in years 11 and 12. We have noted the increase from 30 per cent to 40 per cent and to 50 per cent. In the same way, we aspire to a goal of 60 per cent which has been set for the early 1990s, and so on. These policies are shared alike in this Parliament. Not only is there that pressure but also there is pressure from an enormous number of mature age students, particularly those aged from 23 to 40 who, having missed or not taken any opportunity for post-school education at an earlier age, are now seeking to study economics, business or any area connected with their profession. Those mature age entries into higher education have increased enormously.

I do not wish to go on about this. I wish to say that there is pressure from school leavers, which we acknowledge, and there is pressure from mature age entrants. The point is that this will not be satisfactorily met to the good of all Australians unless there is a change of policy. Whilst this Government persists with giving distortions such as those I have cited, which are thoroughly wrong, the Government will lose credibility and it will be seen to be dithering-as I believe it is-in not responding to the needs of Australia in higher education.

The second matter which I wish to raise concerns the Austudy allowances and, in particular, the general secondary scheme. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) and I have had quite a dialogue, on the record and off the record, with regard to the change in November last year when TEAS and the secondary allowance schemes were integrated and called Austudy. When we passed legislation last year the Minister told the Senate that the Government would be proceeding on the basis that all 16-year-old students and above in secondary schools who met specific family income test eligibility would receive Austudy and that payment would be made to the student. I protested on behalf of the Opposition and said that it should be able to be received, as in all preceding years, by the parent and that this Government and this Parliament should not interfere in the financial relationships between parents and student dependents.

In the debate on the legislation our view was put but it was not accepted because the Australian Democrats were persuaded that a family eligible to receive Austudy would receive a lesser amount because, in the admission of the Minister at the time, it would be taxable in the hands of the receiver. A third or more of that payment-but typically, one-third-would be taken away if it were put in the hands of a parent, who was a taxpayer, rather than a student who was not a taxpayer. At that time I urged, on behalf of the Opposition, that there should be a tax exemption for Austudy payments.

Following the end of the parliamentary session the Government had a change of mind. I was glad that wisdom and enlightenment were coming to the Government. To cut a long story short, the Minister determined that an additional page would be added to the application form so that parents could opt to receive the Austudy payment direct. I, and the Opposition, have questioned the grounds on which the Government maintains that that is lawful. That is, given the assurances that were made by the Minister last November and bearing in mind changes to the taxation Act, how is it that what was said in this place last November is now no longer true? The Minister wrote to me today. She set out answers to my questions of a month ago about this matter in a two-page letter. The Minister faithfully acknowledges that there was a change of mind on the Government's part. It was seen that an enormous number of parents wished to receive the payment direct and, therefore, an alternative would be considered. One of the two options was to take the line that I had advocated-that is, to exempt the payment in the hands of the recipient. That has not been accepted by the Government. Let me quote from the Minister's letter, which I received only this afternoon. It states:

The second option considered was to amend the tax legislation in such a way as to be able to pay the parent but still regard the allowance as assessable income in the hands of the student. While that is the arrangement that we have now taken up, it does bring with it problems of more complex administration and apparent inequity, since the tax system is based on the individual and not the family, as the unit. Recognition of those problems led us at the time-
that is, last November-
to reject the option and to decide in favour of payment to the student.
The last paragraph of this letter, which will lead me to my questions, states:

On the administrative side, the provision is expected to be reasonably complex, as I mentioned at the Estimates hearing. Details of the necessary changes to tax administration and legislation have not yet been finalised.

It was a month ago that I clearly asked the Minister these questions and she clearly understood them. Even the Department did, too. The Minister said that it was necessary to amend the law to achieve this. Accordingly, there is an amendment in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) that is now on our Notice Paper. I see no problem with that. As part of that statute law amendment Bill, no doubt it will be passed before we get up next week. But I ask these questions quite precisely as I do not wish the position of those parents who have opted to receive Austudy payments directly to be in any way jeopardised. The Minister has acknowledged in another answer that she gave to me yesterday that, as of the end of April, I understand, 13,000 parents had already opted for direct payment. If there had been full notice I imagine there would have been very many more. I want to make sure that those parents-13,000 in April, but the number is increasing-who want to receive this Austudy payment in the traditional way have a lawful basis for receiving the payment. I want to know that they will not be taxed and I want to know what all the difficulties that have not yet been finalised are. When will they be finalised? Will they be finalised tomorrow?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit unfair, Senator. Come on. You ask: `What are all the difficulties that have not yet been finalised?'

—I have already outlined these matters in the last 10 minutes, and if the Minister has not picked them up I will be happy to put them again. What has to be resolved is whether the allowance is in doubt or whether it is only the possibility of it being taxable that is in doubt? I want assurances that the matter will soon be finalised and that the payment of the allowance is not in doubt; and I want to know that the matter of the allowance not being taxable is not in doubt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Teague was correct in saying that the Government was persuaded by the concern of many parents that they should be the recipients of the Austudy payment, which no doubt is then used within the household, but primarily, I would hope, for the support of the student member of that household who is, of course, meant to be the beneficiary of that particular allowance. I think it has to be conceded that the eloquent advocacy of Senator Teague played some part in that persuasion. Nevertheless, I think it is important that parents who wish to take that option have their choice respected. In that regard, it has taken some time to devise the procedures to allow the transfer of those payments to parents where that has been requested and to put those procedures in place. I understand that those payments commenced on 6 May in order to coincide with the first pay day of second term in the majority of States. Where the first payment has not been made to the student by the end of first term, parents will receive the allowance backdated to the beginning of the year. As I said, I believe that that process commenced a couple of weeks ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague raised the very difficult question of whether it is necessary to amend the law to achieve the result of parents, although money is paid to them if their choice of that option is respected, not having to pay tax. I take it that Senator Teague means that the tax liability would be with the person of the student concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—I am not quite sure whether the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) is strictly necessary to achieve that purpose when the Minister has made a determination that the parents may receive the benefit if they so choose or whether this merely is being done in order to clarify the situation. Certainly this was a very real difficulty which was noted at the end of the year. I am not privy to the advisings which the Minister may have had on that matter. But it is true that the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1)-which will be passed at the end of this week if the arrangements for the guillotine are observed-does contain one provision which clarifies that situation and puts beyond doubt the legality of the payments which parents will be receiving over the course of the next several weeks. I do not have the terms of that provision in front of me but I would imagine that it has been drafted according to directions from the Department in a way which ensures the legality of those payments.
—So the allowances will not be taxable in the hands of the recipient parents and there will be no delay in continuing payments to parents. Is that right?
—I believe I can answer yes in relation to both those questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The final matter I wish to raise this evening on the education appropriations relates to the national policy on languages and the five-year debate that has ensued very constructively in this chamber about Australia's national language policy. One of the provisions in the response the Government gave to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts was the establishment of an advisory council on Australia's languages policy. The Government has already initiated an allocation of $100,000 in this financial year-and that has been supported by this Parliament-for the implementation of a national language policy. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) has made a commendable response to the Senate's inquiry, and I together with many of my colleagues and, indeed, a number of Government senators, commended the Government's commissioned response which was written by Joseph Lo Bianco.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government-not only by the first heralding of this measure in the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in Melbourne but also by the Minister's clear statement here-endorsed the report. Quite apart from the reinstatement of the English as a second language moneys that the last Budget denied Australian school students, some $28 million and some other related areas in language policy-quite apart from those hot political questions-the most urgent aspect of the implementation of this very important area that this parliament initiated and which the Government has properly taken up is the setting up of the advisory council on Australia's languages policy. There has been $100,000 set aside; a specific set of objectives has been set out for the council. There is a specific constitution for it. Four standing committees and two temporary committees are also well defined and nominees from various categories of persons are to be appointed.

We face some six further days of work in this Parliament and then six weeks of an election campaign-and it will be a couple of years before the country starts to make decisions again. I put this to the Minister: Will his government, or will I, as part of my government, be implementing this part of this report? I believe that after five years of deliberation, it is an urgent matter. It is also a matter that is testable in the election context. Will the Government be setting up this council to get on with the task of implementing the measures that the Government itself has endorsed; or will it be just deferred until after the election, as I gather will be the case with the first important area that I raised tonight from the vague deferral answer I was given?

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is: Yes, we will be in government when the necessary decisions have to be made. In fact, this will all be revealed when the Budget is brought down later this year. In light of the very clear endorsement of the Lo Bianco report by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) one could imagine that that endorsement of the report would be carried over into effective implementation of such key recommendations as those that have been outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take that as a direct deferral and a passing of the buck until after the election. In other words, this Government will not make a decision now to implement this important and urgent matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditures agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Senate tonight to a very important decision handed down today by the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in Victoria, Judge Rowlands, in the matter of Paul Chadwick, as applicant, and the Victorian Department of Property and Services, as respondent. The matter arose out of the events surrounding the by-election for the upper House seat of Nunawading Province, one which will no doubt go down in electoral history as having been initially a tie decided by a vote drawn from the hat and subsequently by a by-election determining the weight of the balance of power in the upper House.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of the conduct of that by-election, a complaint was received from an official of the Nuclear Disarmament Party about a how to vote card that he alleged had been circulated during polling and which appeared to be one issued by his party but which in fact was not. It suggested that voters give their preference votes in an order which would be advantageous to the Australian Labor Party when, in fact, the official policy and card of the Nuclear Disarmament Party did not advise voters with regard to preference votes. Following the complaint the Chief Electoral Officer of the State of Victoria was concerned to determine whether some person or persons had breached electoral law. He indicated before the Tribunal that he had formed the view from the outset that it was desirable for further investigations to take place, that on the face of the card it appeared that there was certainly a question as to whether, in fact, an offence had occurred, and that he did not regard himself as having sufficient legal knowledge to decide the questions involved.

Opinions were then sought from a variety of highly qualified legal personnel. Ultimately, advice was obtained from Mr Habersberger of counsel in relation to the matter, he having appeared for the Chief Electoral Officer in the Court of Disputed Returns in this very matter. He prepared an advice dated 9 October 1985 which indicated that the distribution of the card amounted to an offence, although it was a borderline case. The Crown Solicitor subsequently agreed with that opinion. A member of the Crown Solicitor's Office, who advises the police, also agreed with that opinion and, finally, so did the Director of Public Prosecutions. So there were four persons in unanimous agreement that a prosecution should be brought in respect of the matter.

In substance, the legal advices indicated that prosecutions might properly be instituted against some and named people, although a discretion was to be exercised by the Chief Electoral Officer. It subsequently appears that the Chief Electoral Officer provided those opinions to the Director-General of the Department of Property and Services, who then came back to him and suggested that he should consult the Solicitor General. An opinion was later received from the Solicitor General and junior counsel which suggested that no offence had been committed. In those circumstances, as that view differed from that of the four lawyers who had earlier considered the matter, the two barristers, Mr Habersberger and the Director of Public Prosecutions, were given an opportunity to consider the question again. Each, in substance, maintained his original position, so the fact was that all bar one of the legal opinions sought recommended prosecution of those involved.

The role to which I wish to draw attention tonight was that played by Mr Peter Batchelor, the Victorian Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, who issued a statement at that time conceding that he and others had had a personal involvement in the issue of the cards but stating that the ALP had not been concerned in the matter. I pause to remark that that is a laughable and incredible proposition. It is like the Prime Minister of the country going on to the hustings and making a statement saying that he was appearing in his private capacity as a citizen. It was certainly one that raised a great deal of controversy and speculation at the time, so that Mr Batchelor's behaviour and his self-serving explanation became a matter of very serious controversy. He maintained that his activities had been in the best interests of the anti-nuclear cause. I dare say that the true owners of the card that was purporting to be represented at the by-election would have disagreed with the proposition that what had happened was in their best interests. He also maintained that his actions were lawful. Subsequently, during a television interview, he outlined some amendments to the Electoral Act which he would propose, and in due course a Minister put forward some similar amendments which ultimately were not proceeded with.

The point of all this, Mr President, is that in today's judgment it was held that although legal privilege attached to those opinions and numerous other documents in dispute, the public interest outweighed that claim of legal professional privilege. Therefore, His Honour ordered the release of a series of documents, including those opinions. I should pause to add that the Department, through its counsel, the Solicitor General, then sought a stay of execution of the order. Therefore, the present situation is that until the expiry of, I think, a stay of 10 days we will not know whether the matter is to be appealed to the Full Court of the Supreme Court or, indeed, whether the Premier will take the course of simply releasing the documents and avoiding any further appearance of dragging the chain. But what is of the utmost concern is that, in dealing with the matters in his judgment-which are now, of course, on the public record-His Honour quoted a portion of the advice tendered by the Director of Public Prosecutions and in the course of so doing he exonerated the behaviour of a whole series of persons. Quoting the opinion, he said:

In the light of the enormous publicity this matter has received, surrounded as it has been with rumour and innuendo, I believe it is appropriate in this advice to state quite unequivocally that there is no evidence of the participation in this activity of any Minister of the Crown or indeed of any Member of Parliament. Nor is there any evidence of the participation in this scheme of the candidate Mr Bob Ives or his Campaign Committee.

Conspicuously and excruciatingly absent from that list of exoneratees is Mr Batchelor, the Secretary of the Labor Party in Victoria. As a result the decision, which refers to the critical role played by Mr Batchelor and discloses that the overwhelming weight of evidence was in favour of prosecution, leaves one with no reasonable alternative other than to infer that Mr Batchelor's role requires a great deal of further explanation. The judgment inevitably raises serious questions about his role and probity as an important public figure and these cannot be satisfactorily dispelled or confirmed until the opinions become available.

In these circumstances, Mr President, it is highly relevant to remember that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is already reeling from massive, self-inflicted wounds to his own integrity. Having metaphorically sworn on a stack of bibles that there would be no July election, he then turned around before the cock crowed thrice and promptly called a premature and wholly unnecessary election. In this situation, with his own integrity at stake, he is faced with the prospect of entering a critical election campaign with a very serious question mark hanging over the person who will be conducting that campaign in Victoria.

In these circumstances the documents in question-the legal opinions-ought to be immediately released so that there is no more stalling or filibustering or, alternatively, Mr Batchelor should stand aside until the appeal process is exhausted. Otherwise, the Federal Government will go to the people with an enormous weight of lead in its saddle bags and with questions as to the probity, responsibility and credibility of one of its most senior officials very much at issue. In these circumstances, it is encumbent on the Prime Minister to clarify Mr Batchelor's status and future role in the campaign. He has clearly played a critical and questionable role in the events surrounding that dishonest how to vote card and has made a number of self-serving and unbelievable explanations of his conduct. Therefore, in the light of today's judgment, it is unacceptable that he be permitted to remain in control of the campaign. If he does, the Government will then deserve the animus that will attach to it. There is no honourable course other than for Mr Batchelor to immediately stand aside from any future involvement in the campaign.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.41 p.m.
